TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Religion and Democracy in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned requests:
(i) that those of religious conviction who have contributed to the development of Australia should be recognised in the study of Australian history to ensure that a balanced history is taught;
(ii) that any syllabus prepared on the teaching of Civics and Citizenship should include the contribution of people of religious conviction highlighting their religious motivation;
(iii) that funds be allocated to ensure that teachers are given in‐service training on their role of religious influences in the development of Australian democracy; and
(iv) that materials are produced to support the above for use in the classroom.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are opposed to any moves to cut funding to universities.
We believe that funding cuts to universities can only have a negative impact on society and will impede the development of our Nation.
Furthermore, we are opposed to any increases to the annual amount payable by students via the Higher Education Contribution Scheme.
We believe that increases to HECS will discourage individuals from enrolling in universities.
We believe that university entry should be based upon relative merit, not relative wealth.
We believe that education has a direct social and economic benefit and appropriate levels of funding should be made available from public revenue.
Your petitioners therefore humbly petition that you will not cut funding to universities or increase HECS fees. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever ask.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we condemn the Federal government's proposed changes to HECS whereby the law degree will be placed in the highest HECS tier of the differential system for students commencing in 1997. We deplore this action for the following reasons:
1. The differential HECS system is inherently inequitable in that it exacerbates existing disadvantages confronting many students.

2. Law faculties have long been funded at the lowest level of the Relative Funding Model. As a result law faculties have been increasingly under‐resourced and over‐crowded, compromising the quality of legal education.

3. Course costs cannot be used to justify placing law in the highest category. Such a system places law students at a double disadvantage—high levels of HECS and inadequate resources. Furthermore, the majority of law students are also required to pay considerable amounts for their practical legal training, and as such already face a significant financial burden.

4. Law courses lead to a variety of occupations such that there are vast earning differences between law graduates regardless of whether they are in the legal profession or otherwise. The reality is that 50 per cent of law graduates will not enter the legal profession.
We strongly oppose the Federal Government's cuts to higher education funding and proposed alterations to HECS.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, most humbly ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, abandon these destructive policies immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hinchinbrook Development Project
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia expresses our grave concerns about the conflict in Sri Lanka as arguably the most significant crisis in the Commonwealth of Nations of which Australia is a member.

We understand that both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have expressed their concerns about the conflict and have advocated sending a fact‐finding parliamentary delegation to Sri Lanka. They have also emphasised the need for an internationally mediated peaceful resolution to the conflict that would bring greater autonomy for the Tamils in Sri Lanka.
We therefore pray that the members of the Senate call on the government:

PARA.TAB: to persuade the United Nations to authorise a delegation to carry out a fact finding mission to Sri Lanka.
to appeal to the Sri Lankan government to lift the economic embargo and allow Non‐Government Organisations to carry out emergency relief works without any government interference in the Tamil areas.
to appeal to the parties to the conflict to stop the war and negotiate a political solution that recognises the right of self‐determination of Tamils.
to persuade the parties to the conflict to accept the role of an independent "Envoy" to facilitate a negotiated peaceful resolution to the conflict under international observation.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That mental health service consumers and carers are already significantly disadvantaged by the current poor funding of mental health and psychiatric disability support services.
That the 1996 Federal Budget will halve the Medicare rebate where a person visits a psychiatrist more than 50 times in a year.

That people with mental health problems such as chronic depression, eating disorders, dissociative disorders, or who may have suffered childhood abuse require access to long term intensive therapy. Decreased access to service by private psychiatrists will result in increased hospitalisation for those most in need.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will increase the cost of prescriptions for people on the Disability Support Pension. While the cap on the total cost of prescriptions in a year remains the same, people who are already living below the poverty line will be required to pay more from their fortnightly pension until the cap is reached.

That the 1996 Federal Budget will cut $14 million from Commonwealth Mental Health Programs. This funding had been made available to address serious problems and under‐funding in mental health services in Australia.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that you will oppose cuts to mental health services and increases in the cost of prescriptions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Petition: Unfair & Immoral Act Against Tamils

SPEECH.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives
The Honourable President and the Members of the Senate

We are saddened and distressed about the Hon. Alexander Downer's statement in Parliament on 5 November that `He is willing to meet with Tamil groups in Australia provided that they indicate to him, in writing, that they condemn the terrorist activities of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam'. By doing this, the Minister has made the inference that all Tamils/Tamil Groups in Australia are in some way responsible for actions of the LTTE.

We cannot honestly comprehend this rather peculiar position taken by the Minister against a section of the Australian community in a selective manner. We are also confused over the motive behind the Minister's statement at a time when it is the Sri Lankan government troops who are daily committing terrible atrocities against the innocent Tamils in the occupied areas and pursuing a military solution to the crisis under the pretext of waging a `war for peace'.

We are living in Australia and we are advocating for a peaceful resolution to the civil war. Regardless of what the minister said, it has always been the position of the Australia Tamils to condemn all violent activities in Sri Lanka, be it the LTTE or the Sri Lankan government. Thus, we are unsure about why he singled the Tamils out as the ones needing to condemn the terrorist activities in Sri Lanka.
We therefore pray that the House of Representatives and the members of the Senate call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade:

PARA.TAB: to reconsider his discriminatory statement
to set the same precondition for all parties to the conflict to meet him
to meet the Australia Tamils
to design a strategy to develop a condition for peace with justice, human dignity and equality in Sri Lanka

PARA.EMPHASIS: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1996

BREAK.PARA: The proposed Bill will legislate the Commonwealth's program of assistance for Government and non-Government schools in the States and Territories for the 1997‐2000 quadrennium.

The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992, which legislates the 1993-1996 schools program, expires at the end of 1996. It is imperative, therefore, that the Bill to enact the schools program for the 1997-2000 quadrennium be introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring Sittings of Parliament ahead of the commencement of the program. Should the Bill not be given passage then there would be no Commonwealth program for schools beyond 1996. Consequently, in excess of $3 billion in funding annually would not be available to the States and Territories.
As the Bill was heavily dependent upon decisions taken in the development of the 1996/97 Budget, it was not possible to have it drafted for introduction in the 1996 Winter Sittings.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone

PARA.EMPHASIS: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

BREAK.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 would give effect to a number of measures affecting the social security portfolio that were announced in the 1996 Budget.
In summary the amendments would:

allow a grace period for renewal of medical certificates for sickness allowees, allow continuation of sickness allowance after 52 and 104 weeks and remove sickness allowance loss of income provisions;
introduce a revised impairment table for use in the assessment of disability support pension;
allow telephone lodgement of claims for disability related payments;

rename "carer pension" as "carer payment" and provide greater flexibility to carers by allowing carers to engage in up to 20 hours voluntary work, paid employment, education or training (currently 10) and to increase the number of days (from 42 to 52) that a carer may cease to provide care for a person before the carer ceases to be qualified for a carer pension;

provide for simplification measures for widows and partners by phasing out widow B pension earlier, extending qualification for widow allowance to women aged at least 50 and who were widowed, divorced or separated after turning 40 years of age, extending eligibility for partner allowance to AUSTUDY partners, aligning conditions of payment of widow allowance and partner allowance and providing for the automatic transfer to age pension of recipients of widow B pension, widow, partner and mature age allowance who reach age pension age;
target assistance for the unemployed by modifying waiting periods so that they depend on a person's level of resources and entitlements rather than on arbitrary fixed periods;
tighten the activity test for the unemployed and rationalise and simplify the penalties for activity test breaches;
consolidate and simplify voluntary work provisions for the unemployed;
abolish the earnings credit scheme;
abolish the employment entry payment;
abolish the education entry payment except for social security pensioners;
modify the social security pension, social security and youth training allowance advances scheme;
apply a deeming rate of 5% to a person's first $2,000 ($4,000 for a couple) savings in deposits with financial institutions or held as cash;
apply the parental income test to youth training allowance and sickness allowance recipients under 18;
limit arrears of child disability allowance;
provide for the recovery of excess payments that are not currently recoverable debts;
extend the compensation provisions to age pensioners;
enhance the treatment of lump sum compensation payments; and
rationalise concession card arrangements.
The Bill also contains a non-Budget measure that would ensure that the compensation provisions relating to youth training allowance are aligned with those applicable to social security payments.

It is necessary to secure passage in the 1996 Spring Sittings to ensure that the implementation date of the measures (mostly 1 January 1997 or 20 March 1997) may be achieved. In addition, substantial administrative and systems work has to be undertaken to successfully implement these measures on the various proposed commencement dates. The exact nature and extent of this work cannot be finalised until the enabling legislation has been enacted.

The Bill could not have been introduced earlier as the measures in the Bill (except for the non-Budget measure) could not have been undertaken any earlier as they are the result of 1996 Budget decisions.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister for Social Security.

PARA.EMPHASIS: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FURTHER BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

BREAK.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 would give effect to a number of measures affecting the Social Security portfolio that were announced in the 1996 Budget. In summary the amendments would:
introduce a separate lower maximum rate of rent assistance for single people who share accommodation;

remove the means test exemption of assets held in superannuation and rollover funds by social security recipients under age pension age for people aged between 55 years and age pension age after nine months on income support; and
provide for new holiday processing arrangements for all social security benefits the payment of which is stimulated by lodgement of a statement by the beneficiary.

It is necessary to secure passage in the 1996 Spring Sittings to ensure that the implementation date of the measures may be achieved. Substantial administrative and systems work has to be undertaken to successfully implement these measures on the various proposed commencement dates. The exact nature and extent of this work cannot be finalised until the enabling legislation has been enacted.
The Bill could not have been introduced earlier as the measures in the Bill are the result of 1996 Budget decisions.
This statement is circulated with the authority of the Minister for Social Security.

The proposed Bill will provide a limited Medicare Access for new medical practitioners that do not have post graduate qualifications. It will remove the mechanism for individual claims to be made for higher Medicare benefit to be paid for services of unusual length or complexity. It will increase the maximum gap from $29.30 to $50 between the Medicare benefits and the Schedule fee for any out of hospital service.
The Bill also provides a regulation making power to allow Schedule fees to be adjusted where services are rendered to a patient on the same day as is rendered a diagnostic imaging service.

Passage before 1 November 1996 will allow changes to be incorporated into the next Medicare Benefits Schedule production and thereby achieve Budget savings targets. Any delay in passage of the Bill will seriously affect savings.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Health and Family Services
The purpose of this Bill is to amend Part VII of the National Health Act 1953 to give effect to the following changes in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, announced in the 1996-97 Budget:
increase the patient contribution for general benefit prescriptions, concessional benefit prescriptions and concession card prescriptions
amend the indexation arrangements for both general and concessional patient contributions and safety net thresholds
restrict access to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to persons eligible for Medicare benefits (including visitors from countries with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement)
A commencement date of 1 January 1997 will apply to these changes. This date has been selected to coincide with the commencement of the next pharmaceutical benefits safety net year.

If the Bill is not passed by the end of the year, the changes would have to be delayed until the com mencement of the following safety net year, ie., 1 January 1998. It would clearly be inequitable to make changes to patient contributions and safety net thresholds during the year, as some patients would qualify for the safety net under one set of conditions whilst others would be subject to a different set of conditions.
Delaying the changes by one year would involve forgoing one year's reduction in outlays, estimated to be about $ 170 million.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Health and Family Services

PARA.EMPHASIS: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1996

BREAK.PARA: The proposed Bill will amend the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 by supplementing the 1996 general funding to the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) in line with normal price movement adjustments, reduce general funding and conditional off-the‐job training funding provided to ANTA for 1997, appropriate general ANTA funding for 1998 and appropriate conditional off-the‐job funding for ANTA in 1998.
As the Bill includes supplementation to general funding to ANTA for the current year and a reduction in general funding for 1997 it must be introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring Sittings.

If the Bill is not introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring Sittings, the flow of funding to ANTA, and consequently to the whole vocational education and training sector, will be significantly disrupted.

As the bulk of the funding is provided to State and Territory governments, there is potential for relationships between the Commonwealth and the States and the Territories to be adversely affected if supplementary payments relating to 1996 funding are delayed in 1997, or if the planning of vocational education and training activities for the 1997 calendar year is fundamentally distorted because it is based on an incorrect amount.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone

The Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 giving effect to the Government's Budget commitments of enhanced quality in education and provision of scholarships, increased independence for institutions and a more diverse higher education sector with wider choices for students. At the same time it contains a package of measures that contributes to the Government's savings task in the fairest way possible while advancing key objectives for the higher education sector and setting the framework on which the sector can build for the future.

Amendments contained in the Bill achieve a fairer balance between public and private funding of higher education. To achieve that balance, new Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) charges will be introduced having regard to the anticipated salary levels of graduates and the wide range of course costs. Through another amendment, individuals will repay their HECS and Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme (OLDPS) debt more quickly through a reduction in income thresholds at which repayments are to commence.

The Bill will give Australian students the same opportunity as overseas students to purchase an undergraduate place at a Commonwealth funded Australian university. From 1998, universities will be able to charge fees for Australian undergraduate students only after the target number of places for HECS-only students are filled. For health policy reasons, the Bill excludes Medicine, as the Government wishes to limit the number of medical graduates. The overwhelming majority of students will continue to contribute to their education through HECS alone.

The Bill will give the Open Learning Agency the discretion to set the level of charges for its higher education units but will maintain at the present level the amount of the charge which may be deferred by clients under the OLDPS.

The Bill furthers the Government's commitment to equity in higher education by providing annually 1,000 merit based scholarships, building over four years to a total of 4,000. The scholarships target equity groups including students from low socio‐economic, rural and isolated backgrounds and Indigenous Australians. Scholarship recipients will be fully exempted from the HECS charge.

The Bill provides responsible levels of funding for teaching and research. Funding for research infrastructure, collaborative grants and Australian Postgraduate Awards is increased, and funding for the Capital Development Pool is continued as previously announced for 1997 and 1998. Additional funds are provided for administrative support to assist with the changed administrative arrangements during the transition to the new HECS arrangements. Supplementation is provided for price movements in line with the indexation arrangements announced in the 1995 Budget.

The Government has developed a comprehensive package of measures for the higher education sector that gives greater flexibility to universities in generating revenue whilst ensuring that qualified students will not be prevented from entering higher education because of their inability to pay. Given the long lead times involved in planning for higher education institutions, it is important that measures contained in the Bill be in place for 1997.

The Bill represents a tightly integrated package of initiatives which contributes to the Government's savings task in the fairest way by achieving a more equitable balance between public and private funding. The legislation must be introduced and passed in the 1996 Spring sittings to ensure that changes to funding levels, including the increase in research funding, Australian Postgraduate Awards and funding for scholarships, are available to students from 1997. The measures in the Bill have regard to the planning timetable of higher education institutions and Government commitments not to increase the HECS levels for existing students.
Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator the Hon Amanda Vanstone

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, I seek leave to table and incorporate in Hansard a report to the Senate on the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

As chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances I would like to report to the Senate on aspects of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996, which will make important changes to the ability of parliament to scrutinise and, if the Senate wishes, to disallow legislative instruments. The committee believes that it should report on the bill before the second reading debate, so that Senators can come to the debate with forewarning of a number of issues which the committee regards as matters of concern. At the outset, however, I am pleased to say that the committee supports the bill, subject to a number of important exceptions which I will address shortly.

The basic structure and purpose of the bill is encouraging, resulting generally from recommendations of a 1992 Report by the Administrative Review Council, Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies. An earlier bill to implement these recommendations was introduced into the Senate on 30 June 1994. The Selection of Bills Committee then referred the bill to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I am pleased to recall that the then government accepted all of the major recommendations of the committee, which has therefore already had a significant input into the bill.

In my remarks on the bill I will concentrate on its effects on parliament. The bill will in a number of ways enhance the ability of parliament to scrutinise delegated legislation. The bill will increase the types of legislative instruments which are subject to tabling and disallowance, numbers of which at present may be made and operate without any parliamentary oversight at all. Also, the bill requires legislative instruments to be tabled within six sitting days, instead of the present 15. This is a considerable improvement, because 15 sitting days can cover a period of months, during which parliament may not be even be aware that an important instrument has been made and is in operation. The bill provides for tabling of Explanatory Statements. This again is an improvement. Although the efforts of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee have ensured that all legislative instruments are now accompanied by adequate explanatory material, formal provision for this is appropriate. A House of the parliament may also now require material which is incorporated in an instrument to be made available. Here also the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has not had any problems when requesting such material, but provision for this in the bill is not inappropriate. The bill also provides for motions of disallowance to be postponed for up to six months and in some situations this could be useful.

The bill, therefore, promises much, the second reading speech advising of a significant shift in control over delegated legislation back towards the parliament. However, the actual provisions include a number of exemptions which diminish that parliamentary role.

The committee has initiated considerable correspondence with the Attorney‐General and with other Ministers about its concerns with the areas of the bill which dilute parliamentary control. Together with the committee's Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Whalan, I have had several lengthy meetings with the Attorney‐General to discuss these concerns and the committee is grateful for this courtesy by the Minister. The efforts of the committee resulted in government amendments to the bill in the House of Representatives to meet some of our concerns and here again the committee is grateful for this action by the Attorney‐General. Nevertheless, four areas of concern remain.

The first area of concern to the committee is a provision under which the Attorney‐General may give a conclusive certificate that an instrument is either legislative or not legislative. If the Attorney certifies that the instrument is not legislative then parliament has no powers at all in respect of that instrument. The executive can then make any laws it likes under that particular provision without parliament even knowing, far less having the opportunity to disallow the instrument. Such a certificate by the Attorney is reviewable by the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, but review under that act is only available in respect of procedural legalities. In any event, anyone wishing to take action in the Federal Court would apparently have to pay tens of thousands of dollars in lawyers' fees. The power of the Attorney to give conclusive certificates, reviewable only on the procedural formalities, is a serious diminution of the rights of parliament.

The committee believes that these conclusive certificates should be subject to disallowance by either House. This will ensure the proper position of parliament in what is really the starting point of the scrutiny of legislation. Delegated legislation only exists because it is authorised by parliament and it is appropriate that parliament should decide whether such instruments should be subject to scrutiny. In this context I note that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee both recommended that certificates be disallowable. Of course, making the Attorney's conclusive certificate subject to disallowance will not affect the right of anyone to seek Federal Court review, if that is their wish.

Secondly, the bill generally excludes instruments which provide for national schemes of legislation from parliamentary disallowance. These schemes, which involve the Commonwealth and the States and Territories, are likely to become more important and it would seem to be quite fundamental that parliament should scrutinise this legislation. To exclude it from parliamentary control would not seem to be compatible with the stated aim of the bill to give parliament a greater scrutiny role. The committee believes that parliament should have the same options over such instruments as it has over other legislation, much of which is of far less consequence than national schemes. It is incongruous that the national parliament should not have control over national legislation. At present the committee scrutinises uniform national scheme regulations and, as the then chairman of the committee, Mal Colston, reported to the Senate on 19 September 1995, the committee has received good cooperation from ministers in this scrutiny.

Thirdly, the bill excludes Quarantine Act proclamations from disallowance, although not from tabling. This exemption was not originally provided for in the present bill, but was introduced as a government amendment. The supplementary explanatory statement gives no explanation at all for the exclusion of disallowance, which appears to be another unnecessary limit on parliamentary control. Breaches of these proclamations incur various penalties of up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine of up to $100,000. It is inappropriate that legislation resulting in such penalties should not be subject to disallowance.

Fourth and finally, but not least, the bill provides that prescribed instruments providing for terms and conditions of commonwealth employees are deemed not to be legislative instruments. This means that such instruments will not even be tabled in , much less be subject to disallowance. This exemption could include, for instance, determinations of the Remuneration Tribunal which provide for salaries and conditions of ministers, parliamentarians, judges and members of Commonwealth statutory authorities. At present, of course, these are subject to full parliamentary disallowance. Last year the Regulations and Ordinances Committee scrutinised 300 of these instruments which the bill now proposes may be excluded from the control and even knowledge of. Most of these were made under delegation or supervised by officers of the Department of Industrial Relations. The committee finds numerous defects in these instruments. In the last week alone I have signed letters to the Minister for Industrial Relations about one Determination which was certainly invalid, another which appeared to be invalid and others which did not comply with the enabling act. Here again this provision is incompatible with the stated aim of the bill to shift control over delegated legislation back towards the parlia ment. The fact that such exclusions must be prescribed is not a satisfactory safeguard, because there could be a period of some months between making and the next sitting day, during which defective instruments could be made and which would remain in force even if the regulations were disallowed.

In summary, then, the Regulations Ordinances Committee supports the general thrust of the bill and the great majority of its provisions. The bill will assist the committee to carry out its function of ensuring that legislative instruments are of high quality and, as I mentioned earlier, will in most areas improve the position of parliament as against the makers of legislative instruments. However, there are exemptions to the main principles of the bill which exclude parliament from its proper scrutiny role and which may even take away scrutiny powers which parliament presently enjoys. On behalf of the committee I draw these defects to the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, together with the submissions received by the committee and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The statement read as follows—
Madam President, I present the report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996.

The Bill makes a number of amendments to the 1988 Act. The Committee's report addresses three major initiatives introduced by the Bill, namely: modifications to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS); removal of the prohibitions on offering full fee paying places to Australian undergraduate students; and the provision for the Open Learning Agency to charge for delivering units of study.

The Bill introduces three changes to HECS. First, it lowers income thresholds for repayment of accumulated HECS debt. Second, it provides for an overall increase in contribution levels. Third, the Bill introduces differential HECS contributions from 1997.

These measures refine the current HECS system by striking a better balance between public and private funding of higher education. The differential HECS does this in two ways. The contribution students make will now more closely reflect the actual costs of the courses they study. It will also reflect more closely the private benefits to graduates in terms of expected income in their private careers.

The Committee noted that the average level of HECS contribution under the new system is about 27 per cent of course costs when discounts, such as the interest-free-deferral, are taken into consideration. In international terms, this level conforms to the general range of private contributions to public higher education.

It is too early to predict the impact of the new HECS system on participation rates by students. The Committee therefore believes that the effects of the modified HECS are monitored closely. In particular, the Committee considers that high priority should be given to monitoring access and participation trends according to discipline and socio-economic status.

The Committee also believes there may be a case for science units to be assigned to a lower HECS band than is currently proposed. This depends on whether there is an adverse impact on demand for science courses as a side-effect of the differential HECS. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the allocation of science units to HECS band 2 be adjusted in the event of there proving to be an adverse effect on demand for science as measured by enrolments.

The Bill opens the way for universities to offer full fee paying places to Australian students. This measure addresses the current anomaly which allows for universities to offer places to foreign full fee paying students but prohibits universities offering full fee paying positions to domestic students.
It is important to note that fee‐paying places will be additional to the number of government‐funded places available to Australian undergraduates.

Universities will only be able to enrol fee paying students once they have fulfilled their HECS quota. With any course, the number of fee-paying students will not be allowed to comprise more than 25 per cent of enrolments. Any university which enrols a full fee paying student without first fulfilling its HECS course quota faces an automatic penalty of $9000 for each full fee paying student.

The Committee believes that these restrictions will prevent full fee paying enrolments from crowding out HECS-funded enrolments in higher education. Indeed, it is possible that this measure will free up HECS-funded places in the higher education system for people who currently miss out on places. As some students elect to pay full fees for their first-choice course, they will leave open a HECS-funded place for other students to fill.

The Committee also examined the claim that the provision for the Open Learning Agency to determine the fees it charges is a pilot scheme for applying a fee system broadly across the higher education sector. In the Committee's view, this claim appears fanciful as the unfunded OLA system differs from the government-funded undergraduate system.
The Committee recommends that the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 be passed without amendment. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee deals with the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. The minority report is tabled within this report. The dissenting report is presented to the Senate by Australian Labor Party senators and Democrat senators, and seeks to highlight just how grave and unjust this bill is. It seeks to highlight the essentially inequitable basis on which this government is seeking to administer higher education policy in this country. This bill and associated measures in terms of reductions in operating grants are a means by which this government will seek to achieve drastic reductions in higher education expenditure over the next four years.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to questions that I sought from the department through the estimates process, the extent of those reductions is abundantly clear. The answer to question Nos 9 and 10 published in the additional information booklet to the Senate from the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee clearly shows the cuts to the higher education sector. Under program 2.1 they are given effect substantially by this piece of legislation and demonstrate that the government is seeking to remove over the forward estimates period $1.956 billion from the higher education system. If we include additional new initiatives the government is taking, the net effect of the reductions in higher education expenditure according to the department is $1.821 billion.

The government says, `That is not the real impact because the revenue measures being introduced through the changes to the higher education contribution scheme mean that the overall reductions are much smaller.' What are the attempts being made by this government to raise revenue? The total impact according to departmental figures is $1.130 billion. It is a very dramatic attempt by this government to change fundamentally the nature of higher education in this country over the life of this parliament. I do not think we have seen many opportunities for governments to embark on such a radical restructure of higher education as we are seeing by this minister.

There is an attempt to turn the clock back, to change the direction of higher education, to reduce its overall impact in terms of equity and access, and to make it much more difficult for ordinary Australians to go to university if they do not have the money. They are trying to change a system of higher education fundamentally based on achievement by merit to one of attainment by wealth. That, to me, is the essence of the fundamental injustice of these proposals that are reviewed by this report.

For over a decade the Australian government has sought to turn Australia's education system from a minority elitist system into a mass education system. What this government is seeking to do is to undermine that achievement. We have seen the real level of Commonwealth expenditure increase by some 70 per cent under the Labor government. We have seen an expansion in the number of students by some 69 per cent. In fact, there was a growth in funding to support a program aimed at ensuring there was a mass higher education system in this country, which is fitting and highly appropriate for an advanced industrial country such as ours.

However, this is not the sort of model that this government wishes to follow. This government is seeking to ensure that there is no longer equality of opportunity, that there is no longer governments seeking to achieve that opportunity or equality but seeking to pursue a policy aimed at ensuring that those with wealth get the benefits out of the actions of government in higher education.

Working class children and working class people will be disadvantaged as a result of the policies being pursued by this government. We are seeing a government pursue a policy which is fundamentally aimed at destroying the dreams and aspirations of many people in this country who believe education is their right. The government ought to provide assistance to ensure the achievement of that right of every Australian to go to university or enjoy the benefits of higher education through universities and TAFE colleges.

Quite clearly that program is being undermined by this legislation. What we are seeing here is an attempt to increase the charges for higher education—increased fees and increased HECS. We will see an increase of over 70 per cent on average under this proposal. The government will seek to charge new students HECS contributions of $4,169 compared with the current rate of $2,478.

We will see an application of a differential rate of HECS, so discrimination will be built into the system. This is an inherently discriminatory model adopted in pursuit of a budget driven agenda to back up this ideological obsession with the removal of government activity and to undermine the state responsibility for education in this country. That is basically what it is about.

We will be seeking through this Senate to have that policy changed. We will be asking senators to join us in avoiding some of the most draconian aspects of these policy changes. We will be seeking Senate support for a proposition to protect the rights of ordinary Australians to decent education standards and to ensure the continued protection of Australian students from the prospect of being charged up‐front fees for basic university undergraduate courses.

We all understand just how biased the system currently is. No-one pretends for a moment that the concept of equality of opportunity has been fully realised. It has been dramatically improved in the last 10 years, but it has not been fully realised. We all understand that. The government's response is to say, `We acknowledge that there are not enough people from various sections of our society going to university. To improve that we will make it more expensive. We will make it harder for the sons and daughters of working people to go to university.'

That is the government's idea of improving equity—to increase the charges, to increase the cost of going to university. Quite clearly, that is a proposition that is not sustainable logically. I hope that a majority of senators acknowledge that point and seek to change the government's mind by not accepting this legislation and not accepting the premise on which it is based—the fundamental unequal treatment for different citizens of this country.

It is not just HECS that is being changed through this legislation; there are a whole series of measures which are aimed at undermining the equity of the Australian higher education system. It is designed primarily to justify the reduction of some 17,000 Commonwealth funded places at universities across this country.

Of course, the minister will argue that there will be an opportunity to expand the number of places, but that is predicated on one assumption—that is, you do not have to have the brains to go to university, but you will have to have the money. That is a system of education that this parliament ought reject. It ought reject that basic unequal system of education and ensure that we restore some equity, some balance and some commitment to providing equal opportunities for all Australians. We should be striving to achieve that objective, not turning our back on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today on behalf of the Australian Democrats to speak to the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee report on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill. Senator Carr has mentioned the changes that we have seen mooted over the past couple of months to the higher education sector. The pace, the extent and the rate at which these have occurred have been unprecedented in this country. Many of the changes that have been put forward by this government and by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) in particular are quite regressive.

SPEECH.PARA: The report sought advice from a number of expert witnesses—from the National Tertiary Education Union through to the National Union of Students. Dr Bruce Chapman, the architect of HECS, was a notable witness. He, like many of the people who appeared before the Senate committee, voiced his concern and outrage at some of the promoted changes for the higher education sector.

As Senator Carr said, the financial extent of the cuts that have been made to the higher education sector over the triennium is massive. The estimate that has been put forward previously by the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee has been a loss to the sector of around $1.8 billion over the three years. But, in fact, as Senator Carr reported and is mentioned in our dissenting report, in the estimates committee hearings we were told that an estimated $1.956 billion was to be ripped out of the higher education sector over the next three years.

The higher education funding bill that we are dealing with not only details the proposed changes to HECS. We are looking at not only the introduction of differential HECS and the unfair bans that we see. We are looking at law studies being put in the highest bracket, for goodness sake!

PARA.BREAK: The whole rationale behind the minister's differential HECS—that is, projected income earnings along with course costs—has been defeated only in the last couple of days with the release of the latest report on graduate starting salaries. It is worth noting that gradu ate starting salaries in this country are at an all time low. So the very rationale for differential HECS has already been exposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The HECS increases are quite sinister as well. We will see an increase across the board for current and future students. That goes against one of the policies that the coalition certainly claim to have had prior to getting into government—that is, a concern about retrospectivity. Not only will the HECS bans hit those students who are involved in current courses but so will one of the most sinister changes being promoted by this government—that is, the decline in the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their debts. It is a massive reduction.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's appalling.

—Senator Woodley, you are right. It has gone from around average weekly earnings, or $28,000 per annum, down to around $20,000, or around 75 per cent of average weekly earnings. That is the threshold at which students and graduates will now be expected to repay their HECS debts.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the worst changes that has been proposed by the government in this budget is the proposal to introduce up-front and full cost undergraduate fees for Australian students. This essentially allows university administrations—that is, universities around the country—to charge up-front, full cost fees for all courses except medicine. We can only begin to speculate why medicine has been exempted from these proposed changes.

PARA.BREAK: But what we are essentially looking at here is the absolute entrenchment of user pays education in this country. I must add that, while I agree with many of the comments Senator Carr made earlier, in my dissenting report I have made very clear the fact that the Australian Democrats continue to support a publicly funded and accessible higher education system. That means no fees and charges and no barriers so that people in this country have unfettered access to higher education if they have merit. That means people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, women and other traditionally disadvantaged groups—people with disabilities, indigenous students and people from non-English speak ing backgrounds. The process that I hold partially responsible for the changes that we are seeing here today is the introduction of fees not by this government but by the former ALP government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They unlocked the door.

—They unlocked the door. They allowed not only the introduction of user pays but also the reintroduction of tertiary fees in the form of HECS and the higher education administration charge back in 1988 and 1989. I think that is an important point to make because they did open the doors. They also allowed the deregulation of the postgraduate fee paying sector and they allowed up-front and full cost fees to be charged for postgraduate courses. What we see today is a continuation of that process by the coalition government who, according to the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill, will allow the charging of those fees for undergraduate places.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, what we are saying is that we are going to lock out those disadvantaged groups from higher education in this country. We are not even going to give them appropriate student financial assistance so that they can try to get their foot through the door, because some of the sinister changes that have been made in the budget relate to Austudy as well.

There are a number of other aspects of this report to do with scholarships that are worth reading—the so-called scholarships that will help people who are disadvantaged gain access to university. Under these changes that will mean 4,000 over four years. Big deal! We are yet to ascertain how those scholarships will be determined.

There have also been overall cuts to the research quantum. The minister has claimed that we will protect undergraduate places. However, that is going to happen at the expense of postgraduates. So I do not know what we are doing to the future of research and teaching in this country.

The Australian Democrats make it very clear in not only our comments in the dissenting report with opposition senators but also our own dissenting report that we believe the changes we have seen are a continuation of a process that began in the late 1980s. Those of you who read the dissenting reports and the evidence provided by the expert witnesses will be very clear that the changes that are proposed by this government are regressive, prohibitively expensive and will lock out poor kids from higher education in this country. I thank the secretariat for their hard work at very late hours and also the witnesses who appeared before the committee hearings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Considering the statements that were made by the now government when in opposition in the previous term of the Labor government, the government should be ashamed of presenting this report. Where are Senator Hill and Senator Tierney now with the outrage they were expressing during the term of the previous government in relation to regressive steps, moving towards a greater level of user pays and changing thresholds in terms of accelerating debt repayments?

SPEECH.PARA: The ability of people to pay and to live after going through the stages of university has become more and more difficult. There is an assumption here that education is a cost when, in fact, quite clearly over time we know that education is a benefit. It is a benefit to the country and, obviously, it is going to be a benefit to the economy as well. Yet we are actually pulling it further and further away from people who are not rich in our country.

It is ironic that, just as quite a lot of work is being done to enable a greater participation rate from disadvantaged groups such as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the courses leading to such things as medicine will become more expensive. Here we are saying that people should be pulling themselves up by their bootstraps but, in fact, we are pulling away the ability for medical services to be offered to indigenous Australians for their own communities.

There are a lot of instances here where we are going to see that tertiary education institutions will be a place of privilege. We will have a small group of people who will be the scholarship earners, but it is not exactly a princely sum, and the numbers of people involved on merit will be a lot less than what was available before.

I think this is the wrong direction. Australia cannot afford to go in this direction. When you consider the billions of dollars that are given by taxpayers annually to prop up corporate Australia, what we see today, by way of this report, which says that it is a surprise that the committee recommends that the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 be passed without amendment, is a disgrace.

I agree with Senator Stott Despoja that the ALP cannot stand with hands on their hearts and say, `We have not been involved with the beginnings of this,' because they were. We had lively debates in this chamber with Senator Hill and Senator Tierney involved in that debate. Where are they now?

I think the community will be giving their opinion very clearly when it comes to dealing with this bill. I can say right now that the Greens (WA) will be fighting it on the grounds of justice and equity and common sense in relation to the equitable provision of higher education in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the sentiments of the preceding speakers, particularly Senator Margetts and Senator Stott Despoja. From the Australian Greens point of view, we should be moving to a free entry system to tertiary education for those people who have not been there before but who want to be equipped to take part in Australian society in the 21st century, when it is going to be even more important than it is now to have a tertiary qualification if you are going to be able to get a job and move into a workplace that is satisfying, productive and fulfilling.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of that the impediments are growing and, as this minority report points out, the government is actually cutting support to the tertiary sector and putting the onus on to citizens through monetary barriers which they have to jump to be able to undertake their tertiary education. It is totally wrong. It is the wrong way to go. As Senator Margetts said, at the same time the corporate sector is contributing less and less to the Treasury, so that governments at state and federal level are less and less able to fund the education that is necessary to ensure Australia is the clever country that we are touted to be in the last quarter of this century.

We ought to be moving towards free entry into tertiary education. It should be the same as primary and secondary education. It is an essential part of a citizen's rights in this day and age. To be making it an elitist option for those who have money in their pockets or whose parents have money in their pockets is the wrong way to go. No wonder the government has taken so little part in this debate because it would be trying to defend the indefensible. On behalf of the Australian Greens, I support the sentiments of this minority report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard budget which these appropriation bills implement reminds me of the total of the take advertising campaign which Coles ran in the 1960s. This was a campaign which was part of an intense competition between the retailers Coles and Woolworths. The campaign promoted the compelling message that customers when choosing between the two stores should keep their eye firmly on the total of the take, as opposed to perhaps one or two particular specials as were described as being offered by one of those department stores.

SPEECH.PARA: It is exactly in the same way that Australians should assess the merits of John Howard's budget. They should keep their eyes firmly on the bottom line. If they do that they will see that what John Howard is offering with one hand he is snatching back twice over with the other. Take the family tax initiative for example, which we dealt with yesterday. Of course John Howard has made much of this initiative. For a one income family with two children, one of whom is under the age of five, this will mean an extra $17 a week. For a dual income family earning up to $79,000 it will mean $3.85 a week for each dependent child. That is great. We welcome any help for families.

But John Howard's view of families is a very one dimensional view. He seems to think of them as some sort of a cardboard cut‐out and as being somehow all alone in the world. On this side of the chamber we certainly do understand that they are real. They come in all shapes and sizes and they are not alone. They actually sometimes do need help. They need services and they expect their governments to provide them.

Let me point out during this second reading debate what John Howard's budget has done to some of those services. Take health for example. Notwithstanding his promise not to cut funding for public hospitals, he has taken $800 million from them. This will dramatically increase hospital waiting lists for those who depend on public hospitals. John Howard has also imposed big increases in the cost of prescription drugs. Pensioners will have to pay an extra $100 million a year for drugs under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The cost of each script will be increased to $3.20 without any compensating increase in the pension. He has also completely abolished the Commonwealth dental health program to save $100 million a year. What about the Medicare offices where families get their Medicare and child‐care cash rebates over the counter? John Howard is closing down 84 of them.

All families want their kids educated and most rely on the public education system. This is a budget that cuts funding for public schools. Assistance for students with disabilities has stopped altogether. Vocational education has been cut and the Howard government has abandoned its agreement to fund growth in the TAFE system. If your kids are at university or hope to get there, you had better start saving, because gone now are the days when higher education was within the reach of all young Australians regardless of where they lived or regardless of their circumstances.

Higher education, you might remember, was part of the bad news that John Howard got out of the way before budget night so as not to take the gloss off the family tax initiative. But it does not alter the fact that operating grants for universities were cut by $624 million. Universities will charge more for degree courses and will be able to charge full fees for places above the target number of Commonwealth funded places, which Senator Vanstone has confirmed will be determined at the whim of the minister of the day.

If graduates are lucky enough to find a job when they finish, they will have to start their HECS repayments as soon as they earn $20,701, compared with the previous threshold of $28,495. John Howard has set us on a path which will lead back to the bad old days when if you were well off, your kids were okay and if you were not, they were not.

Those families who use child-care services will find that the $504 million budget cuts will mean higher out‐of‐pocket expenses for child care or lower quality child care or both. For those families with family members out of work, this budget will make it much more difficult for those family members to get back into the work force.

You could only describe the Howard budget in this area as a downright disgrace. John Howard is not game to commit himself to any jobs targets. He has put an end to the Commonwealth Employment Service, first started by Ben Chifley in 1946. He has abolished a huge range of employment programs.

So if you or your kids have ever benefited from any of these labour market programs, take note—they are either being slashed or completely abolished by these appropriation bills. Take note of them: jobskills, LEAP, new work opportunities, jobtrain, the special intervention program, accredited training for youth, skillshare, jobclubs, the mobility assistance scheme and the TAP program for Aboriginals.

What about the impact of John Howard's budget on older Australians? John Howard said that he had spread the pain equally, but he has spread it to the most vulnerable in our community—the sick, the jobless and the elderly. Elderly people in need of nursing home care will have to pay an up- front entry fee. There is no limit to what nursing homes will be able to charge. The average fee in hostels is around $26,000, but it can be as high as $88,000. On top of this, nursing home residents who are not full pensioners will be charged nursing home fees of up to $34 a day or $12,000 a year. This fee will be charged as soon as a person's income goes $1 above the pension‐free area. Inevitably, many of these costs will fall to families of nursing home residents who are unable to meet them themselves.

Maybe you have an elderly family member who is receiving care at home via the HACC program. They will be faced with much higher user fees for the first time as a result of this Howard budget. As I said before, the pensioner dental scheme has been axed. There are higher costs on access to hearing services and a total of three‐quarters of a billion dollars is being knocked off concessions for people on social security payments. This was sneakily done by the same John Howard who told us before the election that `the coalition will maintain all current Commonwealth concessions'.

So on the one hand, yes, families will be getting some extra dollars from an initiative such as the family tax initiative and the private health insurance rebate. But no Australian should be dazzled by those dollar signs. If your family depends on public health or public education services or if it is dependent on child care or if you have someone in TAFE or at university in your family or you have a family member in a nursing home or if you are trying to get back into the work force, you will not have those extra dollars long enough to even realise you had them, let alone enjoy them.

As I said as I commenced my contribution on this debate on the appropriation bills, you have to keep your eye on the total of the take. That is the trick from Mr Howard and his government. I am pleased to say that he is slowly but surely being exposed on this issue.

As an opposition we have made our position on the budget measures very clear. We are vigorously opposed to measures which betray election promises—as we have said many times in this chamber, there are very many of them in this budget of deceit—which infringe equity or detract from national savings.

We have identified a very significant range of measures which fall into one or more of those categories. These are set out in general terms in the second reading amendment which has been circulated in the chamber. I give notice that I will move it at the conclusion of my speech in the second reading debate.

The opposition will also be seeking to have Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) amended to reinstate vital programs which the government proposes to cut or to restore funding in other programs to the levels budgeted for by the former Labor government. These requests for amendments will be circulated shortly. Obviously, they will be moved at the committee stage of the debate on these bills. They will give this callous and vindictive government a last opportunity to reconsider the consequences of the impacts of some of these extraordinarily harsh budget measures.

BREAK.PARA: I hope that senators will take the opportunity that is offered by the second reading amendment that I will move on behalf of the opposition and by the requests to amendments that will be moved at a later stage to demonstrate the Senate's support—like the Labor Party's—for a fair go for all Australians. This particularly concerns the most disadvantaged in our community. I also hope the Senate will really take this opportunity to reject this government's unnecessary, savage and ideologically motivated cuts to programs and services that I believe any reasonable Australian would describe as essential. I move:
(1) At the end of the motion, add: "but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(a) the Budget betrays the Australian promise of working towards a more fair, just, inclusive and united society;
(b) the Budget is both mindless and heartless, and its prescriptions are not what the Australian economy needs at present;
(c) the Budget will have a savagely contractionary impact on economic growth and make impossible the job creation necessary to reduce Australia's still unacceptably high level of unemployment;
(d) with stronger economic growth the Budget could be restored to underlying balance over the life of this Parliament through a much more moderate program of fiscal consolidation;

(e) the spending cuts and tax increases contained in the Budget are, on the evidence of the Government's own Budget Papers, not necessary to reduce the Commonwealth Government's debt-to-GDP ratio and will not produce a significant improvement in the current account deficit;

(f) the Budget not only offers no hope to the unemployed but actively harms their prospects of finding a job by cutting labour market programs and privatising the previously publicly provided employment service function of the CES;
(g) the Budget will have unfair and unjust consequences for the struggling and disadvantaged in our midst-the poor, the old, the sick, indigenous Australians and newly-arrived migrants;

(h) the many spending cuts concerned with education and training, research and development, trade development (including breaches of promise with respect to EMDG, ITES and IAMP), production bounties, and other business support, will be counter-productive in their longer term consequences;

(i) there is deception involved in the family tax package contained in the Budget, whereby what the Prime Minister appears to be putting into one pocket is for most middle Australian families being taken right out of the other by the Treasurer in higher education fees, Austudy changes, higher nursing home charges, higher fees and charges;

(j) there are many breaches of Coalition election promises contained in this Budget, which amount to over $17 billion over four years, and which will cause hardship, insecurity and dismay for millions of Australians;

(k) the Budget involves a massive betrayal of regional Australia through the abolition of the $150 million regional development program, large cuts to road funding, the closure of regional Government offices such as Medicare and CES offices, and the cuts to the ABC and university funding;
(l) the mean-spirited decision to introduce large, up-front entry fees and massively increased daily fees for nursing homes, and increase user-charges will harm elderly Australians;
(m) the abolition of Childcare Operational Subsidies will impact heavily upon community based child care centres;

(n) the reduction of $800 million over four years in public hospital funding will cause longer waiting lists for the sick and reduce the quality of hospital and medical assistance for millions of people;
(o) the Budget involves a breaking of the Government's so called `core' commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety through cuts to rebates for numerous items under Medicare;
(p) the cruel decision to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Health Program will cause serious problems for the less well off;
(q) harsh and promise-breaking decisions will force Australian families to pay substantially more for the cost of their prescription medicines;
(r) the massive funding cuts to education, the increased HECS charges and AUSTUDY changes will penalise the less well-off;
(s) the Budget's comprehensive and ideological assault on the public sector will cost 10 500 jobs in 1996-97 alone;

(t) the Government has failed to honour its election commitment to maintain the environment budget and to provide an additional $84 million in the 1996-97 Budget, instead cutting by 13 per cent the environmental budget and forward estimates;

(u) the reckless decision to reduce funding for the National Highway by $622 million over four years, breaches a clear Coalition election commitment at the 1996 election, and with other decisions will reduce the level of public infrastructure investment, especially in regional Australia;
(v) the decision to impose a 500 per cent increase in the taxation arrangements for visits to the Great Barrier Reef will discourage tourism and cost jobs in Queensland;

(w) the Government has failed to honour its promise to not cut Australia's foreign aid beyond the election commitment to abolish the DIFF program, and in doing so will allow the estimated ODA/GDP ratio for Australia in 1996-97 to fall to 0.29 per cent;

(x) the Government has failed to honour its election promise that Defence expenditure would not be cut, whilst cutting $165 million from the 1995 Defence Budget estimates for 1996-97, and reducing Defence expenditure as a percentage of GDP to its lowest level since 1939;
(y) the mean-spirited and discriminatory approach to migrants and ethnic communities will harm outworkers, hurt newly-arrived migrants and refugees, cut humanitarian aid and penalise asylum seekers;
(z) the substantial cuts to ATSIC and to indigenous-related Commonwealth programs represent a massive setback to the process of reconciliation in Australia;
(aa) the savage cuts to the ABC, of $209 million over four years, are in complete breach of the Coalition's solemn election promise to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC;
(ab) the Budget has failed to honour the promise to maintain levels of arts funding and spend an additional $60 million over three years; and

(ac) the Government's plan to substantially increase Commonwealth court and tribunal fees, coupled with deep cuts to legal aid, will result in a severe curtailment of access to justice by many Australians."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills we are debating are special ones. Unlike other ones, they have a particular place in the constitutional structure of our nation through their intrinsic link to the concept of supply. We all well remember 1975 and the forcing of the constitutional crisis by the Liberal and National parties. I will not forget it. I do not want it to happen again. It is very destructive and should not be recreated. This why Democrat senators have pledged not to bring down a government in this way despite some of the disgusting things this government does in the name of policy.

SPEECH.PARA: We make no apologies for our ongoing commitment to stability of government. Our pledge not to block supply does not stop us though from requesting amendments to the appropriation bills, as I made very clear in my budget address‐in‐reply on 22 August when I said:

This is a tactic we intend to use with the clear and specific aim of putting pressure on Government backbenchers in marginal seats to stand up and be counted on the most damaging aspects of the budget.

That is what we are doing today and I hope that we receive the support of the majority of senators. We would all be aware that coalition backbenchers—particularly new members of parliament—would not have had input into the structure of the budget. In many respects, they would not even have known the fine detail of the budget any earlier than the rest of us. I hope they would have been horrified, as most of us were, with what we have called `the death of a thousand cuts' contained in the budget. So by initiating requests today, the Democrats and the Labor Party have shown that they are doing that.

The Democrats will be giving these backbenchers—as I say, many are in marginal seats and are new members—an opportunity to reflect on the structure and impact of this budget, and to take personal responsibility for either imposing or lifting these cuts on some of the most vulnerable members of our community, normal human beings who live in their electorates. Let these backbenchers answer to their electors for their personal responsibility, not in regard to the architecture of the budget but in the voting for the implementation of these measures.

The Democrats have identified a representative basket of issues within our requests. It covers Aboriginal Australians, the poor, regional development, the environment, the unemployed and public broadcasting. Specifically, through our requests we will be seeking to restore ATSIC funding, maintain ABC funding in real terms, restore funding to the Commonwealth dental scheme, restore the NEIS program, restore previous commitments to the development of the emerging ethanol industry and restore funding to the Daintree rescue package.

In addition, we will be supporting some of the other requests which have been foreshadowed by the Labor Party. A number of my colleagues will be speaking briefly in the committee stage of this debate to highlight some of the unnecessarily harsh measures. Senator Bourne will speak on the ABC, Senator Allison on the dental health scheme and Senator Woodley on ethanol.

To keep my comments brief, I am just going to comment on the NEIS program, on cuts to the environment programs and on cuts to ATSIC. We hear a lot about the predicament of the unemployed. I said on budget night that this budget was built on the backs of the unemployed. I genuinely believe that to be the case. I think the government acknowledges this; that is why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has set up his special subcommittee to coordinate across‐department policies to deal with unemployment. We hope it works but the point is that it comes after the architecture of a budget which specifically chose to put the burdens of the future on the unemployed.

This government has said that most labour market programs are being cashed in because the percentage of positive outcomes from these programs is far too low. The government has said that funding for many labour market programs is being slashed because the programs have failed to deliver `real jobs'—that is, the government's view of `real jobs'—for the unemployed.

This government is also slashing funding for one labour market program which we think was highly successful—the new enterprise initiative scheme. It is a program which has created some 20,000 new businesses over the past 10 years and has consistently achieved positive outcomes—close to 84 per cent. But in this scorched earth, ideological, 20 per cent on everything approach to this budget, this government chooses to single out something which has a success rate of 84 per cent to slash funding to. We do not believe that the decision to do this—it amounts to a 17 per cent cut—makes any sense at all. There is not any justification for slashing funding for such a highly successful employment program when 8.7 per cent of Australians cannot find a job.

The NEIS scheme was an example that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) pointed to in his speech last Friday. When he talked about employment opportunities for indigenous Australians, he pointed to the NEIS scheme. I wondered at the time whether the minister for Aboriginal affairs actually knew the government had said, `Well, we are going to slash funding to this scheme by 17 per cent.' It is a successful scheme. Obviously cross‐department integration is not working yet, because one minister is saying, `Here is a good example of how we can promote Aboriginal employment,' but the Treasurer (Mr Costello) is saying, `Yes, but we're going to cut funds to this program.'

On environmental matters, there have been several important buyback and protection schemes which have been reduced from existing levels under the budget this year, and I am requesting the government to top them up to their former levels of funding. Specifically, the government has decided to drop the amounts for the Daintree rescue scheme and the Sugar Coast rescue package, which was put in place to save the mahogany glider and other creatures in danger of extinction as a result of the expansion of the sugar industry. When we asked the government about this, it said that the promised amounts of money would eventually be met—however, it would take a longer period of time.

It is very difficult to predict when blocks of land will go on the market and for how much. The blocks of land have been mostly identified and, if there are major blocks to come on the market for the joint Commonwealth-Queensland buyback schemes, it is very hard to say to a vendor, `Hang on. Wait until the budget in 1997 or 1998, when we have the next little bit of money to devote to this rescue package.' It does not work like that. So saying, `Oh, we're going to do it eventually,' is an absolute cop‐out.

In terms of the wet tropics, funding for the world heritage management is $9.8 million. Yet in this overall pot, when divided up amongst Australia's areas, funding for the wet tropics has declined from $4 million to $2.8 million.
