We would just like to bring this back to the $4 million mark from the last budget.

The Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, pointed out in the Senate on Tuesday that the wet tropics management plan is near finalisation. He said that the authority desperately needs money for management and for threat abatement work. What are they doing? They are cutting their budget by 40 per cent. Aren't we supposed to make these policy interconnections? Aren't we supposed to say, `Yes, good on you for giving priority to the Wet Tropics Management Authority. PS—Hang on, we won't take any notice of how you are reducing their capacity to implement this policy by cutting their funding by 40 per cent.' We believe the size of this cut to the budget—the 40 per cent cut to the budget—will make their work almost impossible.

In summary, our three requests in the environment area constitute an upkeep of protection and purchase for important places in North Queensland—places which are extremely important for endangered species.

On the restoration of ATSIC funding, I think particularly relevant is the context of the recent and ongoing race debate in this country. Yes, we have focused on the need to address disadvantage, only I think we differ on how mainstream the addressing of that disadvantage has to be. As a result of the cuts to ATSIC, we saw health, employment programs and native title quarantined to some extent. We saw ATSIC's decision as a result of being told, `You'll have to cut your budget by this amount.' We saw the cuts that were made to youth programs, heritage and environment programs, women's programs, legal services—and that is particularly worrying—art, culture and language programs.

I do not see the delivery of services in indigenous areas as simply being about citizenship rights, and that is why I have always thought it necessary to address the wider issue of disadvantage in the broader ways. The contribution of women's programs and legal services to Senator Herron's concepts of self-empowerment cannot be underestimated. The publicity that surrounded the cuts to legal services in indigenous areas has highlighted the fact that indigenous views may not be represented or may be insufficiently represented. That is not acceptable. ATSIC needs every dollar that it had relied on in the past year to do its work properly.

I do not walk away from comments on the need for auditing; I do not walk away from communities being identified as having to review some of their processes, but the bottom line of all of this is about addressing disadvantage and working towards reconciliation. I think a $474 million cut to ATSIC's budget makes a huge dent in achieving those two worthy aims.

I imagine you will hear the Treasurer carrying on about what the Senate is seeking to do. I imagine we will be told, `This is irresponsible; you are breaking the budget. You can't do this to my deficit reduction strategy. It is sacrosanct.' Let me get in ahead of him. The requests being sought by the Democrats total $171 million for this year. This will not break the budget. It is one-eighth of one per cent of the total $136 billion in our budget. It will not do anything to interest rates, either. It will not affect our credit rating, either.

Also, it is well within the usual estimation forecast error parameters—the ones we have seen in the past, $1 billion here and there. A one per cent error on prices inflation, for example, would increase or reduce outlays by $400 million. I am talking about $171 million that I want this government to review and restore. There would be a fall in unemployment recipients. Say labour market programs did work, say NEIS was allowed to keep operating the way it used to; a fall in unemployment of just 40,000—five per cent—would change the budget by $300 million. But more importantly, if this government were willing to review its decision and to reverse some of the meanest and most unfair of these cuts in the name of the fiscal responsibility that they are saying they are taking for Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's important.

—Yes, it is important, Senator Kemp, but it is how you achieve it that is important and the pace at which you achieve it that is important. If the government were to reverse these cuts, the harm done to sectors of the Australian community—to indigenous Australians, to rural Australia, to the unemployed, to the sick, to the environment—could be avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Noel Pearson talking about indigenous affairs on radio this morning. He was talking about guilt. He said that it is not about guilt, it is about having a bit of a heart. That is what has got to happen in this budget. We have got to stop thinking about these numbers on paper, and think about the people that are affected by these cuts. The government tells us we can rely on families benefiting from interest rate cuts, but what benefit is an interest rate cut to a family who cannot afford to buy its own house? What benefit is there for indigenous families, the chronically sick or the unemployed? They fit into this category.

The 1996 budget was not a fair or balanced budget. It pursued obsessive contractionary policy. Its pain was targeted too heavily at those who could not afford to pay. I do not care whether the headlines the next day said, `This is a good budget.' It might be if you are comfortable. But as this budget unravels we will see where the pain falls. If the government is concerned about maintaining this excessive level of fiscal tightening, then it has the other option of alternative revenue raising proposals.

Take Premier Jeff Kennett's advice. Let us start talking about tax reform which includes alternative revenue raising proposals. We suggested tighter targeting of the family tax rebate using the same means test used for family payments, to deny the payment to high income families. That would have saved $100 million just yesterday when we were debating that bill. A 20 per cent cut in the totally unjustified diesel fuel rebate would, for example, completely pay for all the requests we are making. It was appalling, in the budget context, that the preservation of this subsidy to some of Australia's richest companies, this $800 million handout, was announced on the same day as massive cuts to ATSIC—cuts felt by some of our poorest and most disadvantaged families.

It is those kinds of decisions which reflect the priorities of this government—maintain the diesel fuel subsidy in full; do not think about phasing it out a little bit, do not ask about its inefficiencies, which have been highlighted in auditor's reports. No, the priorities of this government are the excessive devotion to fiscal tightening and the pursuit of the dollar, well ahead of the needs of many vulnerable Australian families—maybe some of the battlers that the government thinks it has won over. But it will not keep them if we are successful in highlighting the decisions and the priorities that have been made by this government with respect to the budget.
I want to finish by quoting from parts of a letter by Robert Fitzgerald, the president of ACOSS. Again, it anticipates some of the responses that the Treasurer is likely to make. He says:
. . . these few positive features—
in the budget—

are massively outweighed by the negative. We share the Democrats' criticism of the unnecessarily rapid deficit elimination strategy chosen by the government, especially as it relies so overwhelmingly on the expenditure side of the equation to reach its target. Expenditure cuts contribute approximately three‐quarters to the task, while revenue raising measures contribute only one‐quarter . . .
That is why we say this budget is unbalanced—three‐quarters of cuts and one‐quarter for addressing ways to raise revenue. He goes on to say:
The pace and method of deficit reduction adopted by the government in this Budget will cause severe social hardship and is very likely to be counter‐productive in economic terms.
ACOSS calculates that at least 30 per cent of the expenditure savings over the next two years will affect mainly low income people. Further:

Many of these people are single and . . . will receive no relief from the family tax initiative . . . most low income families will not be fully compensated for the effect of these expenditure cuts and service reductions on their disposable incomes.
We share your view that this is not a fair Budget.
. . . we urge you . . . to prevent their already difficult situation from deteriorating further.
That is what we are doing by way of these requests today. I believe in a year's time when we make the assessment we will be seen to be doing the right thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is certainly not a fair budget. In fact, in my opinion, it is a great deal worse than the 1993 budget. It is unfair, and its cuts are certainly targeted to those people who have the least ability to fight back. They are the people who already have the least power in our society and to whom, over time, as a caring community, there has been assistance given in various ways. There has been not just assistance but commonsense programs to provide the means by which our community can do what communities are supposed to do; that is, build on the strengths within the community. Often, those strengths are community self-help, the ability to survive and live in the future and the ability to provide those things that are basic to human existence. It seems that basic decency has been left out of these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give one example. In education, something like $65 million has been taken out of government schools and given to non-government schools. We are taking money from the public sector and giving it to the private sector. You could call it the reverse Robin Hood syndrome. The Greens (WA) are very concerned; we have been right from the beginning of this budget. In March, we talked about the concern regarding the continued focus on one side of the balance sheet. What we are seeing is not good economic management. We are seeing an ideological push for minimalist government. This is a philosophical underpinning to the government's response to the deficit problem.

It is really quite interesting that there are a couple of deficits. There is the balance of payments deficit and the budget deficit. Many commentators say that what will have more effect on the economy is the balance of payments or trade deficit. But we are not admitting that we have industry and trade policies that are not even seriously looking at that issue. The only thing the government is doing is cutting government spending. It is also cutting taxes, where possible. It is keeping taxes down and trying to compete internationally to see who can have the lowest taxes within the region to attract investment. It is cutting environmental standards.

As we have seen in the last couple of days, the government has been trying to put downward pressure on wages and conditions. In the words of the government via the principal object of their industrial relations bill—I will not call it a workplace reform bill; reform means a change for the better, and that bill is not—it is for international competitiveness and flexibility. Read that as the pushing down of wages and conditions so that we can attract investment. This government has added to what was done in the last government by destroying much of the ability of large parts of Australian industry to meet basic needs in Australia, such as food, clothing and shelter. It does not take people in their stores much to see what the structural changes are. They have been made worse by poor or negative government policy that does not recognise that the push for, and blind faith in, internationalism and the international free market are not getting us where anybody thought they wanted to go, at least not where I thought the major members of the community thought they wanted to go.

In April this year, we talked about the government's push to pursue big budget cuts in a lot of areas to do with social justice while leaving defence spending untouched. It highlighted the ideologically driven approach. Yet EPAC surveys indicate that taxpayers are willing to pay more taxes to get the services they want. They do not want more user pays services. They believe that their taxes should be spent on such things as the environment and on social services such as health and education. If they thought there was any area that we could spend less on, it was defence. That is why we will be endeavouring to make requests in this bill in relation to major areas, such as education, health and social security, and other areas, such as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

It is extremely important that people see what this budget really is. It is not good financial management. It is very narrow management. It is a blinkered approach to what is important. What this government is saying is important is an ideological and, in my view, irrational view about the international free market, although ironically within the coalition we sometimes have more doubters than we have seen from previous ministers in some of the Labor government portfolios. It is a blinkered approach not only to the benefits of the international free market but also to what is happening in Australia.

Much of what is passed in this budget for budget austerity measures is actually a very thinly disguised excuse for rapid privatisation and a rapid reduction in the provision of social services. In that sense, there is a rapid reduction in accountability and buck passing. Along with that comes a rapid increase in potential conflicts of interest, such as when we have commercial operations involved with the traditional role of government.

We are at a very serious time in our history. This budget will unravel as we deal with each of the measures. The reason for that is that those groups and people who will be most targeted will not even see the impacts until they are very clearly in front of them. We will be seeing a great deal of community hurt. Unfortunately, very little real information has been given to people about the likely impacts on them. I know for sure that we will be seeing enclaves of disadvantage getting worse. I can tell you for sure that we will have debates in relation to law and order in the states and in this parliament when we begin to see the social disruption between the haves and have nots that deliberate policies of differentiation will create in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: We give billions of dollars annually to corporations. Absentee corporate heavies get billions of dollars worth of taxpayers' welfare every year in Australia. Yet we cut from the most vulnerable; we cut from the bottom. I am very sad to see that, because of the government's program mismanagement, they thought it was more necessary to do some nah nah nahs on industrial relations this week rather than give us a proper chance to debate the most important issues in relation to this budget and these appropriations. I do not think that is appropriate and I do not think it is the way to be handling the program. I do not think that making political points is more important than the real impacts of Australia's budget.

I obviously believe that debate on industrial relations was very important, but the government are now saying that we have to contract this debate and the proper consideration of the appropriations debate because the House of Representatives is not here next week and it forgot that we needed to have it by the end of November. First of all, we need to ask which departments are likely to run out of money. We need to find out why it was not considered important enough for us to rearrange the program so that we could deal with appropriations on Monday or Tuesday. The world was not going to end if, by Tuesday, the industrial relations bill was still on the program. However, that was not the decision that was made. That speaks volumes for the political strategies of this government and it speaks volumes for their priorities.

There are issues that are important in the Australian economy, and those issues in my opinion are how you meet the needs of people in our society; how you create economies, especially in regional areas, which are truly sustainable; and how you look at appropriate economies which look at the real issues in our society like resources, energy, greenhouse production and the basic human social needs of the people in our society.

PARA.BREAK: I have not seen any recognition at all that these issues are important to this government. I have not seen any recognition at all of the fact that they need to find out what a reasonable government—a responsible govern ment—needs to raise in terms of revenue. What they have done is decide to cut and slash as much as possible at the same time as trying to pull down taxes. I do not believe that is responsible, and I do not believe that that is what the average taxpayer wants.

BREAK.PARA: The average taxpayer wants a fair go. They do not want to see measures which make the rich richer and the poor poorer. They do not want to see measures which basically deny human dignity in our society in 1996. As time goes on, the backlash will be substantial and, in the end, all of those people who are affected, even if they are not able to currently effectively lobby, will understand just how unfair the 1996 budget was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not expect Senator Margetts to finish as quickly as she did.
—Don't worry, it won't affect you.
—No, it will not affect me. I wonder if I can get what is left over from her speech added to mine so that I can fully explain how evil this budget is for the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak on the appropriation bill and to support fully the remarks of my colleague Senator Faulkner, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and in support of the second reading amendment to the appropriation bill that has now been tabled and circulated. It is a very detailed amendment to the appropriation bill, pointing out the wide nature of these cuts which will take effect against the Australian people. They are cuts that are ideologically driven in many cases, and in particular I want to refer to the cuts as they affect the ABC.

The government has justified every one of its cuts on the basis that it has a substantial deficit which has to be reduced. Yet, when you look at the issue of the ABC and the cuts to the ABC and the way they were gone about, these cuts are not done on the basis of reducing the deficit. That is a side issue for this government. These cuts are there for a political purpose—to destroy the effectiveness of the ABC as a major broadcaster and telecaster in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The cuts are absolutely savage. That was the word used by Mr Johns, the chief executive of the ABC, when they were announced. In this year's budget, the cuts are $11 million, which is basically the so-called 2½ per cent efficiency dividend applied to all agencies. That is just on $11 million out of the 1996-97 budget. The next cuts—the real cuts; the ones that really will go about destroying the ABC as we know it—which will occur in the following three years, are $55 million a year out of the ABC's budget. That is the most savage cut to the ABC in its history.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $209 million all‐up, I suppose.
—As Senator Carr quite rightly points out, that is a $209 million cut to the ABC over the next four years. It is unprecedented in the history of the ABC that such cuts are being applied.

BREAK.PARA: All governments from time to time have asked the ABC to make efficiencies and said that the ABC's wish list for an increase in its budget may not be able to be met. At times, various governments have frozen increases. But no government, as far as I am aware—not even when the famous Sir Henry Bland was appointed by Mr Fraser, then Prime Minister, in the mid-1970s—has tried to do over the ABC, so to speak. Even at that stage I do not believe the funding went down. There may have been a freezing of the level of funding but there was no actual reduction. Not even Malcolm Fraser got into the actual reduction of the money for the ABC, even though he put Sir Henry Bland there as chairman to try to fix up the ABC to be more ideologically sympathetic, I suppose, to Mr Fraser's viewpoint.

But this new government has gone a step further. It is reducing the amount of money. The government is not just freezing it—not just getting rid of the price deflator, allowing for an increase even under inflation, freezing it at that level—the government is reducing it in real terms by $209 million.

This is a complete contradiction to the promises made by this government in January and February of this year during the election campaign. I know Senator Alston gets sick and tired of having this quoted at him, but it ought to be quoted at him every day while he remains minister. In his better communications policy statement of 18 January, he said, `The coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC.' Further, in that same document, he said, `The coalition will maintain the current prohibition on advertising and sponsorship on ABC television and radio.'

Senator Alston was one of the commentators on election night. After it was clear that the coalition had won the election and Senator Alston would be the new communications minister, he was asked on ABC television by Jim Middleton about ABC funding. Senator Alston said that funding would be maintained absolutely. Jim Middleton asked, `Even if you find the deficit is bigger than you expected, will the funding be maintained?' Senator Alston said, `Absolutely. John Howard has made it clear that we will meet all our promises, and the ABC is part of that promise.'

Subsequently, when the ABC was before us in the estimates hearing in the latter part of this year, I asked Senator Alston about these promises and about his remarks on election night. He passed this off by saying that his remarks should be excused because the euphoria of the occasion meant that they should not be taken quite as he had said them.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said it was a novel question.

—That is right, Senator Carr. He said, `euphoria'. I asked, `Is this a new generic term for being drunk or drinking too much champagne?' Even if he had been celebrating too much, one would have thought that he would have had the wit to qualify that question that was put to him in black and white terms by Jim Middleton on two occasions. He did not. He said, `The euphoria of the occasion may have led some remarks being generously given.'

BREAK.PARA: The point is that he is on the record. He and the government have now broken that promise completely. It is one of the more outrageous breaches of promise that Senator Alston and the government have made. One should remember that last year Senator Alston chaired a Senate committee that looked at the ABC and found that the ABC was well managed and doing a very good job. There was nothing in that report by the committee, chaired by Senator Alston, that would lead anyone to say that Senator Alston, as minister, would cut $209 million out of the budget of the ABC over the next four years.

It is quite clear from the evidence now on the record that Mr Howard, since becoming Prime Minister, has criticised the ABC as being too politically correct and has said that we hear too much about Aboriginal affairs issues and other minority views on the ABC. That is John Howard's comment. Mr Costello made similar remarks when he released the audit report earlier this year. So we have on the public record Mr Howard and Mr Costello, the two most significant figures in this government, directly attacking the ABC. They have made these cuts for a political outcome: to reduce the effectiveness of the ABC to be a broad based comprehensive broadcaster in Australia.

The irony is that, if you look at any of the surveys over the years, you will find that overwhelmingly in many areas the people who listen to the ABC are coalition supporters. In rural Australia the regional ABC network is overwhelmingly listened to by people who overwhelmingly vote for the coalition. Even in relation to the major metropolitan ABC radio stations—5AN in my state, 3LO in Melbourne, 2BL in Sydney, et cetera—the demographics of the listeners of those stations are that they are overwhelmingly Liberal voters. So any charge of the ABC being biased is extraordinary when consistently it is Liberal voters who are listening to the ABC. The majority of the audience are Liberal voters, so this charge of bias in the ABC is extraordinary.

We just have to accept that this is a political act. It is not a financial matter. It is just an excuse to achieve a political end. In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1), we will be moving a request to the House of Representatives to restore the $11 million to the ABC funding this year. I cannot move the same amendment to restore the $55 million because that relates to next year's budget. Unless this government sees some commonsense about the ABC—and let us hope that the government can learn from its mistake and restore the funding to the ABC in next year's budget—it is going to be condemned as destroying one of the great national broadcasters in the world.

What I find extraordinary is that Senator Alston has admitted he has received 17,000 letters, or thereabouts, of protest about cuts to the ABC. In the estimates hearing, he said that several thousand of those were pro‐forma letters. But the majority were letters people had actually taken the trouble to write themselves to express their view. During my time in this parliament I do not think a minister has received so many genuine letters of concern from the Australian public on any issue—17,000 letters, of which a majority are not pro‐forma but genuinely written by people expressing their own view.

At the same time as Senator Alston received 17,000 letters, he received 60 letters complaining about the ABC's coverage of the gay mardi gras in Sydney. He wrote an extraordinary letter to the ABC demanding that they reconsider the coverage or delay the telecast et cetera because 60 people had written to him. He actually used that as an excuse to write to the management of the ABC. He gets 17,000 letters and does nothing. Sixty versus 17,000—it really does show the imbalance in this minister's attitude towards what he thinks is public opinion.

I think, in the end, this new government will face the music over what they are doing to the ABC because it is overwhelmingly ABC supporters in rural and regional Australia who are upset. The issue about regional Australia—and I come from a small state—is really important. There is no doubt that the $11 million cuts being imposed—not the $55 million; that's next year's business—have already reduced the operation of metropolitan ABC radio. In each state some of the best and well‐known radio announcers have been sacked or forced off air as programs are being merged to make savings—this is from $11 million. What is going to happen to the ABC next year when they have to take $55 million out? We know what will happen. Some radio networks will be closed down completely. Regional Australia will be networked out of Sydney and Melbourne. It will be impossible for the regional network to survive when you take $55 million out of budget over the subsequent three years.

This government have been utterly duplicitous in what they have done to the ABC. What they promised in the election was utterly different from what they are carrying out in their political witch‐hunt and ideological drive, as they see the unpleasantness of some issue which they do not like being broadcast on the ABC.

The Labor Party is committed to support the ABC with its comprehensive charter as a broad based, national broadcaster providing services to all Australians, whether it be Triple J for the young people of Australia, whether it is the Country Hour for farmers to get information about farming issues, whether it is regional Australia to get local community news, whether it is the ABC FM fine music station, whether it is the national second network, whether it is the ABC metropolitan stations or whether it is ABC television, the drama production, which is about $50 million a year. These cuts are more than the total money spent by the ABC in one year on television drama, on Australian content. That could all go in one hit by trying to meet these savings.

As I said, this government are being utterly duplicitous in what they are trying to do to the ABC. In the end, I do not think they will succeed because the reaction on this issue from ordinary Australians of all political persuasions has been ferocious. Seventeen thousand letters to a minister on any issue is unparalleled in my time in this parliament. I encourage the Australian citizenry to be as strong as ever in demanding of their Liberal and National Party members of parliament the preservation of the ABC as a comprehensive, broad based, national broadcaster.

I want to conclude on the other area of my portfolio responsibility, the issue of Telstra. At some time in the next couple of weeks I presume the government will finally bring back on the list the debate about the privatisation of Telstra. Over the last couple of weeks the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in particular, has said the Senate has been holding up the government's legislative program, including the Telstra privatisation debate. Yet it is the government in this place that will not put it on the list to be debated. It is not on the red sheet for today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We want the appropriations.

—You could have had the debate two weeks ago. The debate on the second reading could have been completed and a vote taken on the privatisation of Telstra. The reason the government keep putting this off is that they are not certain of the outcome of the vote in the Senate and they still want to try to convince some senators to vote for their proposition. They have certainly not replied to Senator Harradine's proposal about a preferential share issue to raise the $8 billion dollars. Who knows when they will reply to that? Let us put it at rest. The opposition are not delaying the debate about the privatisation of Telstra; the government are delaying the debate because they are still trying to work out a way to convince the majority of the Senate to vote for it.

BREAK.PARA: In the year just gone, Telstra paid a dividend, after tax, to the federal government of $1,368 million, after they withheld some profit for reinvestment in capital works, et cetera. I want to point out to the Senate that this is not an insignificant sum in the revenue of Australia. When you look at the revenue raised through taxation, you find that the dividend from Telstra alone is greater than the money the Australian government received from the withholding tax which was $1.349 billion. It was greater than the petroleum resource rental tax which was $791 million. It was greater than the capital gains tax which, for the previous year—only preliminary figures are available for 1994‐95—was $965 million. So the dividend which Telstra pays to the federal government is greater than the withholding tax, it is greater than the petroleum resource rental tax, and it is greater than the capital gains tax.

If, as the minister says is inevitable, the whole of Telstra will be privatised, the question I put to the government is: where are you going to make up the $1.3 billion of revenue that is now being paid as dividend to the government and which is more than three other taxes which we collect individually? It is a significant amount of revenue. Ordinary Australians would say, `Perhaps you might privatise something that is losing money and costing us money to keep going, but why would you sell a business that is paying more revenue than three other taxes on the revenue base of Australia?' That is a question which the government ought to answer in this debate on the appropriation bills.

I look forward to the minister, Senator Alston, making a comment about that, or even Senator Kemp, who represents the Treasurer in this chamber. How will the minister make up the revenue loss of $1.3 billion a year when he fully privatises Telstra? Where is he going to make it up? Which taxes is he going to put up to make up $1.3 billion? What further cuts will he make to government expenditure and programs to make up $1.3 billion?

TALK.START.PARA: —They're just going to sack Telecom staff.

—As Senator Conroy points out, only recently Telstra announced that they are going to stack 22,000 staff. During estimates they said that would improve the profit of Telstra by $600 million a year. That could increase the dividend to $2 billion a year. It is bad enough that jobs will be lost, but at least Telstra should be kept in public ownership so that the extra profit stays in the public revenue and can be used to the benefit of all Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the sentiments that Senator Schacht has just expressed. At the outset, I want to talk about the doctrinaire philosophy and the economic fundamentalism which underride this budget. It is the wrong way for this country to be going. It is going to lead to an increasing divide between the haves and the have nots in a country which has prided itself on its egalitarianism, on its ethic of a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about nation splitting. It is going to lead us in the American direction, where the gap between the haves and the have nots is writ large for anybody who wants to walk the streets of any of the major cities to see people who are panhandling and begging. There are 35 million people living below the poverty line, while there is one per cent of people living in extreme and obscene wealth.

If we are going to have a bonded society in the future, we have to lay down the prescription for that now. Instead of laying down that prescription for a fairer, more equal society, where everybody has an opportunity for personal fulfilment, it has to be done now with future generations in mind. You cannot have this doctrinaire economic fundamentalism which says, `Leave society to the law of the jungle, divest parliament of powers and translate them across to the stock exchange,' and at the same time have a fair go.
After the federal budget, 114 of Australia's economists made a statement about the government's economic policy. The statement reads:

The federal government's commitment to reduce expenditure by $8 billion is economically irresponsible. Expenditure cuts of that magnitude will inevitably cause job losses—directly in the public sector and indirectly in the private sector as a result of the downward multiplier effects. There is a strong possibility of precipitating a substantial economic recession.

The goal of a balanced budget indicates pre-Keynesian economic thinking. It ignores the creative role which fiscal policy can play in economic management, especially in tackling unemployment. Moreover, the expenditure cuts would likely fail to produce a balanced budget anyway, because the consequence reduction in jobs and incomes would result in lower tax revenues being generated in the next fiscal year.

More attention needs to be given to the role of government expenditure on repairing the nation's run‐down infrastructure, creating jobs and fostering industry and regional development. If necessary, increased taxation and other revenue options should be under consideration. Savage expenditure cuts are economically irresponsible and socially damaging.

This statement was sponsored by Associate Professor Frank Stilwell from the Department of Economics at the University of Sydney, by Emeritus Professor John Neville from the Department of Economics at the University of New South Wales, by Professor John Quiggin from the Department of Economics at the James Cook University and by Dr Phil O'Hara from the Department of Economics at Curtin University, and was supported by 110 other economists around the nation.

So the feeling that the government is going in the wrong direction is not just a political expression. It is not just a feeling of disappointment by those who want to see more money going in their direction in Australian society. It is a very strongly felt academic and analytic viewpoint from people who do not hold the government's doctrinaire economic fundamentalist viewpoint.

Having said that, I want to point to some of the specific implications of this budget, which we are debating here today under the government's suddenly found panic button, which says that if we do not get it through today we will run out of money because the House of Representatives is not sitting next week as the Prime Minister is away. Whatever the case, the government has just spent a huge amount of Senate time pushing through its industrial relations legislation. That bill had priority over the budget as far as this government was concerned.

One cannot help thinking that this panic button approach to discussing the budget is simply a way of truncating and stifling that debate. The government has been able to stifle the full debate on the budget in the public arena. It has successfully got away with that, and it is getting away with it today because of the truncation of this debate. It should have been a matter being debated before the industrial relations legislation, which quite clearly does not have the relevant urgency that this legislation has for the whole nation.

I turn back to some specifics. I am going to apply some of these to Tasmania and to challenge the Tasmanian government senators opposite to get up and defend the impact that the budgetary measures they are shoving through here today—their cutting and slashing left, right and centre—will have on Tasmania, the island state.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Calvert sits over there waggling his finger as he cuts millions out of the Tasmanian budgetary allocation, as he cuts into the welfare of every Tasmanian by aiding and supporting the government on these matters. Let me put some of those to Senator Calvert, who is the only other Tasmanian senator in the Senate at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, we have the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program. There is a national cut of $56 million in the next fiscal year. The estimate for Tasmania is that $1.6 million will be slashed out of that program. That is going to hit 15,000 Tasmanians, including elderly Tasmanians, each year from now on.

Let Senator Calvert explain to those 15,000 Tasmanians why he supports the government's cut to this very successful dental health program, which they have access to. The cuts he is voting for will, of course, result in increased waiting lists and fewer people being able to have access to dental health.

The homeless kids Austudy incidentals allowance is being abolished. This is a pathetic measure by this government. The national cut will be $3 million in the next year. The estimated cut for Tasmania is $54,300. People might say that that is not much when we are looking at a budget of more than $100 billion, but let us look at the individuals who are affected in the state which has got the highest unemployment rate in the country—an unemployment rate which is going to be substantially increased by the measures which the Tasmanian Liberal senators are voting for in this budget.

About 180 homeless youth in Tasmania receive Austudy. The allowance involved here was a one-off payment of $300 at the beginning of the year for expenses such as books, equipment and course costs for kids who do not have family backup, who might otherwise be on the streets and who want to get a secondary education so they can go on to tertiary education.

This allowance was to help them get books, rulers and equipment so they can go to school the same as other kids who have got the backing that they do not have. It is aimed at allowing them to have an education so they will get a job further down the line and will not be on the scrap heap.

BREAK.PARA: What are the Tasmanian Liberal senators voting for? They are voting to take from those kids that measly $300. That is going to lead to some of those kids failing. That will be the difference between whether they succeed—whether they make the grade against all the odds—or whether they fail. Quite clearly, those Liberal senators opposite do not care. I do not think they understand the situation that those kids are in with all its complexity, all its hardships and everything that is against them.

But here is a measly $300 specifically allocated to get them a start up again in education and to help them make that positive decision, and these Liberal senators are voting to cut it out. That says a lot for their concern for the have-nots in our society. That says a lot for their concern for the unemployed. That says a lot for the heartlessness of this budget, which is going to pull the rug from under kids like that.

Another measure in this budget is a $30 million cut to the job program in Tasmania. The national cut is over half a billion dollars. There will be cuts to the LEAP, the jobskills and the new work opportunities programs, and they will lead to a loss of 3,623 placements in Tasmania. The government says, of course, `We are moving towards a private enterprise situation. We will put it to the employers themselves and we will divest government of the responsibility for helping people get a start up. We will cut the previous, successful Labor programs to ribbons and, in doing so, we will cut nearly 4,000 jobs.'

But what has the government got? It has a special employer support program, which will create some 800 jobs in the green corps—great name. It may attract some good, positive publicity to paper over what it is doing. It is the green wash brush out again. While the opportunity to get back into the workplace through reskilling will be taken from 3,623 people, including long‐term unemployed, this green corps proposal out of the government's public relations machine is going to create seven to 10 job placements in Tasmania. So they are slashing 3,623 jobs and putting seven jobs back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get the seven from?
—You can give me different figures, if you have them, Senator Calvert.
—They wouldn't be as shonky as yours.
—Order! Senator Brown, do not respond to interjections. I ask senators not to interject.

—I will be waiting to hear Senator Calvert get up and give, firstly, the specific figures for Tasmania on the job losses from the government's slashing of these job creation programs and, secondly, the figures for jobs to be created under their so‐called green corps program. Let us have the figures from Senator Calvert when he gets up and makes his contribution.

BREAK.PARA: Then we get to the cuts to the ABC—$209 million over the next four years. Pro rata that is a $7 million cut out of Tasmania where the ABC's listening audience is greater than anywhere else in the country. The ABC rates high because it gives current affairs coverage second to none. It rates high because it gives talkback, not available elsewhere on commercial radio. It rates high because Tasmania is a regional community without the metropolitan weighting that you have in the mainland states, and it covers the interests of regional and rural communities in a way that commercial radio simply does not and will not.

Yet the ABC is having its budget massively slashed because the government does not control the editorial content of the ABC—nor does anybody else. It is that very independence that a Liberal government should be standing up for that is being punished by these budget cuts, which are going to quite unduly and unfairly affect Tasmania.

A range of amendments have been flagged here today from the Labor Party, the Democrats and in particular the Western Australian Greens Senator Dee Margetts. I will be supporting those that move to redress the impact of this savage budget on Australians, particularly those who are vulnerable, those whom the Prime Minister said he was going to protect and those who are going to be extraordinarily disadvantaged by the cuts.

I might say that it is not just the cuts that are worrying. It is also the pouring of advantage across to the silvertails, to the Stock Exchange-led component of Australian life. Let us look at the diesel fuel rebate and support that being kept for the farmers and hospitals and so on. But how can you endorse the government handover in one year alone of $800 million to the big mining corporations, a return of their properly paid tax on fuel usage, with these savage cuts? How can that be justified except as a gift to the already wealthy, to the haves, to the people who are able to wield power on weak-kneed politicians and get their pockets lined at the expense of poorer people in our society? This year, the government is handing BHP, the big Australian, a cheque for $80 million on a silver platter at a time when it cannot find the money to give $300 to kids who simply want to buy books and go back to high school. That is the heartlessness of this budget.

After that, we look at the government's much touted effort to catch tax avoiders. Each year, $800 million is forgone there. They say they have a program in place to catch up $100 million of that this year. There is another $700 million—wrongly, I submit—going to tax avoiders at the big end of town at a time when this government cannot find $300 to give to kids who want to get back into school.

It is no wonder there are only two government members opposite to defend the situation that this budget will put Australians into. It is no wonder there is so little support in this place for this bill that the government is wanting to rush through the Senate today on the pretext that it is too late to have a bigger debate, that it is too late to allow a more wide-ranging debate because the House of Representatives will not be sitting next week.

As Senator Schacht said, $1.3 billion is to be forgone if only the government can get through its legislation to flog off Telstra. That is $1.3 billion in perpetuity. That is $1.3 billion that is going to have to be found through future tax increases or, more likely with this government's split and divide attitude to the community, through further cuts to education, health, community services and employment schemes.

There is only one word to describe this budget—heartless. There is only one phrase that really covers it well—divide. The whole ethos of this budget is to take more power from this place to work for the common good of the Australian people, and hand it across to the Stock Exchange so that the haves can continue to accrue, in their interest, the benefits of an economic direction which is economic fundamentalism, away from the egalitarian viewpoint that has been so much espoused as the Australian ethos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to close the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) which are before the chamber. This budget has been widely welcomed in the public arena and seen to be a fair budget. It has been extensively debated; probably more debated in the estimates committee procedure than any other budget that has come before this parliament. The opportunity for debate on this budget has been huge, Senator Brown. If you were not there to make your views known, I am sorry about that. Let me say to you that very many senators took the opportunity to take part in those estimates hearings, which, I think I am right in saying, were the longest in memory.

SPEECH.PARA: This budget has been very extensively canvassed. It has been welcomed by the public. It is a dilemma for opposition senators and other non-government senators and Independents that this budget has been very widely welcomed by the public. We can recall that on the day after the budget a headline read `A fair go'. That summed up the way this budget was received in the public arena.

The unreality of what we are hearing in this debate is quite extraordinary. We have had the Lindsay by-election, we have had the estimates arrangements and we have had the very satisfactory consequence already flowing through from a responsible budget of pressure being taken off interest rates, which have come down substantially since the March election.

I repeat: we will not be supporting the various requests which the opposition, the Democrats and, I think, the Greens will be proposing, although we have not seen amendments from the Greens. As far as I am aware, I think Senator Brown mentioned there are some amendments that the Greens are circulating, but we have not seen them. I checked just prior to standing and I notice that you refer to them in your remarks, but they have not been seen.

The requests by the Labor Party would cut budget savings by, wait for it, $1 billion in 1996‐97. One is reminded of the famous old quote of the Bourbons which seems to relate also to the Labor Party—they have forgotten nothing and they have learnt nothing. They have not forgotten how to spend money and they have not learnt that it is important to be responsible and fiscally responsible. This $1 billion is before we learn what they wish to do in detail on the taxation front. This is just for starters, Senator Faulkner.

There were a number of issues raised, all of which have been very extensively canvassed over a long period of time and during the estimates process. I wish to make a few brief remarks on the importance of the budget and the appropriation bills in particular which should be passed in full.

The budget is a key element of putting Australia on a better path. We recognise that we had to make some tough decisions in this budget, but failing to act now would only make the decisions even tougher and more painful down the track. The facts are very stark. In the past five years the Commonwealth under the Labor Party amassed some $70 billion in deficits. In other words, they spent $70 billion more than they were prepared to raise. Commonwealth debt now stands at $100 billion. Our public interest bill is over $9 billion a year and is almost as much as the Commonwealth spends on defence and education. That, Senator Brown, is one of the consequences of overspending, which the previous government did with a vengeance.

BREAK.PARA: This debt and interest burden is placed on all Australians and must ultimately be repaid by all Australians, including future generations. Passing this budget offers the Australian people a better way. It offers them less debt. It offers them lower interest rates. It offers them more jobs and better living standards over the medium term.

Most importantly, this budget is consistent with the promises we made to the Australian people when they elected us to office on 2 March. The budget makes good our promises on helping families, through the family tax initiative, providing incentives for private health insurance, helping small business by reducing the provisional tax uplift factor, providing the CGT rollover relief, and implementing the modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship scheme.

The budget has been endorsed by the people. It is one of the most popular budgets which has been brought down. As I said, that shows the unreality of so many of the comments which have been made in this debate so far. It is clear that the budget has been widely accepted by the Australian people. It is a fair‐go budget. The people want this government to be given a fair go. It is a budget which deserves the full support of the Senate. I commend the appropriation bills to the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Faulkner's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1996-97
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996-97. Requests for amendments have been submitted by the Australian Democrats and by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to advise the committee that as of last night there were 15 or 16 speakers listed to speak on the appropriation bill and as of this morning there were about six or seven. Of course, I had worked my program around that particular fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I did have a look at the second reading amendment without reflecting on it. I am not sure that I would have voted for it because it was a Gareth special which mixed all sorts of things in. There are things that I liked and things that I did not like to be quite frank, but it would not have made any difference one way or the other. I have before me now the specific amendments that the opposition is proposing. I thank the opposition and the Democrats for sending that to me last night. I have done the best I can and it may well be that on one or two of them I will ask that the Senate be divided. I will listen to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for those comments. I formally move the request standing in my name on behalf of the opposition to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996‐97:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the bill by increasing the votes for departments in accordance with the following schedule:

ROW.ENTRY: 4.01—Payments to the Australian Film Finance Corporation Limited
‐For expenditure under the Australian Film Commission Act 1975
Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
1—Expenditure under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975
9—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Services

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of this particular request have been circulated in the chamber. I say at the outset that I will not take up much of the committee's time on this request. From the opposition's perspective it is important that we honour the spirit of the changes that we introduced in government—and which in fact I introduced in my previous incarnation as Manager of Government Business—to the way that the appropriation bills are handled.

I appreciate that it has become unusual since the adoption of these procedures for the bills to be debated in committee, but we are dealing here with an extraordinary situation. We have a budget which flouts the government's election commitments in so many areas and spreads the burden of the government's fiscal consolidation strategy to those who can least afford to bear it. It is those same disadvantaged members of the community whom this government gave an ironclad commitment—an ironclad promise—to protect.

I want to put on the record the Labor Party's protest about the way in which the government has handled these bills. I want to draw on the comments which Senator Harradine has just made to the chamber. We are all aware that they have been on the Notice Paper for weeks, in fact since 11 October. It was only last night that I received frantic information that the government had discovered that these bills had to be passed at all costs today. That might go part of the way to explaining why a number of opposition speakers who had intended to make a contribution to the second reading debate on these appropriation bills did not exercise their right to make that contribution.

It was literally last night when we had fevered advice from the government that it was now or never in terms of today for the appropriation bills. I might say that this advice came at a time when there had been many opportunities which the government could have exercised to interrupt the debate on the workplace relations bill at any stage to deal with the appropriation bills. I am sure that most of the senators sitting in the chamber at the moment who made contributions on the family tax issue yesterday would have been willing to make them at a later stage and give more time to dealing with the appropriation bills.

I do think that the government has had ample opportunity to better order or re‐order its business in such a way as to allow these particular bills to be passed in good time. I do not believe that any senator in this chamber would have had any difficulty with such a proposal if it had come forward from the government. It did not come forward from the government at any stage. As I indicated, it was only last night that I received a telephonic communication that the bills had to be passed today. I can only come to one of two conclusions as a result of this situation: that is, that we face yet another example of serious mismanagement of the Senate program on the part of the government, or the other conclusion that this is simply some sort of a ruse to force these particular bills through the Senate.

Let me make absolutely clear that from the opposition's perspective, given the changes to the way the committee stages of the appropriation bills will be dealt with, as I have indicated we will honour the letter and the spirit of those changes which were introduced by the previous Labor government. I will quickly move to speak in support of the request that stands in my name before the chamber. I might say that the remarks I make now can also be held to apply to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) when the committee moves to deal with that bill.

The request for amendments to these two principal appropriation bills before the Senate does provide the Howard government with one last opportunity to reconsider the budgetary folly that it embarked upon. In making this request, the opposition is calling upon the government to right some of the most serious and some of the most grave injustices that are contained in the budget, particularly in relation to cutting funds for labour market programs, for child-care assistance and for nursing homes. Also, there is the termination of the Commonwealth dental health program, which is perhaps the unkindest of all.

The opposition considers that the funding increases contained in this request are not economically irresponsible, as was suggested by the minister in his response to the second reading debate. We consider that any attempt by the government to whip up some sort of air of fiscal crisis to justify the budget cuts, which this request seeks to change, really is nothing more than a very transparent, very self-serving ploy on the part of the government.

The truth of the matter is that, on all the available international comparisons, the Commonwealth's finances are in sound shape. That is the truth of the matter. Even before this budget, we had the third lowest level of public expenditure in the OECD, the fourth lowest level of public debt and the third lowest deficit. The argument of the opposition is that a more moderate form of fiscal consolidation was required from this budget. What was not required was the hairy chested, ideologically driven rush to fill the phantom black hole—the black hole that we hear very little about any more from the government.

On this view, the reinstatement of the funding nominated in this request would be consistent with public finances, and is consistent with sound public finances, and the opposition does commend them to the Senate. This is a way of forcing this government to reconsider some of their most short-sighted and most heartless and most vindictive budget cuts. I commend the request to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Democrats, I say that we also believe there are items in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2)—but we are dealing with bill No. 1 at the moment—that really are quite untenable. We believe the House of Representatives should be given another chance to have another look at it and to have another think about whether it is appropriate that this parliament should slash and burn some schemes and cut funding in the way it has been cut for several areas. We believe those areas are essential and must be returned.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Labor Party's request goes, I would ask the Labor Party, if they would not mind, to please move their request in two parts. So, if it is appropriate for them, could they move the amendment to division 220, which is on employment, education, training and youth affairs, and the amendment to division 340, which is on health and family services, in one block and all the rest in another block?

TALK.START.PARA: —As chairman, I could divide the question, if it is satisfactory to the Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I indicate, Mr Chairman, that, if you intend to utilise your discretion under standing order 84(3) to divide this complex request in the same spirit that Senator Bourne proposes, it would be a sensible thing to do. I think the opposition appreciates that that might aid the committee to ensure this debate moves as quickly as possible. So I indicate to the committee that I would be comfortable with such a division on your part, Mr Chairman. It may be that Senator Harradine, given the nature of the comments he made, might also propose that the request be divided.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition will be pressing all elements of the request but is happy to assist the committee by accepting the complexity of the request, and it might be appropriate to divide it in the way that Senator Bourne suggests. We will be at this stage seriously proposing that all parts of our request be tested by the committee at the conclusion of the debate, but we accept that the request be divided in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bourne, because there are other speakers, as chair, I will make a decision just prior to the vote about how the division will occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats's requests basically come in four parts for Appropriation Bill (No. 1). The first one is an increase to ABC funding, which would return the so-called efficiency dividend—really an inefficiency dividend—for this year. As we know, the most severe cuts start next year. We also know that the ABC is now preparing for those severe cuts. Because they believe that they will happen and that they do have to prepare for them, many programs are being cut and many staff are being made redundant. So we believe that it is essential to move those requests at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The second lot relate to the new enterprise incentives scheme. The Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot), in her speech in the second reading debate, gave reasons for why we are moving those amendments, so I will not be talking to those. The third relate to the ethanol bounty. Senator Woodley will be speaking for a very short while on that. The fourth group of amendments relate to ATSIC funding. That has been covered also by Senator Kernot in her speech. Senator Kernot also mentioned where the money would come from if all of these amendments were passed. It is not impossible to find the money; it is quite possible to find it. We believe that they are essential.

I will speak for a couple of minutes to the increase in ABC funding. Basically, the reason why we believe that the efficiency dividend should not apply to the ABC is the same reason that it has not applied to the ABC for several years now—the ABC is a different organisation from most organisations to which the efficiency dividend is applied. That is because most of their money goes on programming, and most of their money goes on money to pay staff to do that programming.

They have lost a lot of money in the past that other organisations have not lost. It is ridiculous to say that they are not efficient. They are efficient. It is a very efficient organisation. Very many studies in the past have shown that they are efficient. In fact, in the March 1995 report of the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations—chaired by the now Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston); I was the deputy chair—we found that the ABC should not be subject to the efficiency dividend.

I still agree with the recommendations of this report. I believe it is important that we give the ABC the indication that we do believe that their funding should not be slashed—of course, they are about to be. Even this first $11 million is a very difficult amount of money for them to find. I believe that we should stand by our report and our recommendations in the report of last year. Because the ABC is so important—we need to send this message to them—and because they are a different organisation from those to which the efficiency dividend applies, or would apply differently: those are the reasons why we should be passing our requests to the House of Representatives to look at increases in ABC funding for this budget. Senator Woodley is going to speak for a few minutes on why we should be looking at the ethanol bounty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the way this debate came on, there have been discussions between offices about requests and so on. As we speak, requests have been readied relating to the Greens (WA) amendments to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). It is my understanding that they do not intrude on any of the other amendments either by the opposition or by the Australian Democrats. When they arrive, I will be able to speak to those.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak to the issue of affordability. I point out the fact that tax bills will be coming up in the next couple of weeks. I flag that we will offer revenue options for the government, like a 20 per cent minimum corporate tax, which should be able to raise the government about $1 billion. We will offer revenue raising measures of 50 per cent dividend imputation, which could raise the government around $700 million. We will offer the elimination over three years of the diesel fuel rebate for mining, which should raise the government about $1 billion. So there is no problem, in my understanding, of funding—even for the maintenance of the reasonable funding that is here.

It is not as if the departments are overly resourced. A lot of the time it is people who have been cut. If you are providing services and you cut people, it is not efficient at all; it is inefficient. My definition of efficiency is being able to provide a service better. If you have more people waiting, fewer people able to access the services and fewer regional branches and so on, that is not efficiency at all. It is only a limited version of productivity a la the government's industrial relations ideology that if you have more jobs and more throughput, throughput equals productivity. It is not outcomes. It is not real efficiency. In my belief, it actually generally leads to greater inefficiencies because, if services which were provided are not able to be provided, it shifts the onus on to other, sometimes emergency, services. If the ability for people to deal with their own problems is reduced, then you end up with greater problems. For instance, if you cut from the environment programs—very modest environment programs, I must say; I do not think we have ever put enough resources into looking after or repairing the environment and looking to our future environmental expenditure—you do not save money. All you do is transfer the debt from now to the future. The debt, certainly on such things as environmental programs, means that you pay a lot more in the future rather than a smaller amount now.

I know some people put no value on future debt, no value on what the generations are going to have to pay in the future—whether or not it be a poor quality education system, a decreasing level of health equity, a change which limits the ability of people to access quality public education at public primary and secondary schools. That debt goes on to the community. We are not saving money. We are actually creating a debt for the future.

The Greens (WA) support the amendments put by Senator Faulkner from the opposition in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1996. We certainly will be wishing to add to that discussion once our amendments are circulated. It is very important to remind ourselves that the amounts, such as the $578 million in labour market and training assistance programs, that have been mentioned are essential. We cannot pull out systems that are working and assume that somehow or other those people will just go away. They will not just go away. They are hundreds of thousands of real people. We worked out that something like 120,000 got missed off the list in relation to different categories of people. There will be more added to the list when service providers to the community are cut out.

Decreasing wages and conditions in the community leads to more unemployment. It affects our ability to pay for basic goods and services, such as small businesses that operate in an area to provide lawn‐mowing, hairdressing, window cleaning, carpentry or car repair work. The ability to purchase goods and services operated by the community changes. In terms of wages and conditions, the average worker on a federal award has known what the future holds. The ability to purchase goods and services from the local community and small business becomes a great deal weaker once you decrease wages and conditions simply for the ideological purpose of trying to be internationally competitive, even though a great number of people in Australia are producing goods and services to be used in Australia. It is very short-sighted.

These cuts in labour market and training assistance will haunt the current government. You cannot pull out assistance like that and not expect that the large group of people who will be currently disenfranchised from the system will not turn up in some other area as a large and growing socially disenfranchised group of people. Be it on the head of the government if they continue to think that is possible and that they can get away with that kind of thoughtless, single-minded and short-sighted approach. I will be supporting the opposition's amendments in relation to maintaining—I do not think there are any outlandish increases—decent levels of funding for basic programs and providing basic government services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are moving to reinstate $12 million for the ethanol fuel bounty scheme. As a matter of fact, it is quite clear as I talk to government backbenchers that they are also in favour of restoring this scheme. That includes quite a number of them, who I certainly will not name. They are hoping that the Senate carries this to strengthen their hand in talks with the government.
—Not this one.
—It might not include Senator Panizza, but it certainly includes other people.

PARA.BREAK: I know, however, that the official view of the government is that they are not in favour of this measure which the Democrats are pushing. They have set their mind against it—or should I say very directly that the minister has. This is very clearly an action by a minister who has no concern for any alterna tive to the fossil fuel industry because of his own involvement in it. That is all he can see.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister is a great supporter of the coal industry, as we know. I believe that the petroleum industry has also got to him. Because of that, the abolition of the ethanol fuel bounty is really an ideological position that he has adopted. He wants nothing to do with an industry that is on the verge of having a significant future in this country. It is an industry that would contribute significantly to the environmental obligations that we have in this country. It contributes significantly to rural jobs, rural industry and regional development. It contributes significantly to value adding for primary industry. Despite all those advantages, this minister says, `No, thank you. I want to support my friends in the fossil fuel industry, so I am going to get rid of a competitor', which is exactly what ethanol is.

It is about time that government members opened their minds on this one, even if they have to offend their minister. The rest of the government ought to pull him into line. This country pays something like—this is a minimum figure—$5 to $8 billion in direct subsidies to fossil fuel using and producing industries that damage the environment. They also contribute to global warming with their encouragement of fossil fuel use. The fossil fuel industries are very much against the development of the ethanol industry in Australia and have apparently put pressure on the government to drop the scheme. It is a bad decision by the government for many reasons.

I am conscious of the pressure of time. I would like to spend a lot of time speaking on this, but I will not. I am prepared to try to fit in with the government's program. Because they have stuffed it up completely, they now have to put this kind of pressure on the Senate. They really do not deserve cooperation. However, let me say again that this bounty will help greenhouse gas emissions significantly. It is promoting regional industry and jobs. It is value adding to primary industry. This government wants to send it down the tube. It is a crazy proposition, and I hope that the Senate supports the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Woodley for his comments to the committee. I fully support the proposition that we should make a request in respect of that matter. What I would like to see this committee do, and the Senate do, is adopt certain requests which we have some confidence that a substantial number of government backbenchers, if not the government, would support.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a whole range of requests here that have been provided to us by the opposition and by the Australian Democrats. As I indicated, there has not been a great deal of time to give detailed consideration to all of them. Indeed, I received the draft late last night after knock-off time—what is knock‐off time around here anyhow? I noted that the date on which the amendments were circulated was today's date at, I think, 10.03 a.m.

So there has not been a great deal of time to give full consideration to them—on the basis that we need to, apparently, get the appropriations through for them to be sent to the House of Representatives. I understand if we do not do that today then there will be a cost of $300,000 to bring the House of Representatives back for them to do it in time for the fiscal purposes of the government.

What I would like to see happen is the isolation of a couple of requests which do in fact have the support of a number of government members. If we pass this this afternoon with, say, a raft of amendments which go, really, to the heart of the budget, the House of Representatives will be waiting to deal with it. If the House of Representatives is told, `Yes, there are requests that have come from the Senate,' I would suggest that those requests would get short shrift. But if we isolated two areas where we know that there have been substantial concerns by members of the government and those areas are not going to the heart of the government savings program, then that is what I suggest we might do. That might be more useful than carrying a whole raft of requests to the budget, though I agree with many of them.

BREAK.PARA: Under those circumstances, I certainly would like to agree with Senator Woodley. When the time comes, I would ask you, Mr Chairman, to divide the amendments such that we can vote on that one separately. Similarly, when it comes to appropriation bill No. 2, with the dental health scheme, I would certainly like to see that divided and voted upon separately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is before the chamber a raft of amendments and requests to the appropriation bill. In my second reading remarks I have covered the government's objections to these requests. We will be holding to that position. We believe the bill should be now passed without requests.

—The question is that the requests be agreed to. Senator Harradine, I did not get the chance to check with you. Is it the request of Senator Faulkner's relating to primary industries and energy, division 490, that you would like separated?

—Can I take a point of order to assist the committee. As I understand it, Senator Harradine, you have requested this of the chair: that division 490—primary industries and energy; effectively the ethanol bounty scheme—be put to the committee separately.
—That is correct.
—On appropriations No. 1. You have asked for a matter to be dealt with separately in relation to dental health in appropriations No. 2.
—Yes. I thank the Leader of the Opposition. If that is convenient all round, I would ask for that.
—Could I ask whether the original request—that employment, education, training and youth affairs and health and family services be put separately—still holds?
—Yes, Mr Chairman. As I indicated, if it will assist the committee, I think that is a sensible approach.

—What I will therefore do is take the request of Senator Faulkner to excise employment, education, training and youth affairs, health and family services, and primary industries and energy. After having done that, we will put employment, education, training and youth affairs and health and family services together and then we will put primary industries and energy separately. Is that satisfactory to the committee? It is so ordered. The question before the chair therefore is that the request of Senator Faulkner's—less employment, education, training and youth affairs, health and family services, and primary industries and energy—be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the request (by Senator Faulkner ) be agreed to except in relation to divisions 220, 340 and 490.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, we need to make sure that we are all clear where we move from here. The preference of the government is to continue with the appropriation bills which are before the chamber. We made good progress this morning and we would like to continue. We recognise we want to have agreement from the Senate on that matter. My understanding is that we have general agreement that we proceed with the appropriation bills, but we need to have that confirmed by the Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Madam Acting Deputy President, I did not get advice last night that this was likely to happen. Today we thought that, amongst all the other work that we do, we would have a chance to circulate our own amendments to this very important appropriation bill. I also did not get the impression this morning that we would not have access to debating time this afternoon.
