The reason that was given as to why we had to do it today was that the House of Representatives is not sitting next week and, therefore, it would cost hundreds of thousands of dollars to bring members back. We listened to that, and many people are trying to cooperate here in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Now we find out that, not only is it too inconvenient and expensive—which we understand—to get the House of Representatives back to deal with an issue which should have been managed early this week by rearranging the program, but we are told that the House of Representatives is sitting until only 5.30 p.m., that members want to get away early on their flights and, therefore, we cannot use debating time this afternoon to finish this off.

I am trying to be as cooperative as I am able in the circumstances but, as I say, I did not hear about this last night. I was not aware of this until just the last couple of minutes. We understood that, no matter what time was available this afternoon, there would still be government documents. I did not have any idea this morning, when this shemozzle was mentioned, that this meant there would be no debating time to finish off the appropriations bills this afternoon.

Given that it is still Thursday, not Friday afternoon and not Christmas Eve, if it is important to save the $300,000—and I agree that is reasonable—I suggest it might not be unreasonable for the adjournment of the House of Representatives to be fitted in so that the reasonable effort that is being made by the Senate to properly deal with this bill is taken into consideration.

From the point of view of the staff, and certainly from the point of view of my staff, it is not fair to suggest a sudden change in the program when we are not given the lunchtime to get things in order and deal with this bill properly. I do not think it is reasonable. I can see that if we go to a vote the numbers might well go against me. I do not think this is good practice. If the government in the House of Representatives is asking for it, it should do its part also. If it is an important bill to the government, it should do its part along with the Senate to try to get this bill dealt with properly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I think some of the points that Senator Margetts has made have some substance in terms of the shemozzle the government is responsible for this morning. However, having been informed that there is a genuine urgency about the appropriation bills, I did indicate in my contribution during the committee stage debate that the opposition would do all that it could to facilitate the passage of the appropriation bills. I am not going to resile from the commitment that I made.

BREAK.PARA: It seems at this stage that the best and most sensible approach for us to take is to delay general business this afternoon after the taking note of questions. I would suggest a period of dedicated government business time for anything up to two hours after the taking note of questions after question time this afternoon. So that would commence at approximately 3.30 p.m. That would give ample opportunity for the Senate to finalise its approach. Obviously, any requests that are passed have to go to the House of Representatives.

The Senate sits next week, and it is the timetable of the House of Representatives that is of concern to the government. I think we need to acknowledge that. The House of Representatives is not sitting next week, otherwise we would not be having this debate at all. I suggest that, if we have that two-hour period, all amendments can be dealt with in a reasonable time frame. It will certainly give the House of Representatives an opportunity to consider the requests of the Senate if any are carried to appropriation bills Nos 1 and 2.

I ask whether, in the same spirit of cooperation that has been clearly evidenced by the approach of the opposition, the government would consider that a sensible way of dealing with the impasse that we now find ourselves in, given that as it is almost 1 o'clock we normally deal with non-controversial business. If other business were not to be conducted, it would have been possible to have series of one-minute divisions perhaps going through to 1.45.

But the points that Senator Margetts makes about the circulation of her amendments and the like are not without some substance. So, in the spirit of genuinely trying to address this matter, I ask the Leader of the Government whether the approach I have indicated would be acceptable to the government. That would mean that we would move to non-controversial business. I believe there is one bill listed for debate at lunchtime today. So I ask the government for a response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We appreciate the spirit of compromise, and we are prepared to agree to Senator Faulk ner's suggestion. Our preference would have been to continue debating the appropriation bills now, but we understand that for this chamber to work it requires all parties and independents to be in accord with the processes to be adopted. As a result of the discussions that have taken place, there is obviously considerable discomfort with that proposal on the part of some in this place. Therefore, I think the alternative that has been put by Senator Faulkner is reasonable in all the circumstances. Senator Campbell has a motion that will express that in the terms that the Senate requires. I thank Senator Faulkner and others who have indicated that they would cooperate in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Campbell)—by leave—agreed to:
That the order of consideration of business, after the conclusion motions to take note of answers to questions, for the remainder of today, be as follows:
(a) Government Business order of the day No. 1 Appropriations (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1996‐97 and to related bills) till not later than 5.30 p.m.
(b) Tabling of documents.
(c) Consideration of government documents, under standing order 61; and
(d) Consideration of committee reports and government responses, under standing order 62.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Wool International Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President—
—Are you talking on wool?

—Absolutely. I grew up on a farm, unlike most honourable senators opposite. It was a dairy farm, I must admit. I always used to envy wool growers, because they did not have to get up early and milk cows twice a day. They seemed to me to have a much more luxurious life by not having to milk cows twice a day—which was an inflexible work arrangement for 365 days of the year. I remember going off to play football and having to come home after the match to milk cows. The sheep farmers, beef farmers and wheat farmers could stay around and have a drink at the footy club afterwards, when we dairy farmers had to go home and milk the cows.
—That was a long time ago.

—I have to agree, Senator McKiernan; that is a long time ago. But I still have more than a passing interest in rural matters and, on behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we will not be opposing the Wool International Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear that the arrangements for dealing with the wool stockpile were introduced by the former government in 1994. We acknowledge that the then opposition, now the government, basically supported those arrangements. The issue that we are dealing with now with the wool stockpile and its hopeful disappearance by the year 2000 is that, since 1994, the program has worked very well to reduce the stockpile and its influence on market prices. I think that the real issue for the wool industry is how we got into that situation in the first place with the wool stockpile.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about John Kerin?

—I am glad you interjected, Senator McGauran. I remember John Kerin, as primary industries minister, coming to the Labor Party caucus to seek approval for the guaranteed floor price scheme. The wool industry, dominated by wool growers, was recommending that the floor price, the average price, the guaranteed price, consistently go up and up. When the market started to get a bit shaky, his recommendation, on behalf of the wool industry itself, to the federal parliamentary Labor Party and to the government was that we should guarantee the price. This is what the wool growers wanted.

BREAK.PARA: So what happened? Over a period of a year or so, when prices were collapsing in the marketplace, the Australian government picked up the guarantee, which, I think, within 18 months, reached nearly $4 billion. What had happened? In the late 1980s and early 1990s, but particularly in the late 1980s, the industry, in my view, got greedy and tried to use the price mechanism to overcharge the world market for wool.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spot on!

—Spot on! The industry got it absolutely wrong. In the end, it was left with the unreality that people in the world market were being asked to pay 800c or 900c per kilogram for wool when the marketplace was not willing to bid. So, when the wool was on the market floor, the government had to pick up the guarantee and purchase it because it was not reaching the reserve price.

BREAK.PARA: When the reserve price was first introduced by the Whitlam government in 1974—

TALK.START.PARA: —Doug Anthony.

—No, you have got your history wrong, Senator McGauran. The first reserve price scheme for wool was introduced by the Whitlam government in 1974. It was a floor price scheme. It was floor priced so that there was a bottom through which it should not fall. What happened in the late 1980s was that the wool industry, to be blunt about it, got a bit greedy. It tried to shift the floor price up to become a ceiling price which, in the attic, we could not fall through. So instead of being a floor price to guarantee minimum income for wool growers, we tried to fix the market level at a price for wool which, in the end, the world market was not willing to pay. Then we said to the Australian taxpayers, `We want you to guarantee this price so that we can try to beat the world wool market in forcing them to pay this higher price.' In the end it all came tumbling down.

BREAK.PARA: I remember at the time someone pointing out that New Zealanders and Argentineans were getting a real benefit from our reserve price for wool. Why? Because when we were setting it at 800c a kilogram, they were selling just underneath, at 750c, disposing of their wool because their price was a bit cheaper than our reserve price. Our reserve price scheme was the best thing New Zealanders and Argentineans—two of the world's major producers of wool on the export market—ever had working for them. Our taxpayers made the Argentinean and New Zealand wool industries very profitable. What a mug bunch we were!

I have to say I cannot prove this outside of the caucus room but, Senator McGauran, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I was one of the first members of the federal parliamentary Labor Party to question John Kerin. I asked: how long are we going to go on providing a reserve price, a guarantee, for the stockpile, because in the end the country cannot afford a $3½ or $4 billion guarantee?

TALK.START.PARA: —For a dairy cockie, you're not bad.

—These are simple economics, Senator Panizza. You have had some experience in the wool industry. The real issue with the reserve price scheme when it became a floor price rather than what we tried to turn it into—a ceiling price through which we could not fall—was that we tried to play around with the international market because we were the major growers in the world, the major producers. We all but destroyed the wool industry as a result.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say that, back in 1974 when the Whitlam government introduced the first scheme, I was an enthusiastic Labor Party supporter of it—with some rural background—as everybody was. But what we actually did to the wool industry was to say to the wool producers, `Produce whatever wool you like, whatever amount you like, in whatever quality you like, and someone else will have the responsibility of marketing it.' We removed from the wool growers any incentive for them to think about the quality of their wool and about the marketing of it.

The comparison we could make is with the cotton industry, where there was never a reserve price scheme operating in Australia. It was a totally free market where the cotton producers looked at selling on the futures market, getting forward contracts and so on. This was all, of course, strongly opposed by a lot in the wool industry who wanted a guaranteed price. The cotton industry very rapidly grew in this country to become one of our major export earners, with no reserve price scheme operating, no guarantee operating, with the cotton producers themselves taking the responsibility of working out what was the best price. That is an example. Unfortunately, the wool industry has had to learn the hard way and, I have to say, the Australian taxpayer has had to learn the hard way, over the last half decade.

I believe that the bill before us today gives greater flexibility in the way in which the remaining part of the stockpile will be disposed of by the year 2000. I am told in the bill, which we support, that 31 December 1998 has been set for the final repayment of the debt and that the last bale of wool goes out of the stockpile no later than 31 December 2000.

The history of Australian agriculture, with the events relating to the stockpile, and the collapse of the wool market and the wool industry in the late 1980s to early 1990s, is one that this parliament should never forget. It should never be removed from our institutional memory that trying to play around and rig a market, because we are the major producers, and to do it at the taxpayer's expense and as a taxpayer guarantee, is not a responsible way to go. It has done the wool industry enormous damage.

We should obviously dominate the wool industry, not only in production but also in processing. If we had spent a small proportion of the money that we had guaranteed to wool production on marketing and processing in Australia, instead of exporting hundreds of thousands of bales of wool full of dirt and grease and so on every year, we would be exporting finished cloth. There would have been value added to the process, creating a lot more jobs. It is very good to see, in so many cases now around Australia, individual wool growers taking the responsibility of producing wool for a particular part of the market, following it through with their own processing, with direct contracts, and producing finished, high quality woollen garments and exporting them.

In Ballarat 18 months ago a wool producer bought his own equipment and was scouring, spinning and weaving the wool and producing high quality, individually designed patterns. He employed several scores of hand‐knitters around Australia who took his high quality yarn and knitted it into individually designed jumpers. Those jumpers were put into special packs and exported to the American market and were selling for $200 or $300 each. That is an example to us all of classic, perfect value adding. That was a wool producer taking—from one end to the other—total control of his own economic destiny. We should encourage many more of our wool producers to do the same, either individually or collectively, through cooperative arrangements with each other. They are then taking control of their own future by being involved in working out contract arrangements to sell their wool, and working out what is the best quality of wool that the market wants at the moment.

No longer can any agricultural industry, let alone the wool industry, argue that to produce it is the only issue. That is the easy thing for Australian agriculture. You have got to get the production, the marketing and the value added processing right. The whole debacle—that is the only thing it can be called—related to an industry trying to fix the market, not at its own expense but at the expense of the Australian taxpayers. Ultimately, many farmers did suffer horrendous losses, because not even the taxpayers of Australia could sustain a guaranteed price of 800c to 1,000c per kilogram—the level at which it was set in 1990. The opposition supports this legislation and looks forward to seeing a more prosperous wool industry as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996. I listened to Senator Schacht with great interest. He gave a very interesting historical overview of what has happened, although a lot of what he said did not address the issue that we are actually debating in the bill—
—Why we are debating this bill is because of that history. It never would have occurred if we hadn't got it wrong.

—Yes, and I even agree with some of the history; but there are other perspectives on history, as you know. History is always written by the winners. The Democrats, having had the agony of debates that had gone on at least since 1990, were trying to represent some of the wool growers who had a contrary opinion to that of both the government and the coalition, even in 1993.

BREAK.PARA: I was going to spend a lot of time reading what was said at the hearings in 1993. Some of the things those wool growers said were quite prophetic. They warned that the very rigid fixed release schedule, which was put in place, would operate as a factor in forcing the price of wool down while the stockpile remained high and while the 187,000 bales on average per quarter were being pushed onto the market. They warned the auction system for new wool could not withstand competition of large amounts of wool from the stockpile being pushed onto the market. They were right.

Except for a couple of peaks, we have had no improvement in the price of wool during the last three years. While people will argue with me and say, `There are a lot of reasons for that,' very few in the government or the opposition are prepared to admit that one of the contributing factors was the rigid fixed release schedule. No‐one can convince me that it was not a contributing factor. I was going to read a lot of what was said in 1993, but I am not going to do that because—

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate it.

—No, because I would have had to pick pieces out. But it is worth repeating that the words of the wool growers at the hearing on 22 October 1993 who warned us about what would happen were prophetic. They warned us that the fixed release schedule would have the effect that it has had. There are always, in this kind of debate, a number of truths. The other truth that has to be put alongside this one is that there is a very real argument which says that the stockpile had to be reduced as quickly and significantly as possible. The fixed release selling schedule has had that effect. The stockpile is now at a much more manageable level.

BREAK.PARA: The government had to be dragged screaming to make this minor amendment to the fixed release schedule. In 1993, the then shadow minister, and now minister Anderson, did not want to hear any of the arguments which were put to him. It has to be said that even this year the minister was reluctant to make any alteration to the legislation.

It may be that we have reached a stage where this amendment is almost irrelevant because of the reduction in the size of the stockpile. I think we should have given Wool International the flexibility in marketing that it needed a lot earlier than this. We put up the idea of a trigger price. If it had been put in place in 1993 it would have given Wool International flexibility. People will argue about that with me till the cows come home, but I will keep saying it.

Now, towards the end of the whole process, we are at last giving Wool International a bit more flexibility through reducing the amount from the stockpile which has to be sold and also giving them a little bit of flexibility at the upper end so that they can sell from the stockpile if the market improves. That is important. The Democrats will support the legislation. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wool International Amendment Bill does two things. Firstly, it replaces the current terms of the fixed disposal schedule of the wool stockpile with more flexible provisions and reduces the 185,000 bales a quarter to be sold initially to 135,000 bales a quarter. Secondly, it provides for a change in emphasis of the role of Wool International, requiring it to have regard to the effect of its disposal on the market. In effect, it therefore requires Wool International to maximise the profitability of wool growers both in terms of the value of their fresh wool and their equity in the stockpile.

PARA.BREAK: This legislation comes substantially out of the second wool round table conference in August. Minister Anderson is to be congratu lated in bringing all the disparate wool groups together twice this year—in May and August—to get some agreement. As Senator Woodley said, there had been enormous pressure from the Wool Council, the stud merino breeders and many others for a change of the stockpile disposal. I suppose the story of the wool industry is a bit like that of Greek political parties: if you have five Greeks, you generally have at least six political parties. If you have five wool growers, you have six solutions.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no easy solutions with wool—and it has been a very long and painful seven years. I guess this legislative change today will go some way to finding some solutions; hopefully, it does. Out of the second wool round table, commonsense and compromise prevailed and all the participants came to a position which they could all reasonably accept. The participants included interests, both overseas and Australian, from all sectors—manufacturers, processors, brokers and growers. The position on future stockpile management is well known and I will not go through that because of the shortness of time allowed for this debate.

This legislation is the beginning of the final chapter of what has been a disastrous seven years for the wool industry. The first attempt to handle the 4.7 million bale stockpile and the $2.8 billion debt was an attempt to sell enough wool to meet debt repayments. That had a disastrous effect because, when we got to the end of a period where a certain amount of money needed to be repaid, the market came under enormous pressure. It was speculation in reverse. That was just not a way to sell anything.

The second attempt was the setting up of Wool International by the previous government, which we supported. Again, there were no easy answers and the set stockpile reduction of 185,000 bales per quarter came into operation. This worked adequately for the reduction of the stockpile and the debt. But pain to wool growers continued for the whole of the period, and it continues and can never be underestimated.

These new changes are all about increasing the value of the stockpile and also of fresh wool sales as soon as possible post 1 January next year. This is an attempt to provide the market signals that will give wool growers hope and profitability, and also encourage them to continue growing wool. That is something that also cannot be underestimated.

I would like to make a couple of brief final points. The first is to wish our colleague Senator Winston Crane a speedy recovery. I mention him in this context because Senator Crane is one of the staunchest supporters in this place of the wool industry. I do not think it has a greater friend than Senator Crane. As chairman of the rural and regional affairs committee he has been vitally involved in the evidence that was provided to the Senate on the options that might have been available in changing the actual stockpile sales.

The second point is to note that the wool industry reached another milestone this week in stockpile sales, with the stockpile falling to below two million bales. So it has more than halved in the last three years from its high of 4.7 million bales. By June next year, the stockpile will be 1.7 million bales—that is, a massive three million bales will have been sold down over six years. The debt, which peaked at $2.8 billion in 1991, will be $900 million by the end of this month. By June 1997, this debt should be reduced substantially, to around $600 million, and the equity remaining will be of great assistance to wool growers. Hopefully, it will be in excess of $500 million.

PARA.BREAK: Access to that equity is for debate at another time, as is the role of Wool International in forward marketing proposals and the proposed wool joint venture. Of course, the future funding and role of promotion is another big issue for debate at another time. With those few words, I applaud the minister for the work he has done in the wool industry. He has had an enormous requirement to come to grips with a very difficult historical record of problems and the enormous number of different solutions that have been put forward. With great tenacity and a capacity to master the facts, I think he has been able to provide a framework so that we can go on, hopefully, to a time of much greater prosperi ty and development in a very great Australian industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I declare my interest as a wool grower. Secondly, I agree with what Senator Schacht had to say. It was a good resume of the ails of the industry since 1988‐89. He described very well what was wrong. The problems came about not necessarily because of the greed of the growers, but because of the growers' peak body. I agree with that. The change away from 187,000 bales per quarter was not necessarily brought about totally by the industry. It was brought about—as Senator Schacht or Senator Macdonald mentioned—by the demands by the Stud Breeders Association of Australia that we interfere with the sale of 187,000 bales per quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish the new measure well. I hope it does something for wool and that it gets the price moving a bit, but I have got very grave doubts that it will. I have said all along that I have got grave doubts that it will make any difference. We will see when the time comes how much difference it does make. The only real friend of wool growing at the present moment is the downward pressure on production. Production has dropped from 1,020 million kilos in 1989‐90 to about 614 million kilos this year. It continues to drop.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many bales is 600 million kilos?
—About three million bales, roughly.
—So two million is about two‐thirds of the annual production?

—Yes, that is right. Our hope is to get rid of the stockpile, get production down and get back to a truly free enterprise industry. Then, of course, we will build the demand up. Those things have got to be done. I do not want to prolong the debate. I wish this measure well, but I am very sorry that I have not got much confidence in this amendment. I would like to put on the record that more Western Australian wool growers agree with me than have the opposite view, but I still wish the measure well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues in supporting this legislation which is before the Senate. The measure of the importance that the Senate, if not the parliament, has given the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 is that it was given priority as a matter of urgency. It jumped over many other seemingly equally important bills to be voted on at this very moment so that it can be enacted on 1 January 1997. That is the importance the Senate has given it. We know only too well the importance it has for the industry. I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald. As he well knows, this is extremely important for our National Party constituency. That is why we joined the debate. Given that we are pressed for time, we cannot allow such an important bill as the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 to go by without our comment.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald and I have been involved in this debate for the past six years. My colleague has in fact lived with this debate as a wool grower himself. I have to differ somewhat, though, from the comments of my very good friend and colleague, and marvellous wool grower, Senator Panizza. I thought he was a little too kind to Senator Schacht, quite frankly. Senator Schacht is not a bad senator, and he was a very good dairy farmer in his day, but I think he had a bit of difficulty grappling with the wool industry's history. There was a touch of rewriting there. We are meant to believe that, behind closed doors in caucus meetings, Senator Schacht spoke up for the wool industry, and that John Kerin was at no fault at all—that he was faultless, that the history of John Kerin is clean on this!

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had refused the requests for the industry to guarantee it, you would have been jumping into him.

—The former minister Mr Kerin made several commitments and promises to the industry during the time of the darkest moments of crisis—and he broke every single one of them. The then government could not sit tight, and had great difficulty grappling with the crisis at the time. Quite frankly, we would never have been in so deep a crisis if that government had shown a bit more managerial ability.
—Senator Panizza agrees with me.

—In spite of all the times I have agreed with Senator Panizza, I have explained that he was just a bit too kind to you. He is probably just a little swamped by the euphoria of having the US President out here yesterday, and he was rushing off to grab a bite to eat before question time, and so he was just a little too generous to you. You should not take advantage of Senator Panizza, because he can bite back just as hard on people like you. He is in a good mood today, but I cannot allow your trying to rewrite history to that extent to go by. Of course, elements of what you said were true: there is no doubt about that. But, as for trying to make Mr Kerin fault free, go and try selling that to a wool grower! Given his history, they would string up Mr Kerin in the shearing shed if he went anywhere near a wool grower.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, we are all in agreement on this legislation; and that is the most important thing. We all have our version of history—some versions more truthful than others—but I cannot come to grips with trying to understand what happened inside your caucus meeting. Do you want us to take it on faith that in fact the caucus actually discussed the wool industry, do you? Even that idea surprises me, let alone that you stuck up for it. I am surprised that the caucus ever got around to discussing the wool industry, when it had so many other things to discuss, such as how much you were going to flog off to the union that week, or what special grants you were going to give that week, and what person was taking an ambassadorial position, ready to go. Anyway, I am quite happy to think that at one stage during your 13 years of government you bothered to discuss the wool industry.

Getting down to the legislation in the very short time that we have all been given for the debate, because we want the bill to go through, I will say that, a bit like my Democrat colleague, we are all aware of the history of the Garnaut report and its recommendation, which was taken up by the coalition and the then government for a fixed schedule. But that time has run its course for whatever benefit it did have. In fact, even Professor Garnaut himself has said that it has run its course and that we need a far more managerial and flexible sale of the wool stockpile.

That is why this legislation is important: we now need to manage down that last two million bales for the sake of the wool growers. The wool growers have sent that message loud and clear through the ranks of the industry. I am glad to say that that message got to the round table, but not without a bit of effort by the wool growers to shake up all industry bodies to get that message through. And now we have an acceptable piece of legislation rushed through the parliament. The fact that matters of urgency can be taken through the parliament in a short space of time shows that the parliament can and does work.

There was only one party that disagreed with this legislation and did not even want to debate it: the Green movement. They had their own particular agenda. Their protest was that they were not even consulted on this matter; but this matter has been around for some six years and it is very regrettable that they know very little about the wool industry and that they, if they had had the chance, would have held up this legislation. However, the coalition parties support this legislation, as does most of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 is widely understood, and I do not propose to recanvass that. The tragic history of this industry is also well known, and it took as its victims thousands and thousands of families. I would like to cover, on a more positive note, a number of issues that were raised this morning with those members and senators who were able to attend a briefing from the IWS and its Managing Director, Mr Kloeden, who was much more optimistic than perhaps the price of wool might indicate, in particular, about the increasing demand for wool products in the UK, the United States and some of the northern hemisphere countries. I think that growers can look forward to increased demand and perhaps increased price in the future. Clearly, getting greater flexibility in the disposal of the stockpile is fundamental to that. I look forward with optimism, as they do, to greater prices and greater demand, which will lead to the reconstruction of a great industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all the speakers who have spoken: Senator Schacht; Senator Woodley; Senator Sandy Macdonald, who is one of the few wool growers who has spoken in this debate; Senator Panizza, who is also a wool grower; Senator McGauran; and Senator Ferris. The amendments proposed in the Wool International Amendment Bill 1996 are the result of all the extensive work that has gone on at the round table. I congratulate John Anderson. There is a genuine consensus among members of the industry at the moment that the amendments are necessary and that they want them to go through.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is signalling through these amendments, though, its intention to continue to withdraw from the industry and allow it to take control of its own future. We have confidence that the industry is ready and able to provide its own leadership. The government will, of course, continue to assist the industry in areas such as market access, micro‐economic reform, industrial relations and other broad issues. I thank all those speakers once again for being so helpful and forthright in this debate so that we can get the bill through in quick time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.39 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Jocelyn Newman, the Minister for Social Security, will be absent from question time today. She will be in Sydney with Mrs Hillary Clinton. In her absence, Senator Alston will take questions relating to her portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The opposition does believe that it is regrettable that Senator Newman is not with us for question time today, but we do understand that she was required to attend a certain function in Sydney at short notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, we do strongly regret the fact that you are with us today. As the senior female presiding officer in Australia, we believe that you too should have been invited to the same function in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Australian government support the reappointment of Mr Boutros Boutros-Ghali as Secretary‐General of the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —That strikes me as being a little sensitive for me to have a go at without seeking some advice from others. But we certainly recognise and appreciate the very helpful and constructive contribution Dr Boutros Boutros-Ghali has made as Secretary-General of the United Nations.

ANSWER.PARA: I will seek advice from the Minister for Foreign Affairs as to whether he wants to make any public statement on the continued candidature of Dr Boutros Boutros‐Ghali. That is if he is going to continue in the race—I think I heard this morning that he may not. I will seek advice on the Australian position in relation to his earlier nomination and let you know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. First of all, Minister, I am astonished that, in view of the publicity about this issue over the last several days—not just the last few hours—you do not have a brief available to indicate to the Senate the official position of the Australian government on this matter.

QUESTION.PARA: When you seek to refer this matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for clarification of the government's position, could you ask him if the matter was discussed at all between President Clinton and Prime Minister Howard or at the cabinet meeting with the US President yesterday? If we are supporting the nomination of Mr Boutros Boutros-Ghali and that nomination is not successful because of the American veto, do we have any view yet of whom else we would support, particularly from the African continent? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer those additional questions to the minister for advice as well.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Yesterday the centrepiece of the coalition's family package—the family tax initiative bills—was passed by the Senate. These measures will deliver assistance to around two million families with children. When will Australian families begin to enjoy the benefits of this government's initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for his question. He has always shown in this chamber his very strong interest in family issues. The family tax initiative bills were passed by this chamber yesterday with, I think, the support of all sides—even the Labor Party thought they were great bills. We welcome that sort of support.

ANSWER.PARA: The family tax initiative, as you have suggested, is the centrepiece of the coalition's family tax package to ease the tax burden on low and middle income Australian families with children.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you reading it if you know it so well?

—The good news, Senator Ray, is that, for around two million eligible Australian families with children, the initiative will commence on 1 January 1997, just six weeks away. Australian families will be delighted with the present that will be coming from the coalition government just after Christmas.

ANSWER.PARA: This is another election promise delivered, as the Treasurer says and reminds us frequently, in full and on time. It is an election commitment that will put $1 billion a year into the pockets of Australian families. The coalition framed the policy to give families hope for the future after 13 years of neglect by the Labor Party.

The policy recognises the central importance of the family and the costs of raising families. It offers families choice in whether one parent wants to stay at home to care for children. The family tax initiative recognises that not all Australian families are identical. It recognises a wide range of family structures in Australia. As well as nuclear families, it covers sole parents, grandparents caring for grandchildren and foster families.

Consistent with our election policy, the initiative is being delivered in two parts. The first part is to increase the tax free threshold of $1,000 per child for families that meet the family income test. This translates to a $200 tax cut per year per eligible child. This part is available to all types of families, including single income families, provided the income tests are met. An eligible family with three dependent children will receive a tax cut of $600 per year, or some $23.10 per fortnight, under this part of the initiative.

Under the second part of the initiative, single families, including sole parents, with at least one child under the age of five, may be eligible for an additional increased tax free threshold of $2,500. This is an additional tax cut of some $500 per year. This part recognises the additional costs of raising a young family—and we make no apology for that.

A family which meets the criteria for both parts with two children under five will receive a total tax cut of some $900 per year or in the order of $34.60 per fortnight. Families do not have to wait until the end of the financial year to access the tax cut. It can be accessed through the PAYE system or on assessment.

Low income families which do not have a high enough tax liability to benefit fully from the benefit of the tax cut will have the alternative of receiving the family tax initiative as an equivalent fortnightly cash payment from the Department of Social Security called family tax payments. Some 900,000 families will receive an immediate boost to their disposable income through this payment option from 1 January.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said on 30 August, about the inquiry he instigated into private health insurance premiums:

QUESTION.PARA: I think the people in the industry all understand we will be looking very askance at applications for increases during that inquiry.
How askance did the Prime Minister look at the applications for premium increases that were approved and have rendered the health insurance rebate worthless?

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters were obviously looked at very carefully.
—Five times the rate of inflation. Is that fair?

—Well, you have to ask the question: when was there last an increase? You have to start looking at it from that point of view. If you look at the Medibank Private case, I am told there has not been a premium increase for the last 19 months. I am told also that during—
—What is the inflation rate for the last 19 months?
—Yes, but that is not the total story. That is just part of the picture. I am also told that benefit payments have increased—
—You are told. Don't you believe it?
—I have no reason not to believe it.
—Why did you say you were told?
—Because that is what the brief tells me.
—You are not going to tie yourself down to a PM&C brief, are you? You are too smart for that.
—Well, I know you look at these things very technically, Senator. Medibank Private's rates, I am told, are still amongst the lowest in each state.
—Truly pathetic.

—I suppose really what you have to do is look back over a period of history and see the circumstances that have led to it. The circumstances were as a result of the previous government's policies in relation to these matters. In fact, I am told that a lot of it is purely and simply because of the concerted drive by the previous government to remove support from the private sector. First, the contribution to the reinsurance pool was gradually phased out between 1983 and 1989. That loaded some $100 million onto the funds. Then the bed day subsidy was done away with in September of 1986 at a cost of $135 million. Then the Medicare rebates for in‐hospital services were reduced to 75 per cent with the funds being required to cover over 25 per cent. Also the Medicare agreements of 1993 gave the states every incentive to increase public patient throughput at the expense of private patients, thus pushing private patients into private hospitals with increased costs to the insurance funds.
—What else have you been told?

—Senator Faulkner will be aware that Access Economics has recently calculated the cost shifting involved in these measures by the previous Labor government, including the shift from public to private hospitals, as costing the funds $846 million in today's dollars, which represents a 39 per cent increase in premiums. In other words, if it was not for Labor, hospital premiums for a family would be $30 a month lower and the consequences of this increase would not be as great.
—That is what you have been told.

—That is what I have been told, and that is what I think is correct. Therefore, whilst we are obviously disappointed that these increases are necessary, there seems to be no doubt that they are necessary as a result of the policies that your previous Labor government put in place. As a result of the ineptness of those judgments, the Australian people are now having to pay more for their private health care.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will your government be complying with your election prom ise to provide a private health insurance rebate to Australian families and institute a rebate that has some worth in light of the government's decision to rubber‐stamp the health funds' application for increases and cut the bulk of the rebates well before they come into effect on 1 July next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we will. At least we are doing something to support people who have taken out private health care. These increases would have occurred anyway. Do you know, Senator, that between 1984 and 1995—years that you would be very familiar with—the rates increased, on average, about 12 per cent each year. I do not remember you coming in here being embarrassed about that.

ANSWER.PARA: In one catastrophic period between 1986 and 1988, premiums under your government increased by 40 per cent. So they were increasing in any event. The difference is that we are prepared to do something to reduce the cost to Australian people. We are prepared to give them some encouragement to remain in these funds and, if they are not in the funds, to join the funds. If some, such as your previous Prime Minister, Mr Keating, had been prepared to make a contribution to private health care, that would have helped also. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many senators breaching standing orders and intruding into question time.

—My question is addressed to the minister for Austudy, Senator Vanstone. On 10 December the opposition joined with the Democrats to disallow Austudy regulations which, among other measures, benefited rural families in drought affected areas. A significant number of rural families were assisted by this measure. Can the minister inform the Senate of the action she has taken to restore these very valuable Austudy regulations? Can she also inform the Senate of the benefits for rural Austudy recipients arising from the government's recently announced extension to drought recovery assistance?
—What did you say at the National Party conference?
—Order! Senator Faulkner, you have been interjecting too frequently in this question time and I ask you to desist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell for that question. You do not know how pleased it makes me to answer it. As Senator Faulkner rightly identified, 10 September was not a good day for Labor members and for the Democrats. In a rush to make a very cheap political point, they disallowed a number of regulations and of course realised later what they had done. What they had done was cause enormous heartbreak and concern in rural communities, communities which Senator West pretends to look after. She accuses the National Party of walking both sides of the street when in fact she does the same herself.

ANSWER.PARA: The regulations that were disallowed were in fact the previous government's own regulations. They disallowed their own regulations; their own budget decisions from the 1995‐96 families package. They came in here and disallowed their own minister's regulations. They were decisions that were taken by the previous cabinet and endorsed by the previous cabinet including some members opposite here. Then they came and voted against them to make a cheap political point. The disallowed regulations actually came from the then minister, Minister Free.

The opposition's decision to support the disallowance was done in haste and they wiped out Austudy assistance to rural families in exceptional circumstances in drought affected areas. This would have taken assistance through to the end of the year in which the drought recovery period ends. The action of the Labor opposition was completely irresponsible and could have dealt a very savage blow to rural Australia.

As usual, the people opposite created the mess and we have been left to fix it up. This government was very concerned about the mess that was created by Labor members opposite. Drought exceptional circumstances were revoked from parts of South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland on 11 June and students from those areas would not have got Austudy until the end of the calendar year if we had not acted. That gap might not mean a very large amount to some, but it is a lot to the people who were expecting it.

Senator Boswell, together with Senator Woodley—who graciously and rapidly recognised the error of his ways—moved to rescind the disallowance on 9 October 1996. This week we have reintroduced these Austudy regulations to ensure the assistance to rural Australia. We have re‐established student assistance measures to ease the plight of families and students in drought affected areas who otherwise would have been so harshly affected by this opposition move.

If we had not moved to reintroduce this Austudy drought relief measure, many students from needy rural families would have had their student allowance reduced or stopped altogether before the end of the year in which they were studying. Students would have been left only getting Austudy for a six‐month period following the revocation of drought status. In addition, struggling rural families will receive a significant boost from the $81.5 million package of drought recovery assistance recently announced by Minister John Anderson.

The drought recovery period has now been extended from six to 12 months and that extension will assist in securing the future of students from farming families. Together with the government's reintroduction of previously disallowed Austudy regulations, this means additional assistance for rural families. Families in areas whose recovery period would have ended on 11 December will now be able to access student assistance under special concessions until the end of next year. These measures demonstrate the strength of the commitment of the government to assist rural families and our willingness to clean up the mess that Labor creates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joe and Enid Lyons Memorial Lecture

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Which officer in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet authorised the department to send 13 staff members to a Liberal Party function, the Joe and Enid Lyons Memorial Lecture? How does the minister reconcile this expenditure with the savage cuts being imposed on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet by this government? What benefit does the minister believe was derived from a physical presence at this function which could not have been derived from a mere reading of the speech?

—As you will recall, the Joe and Enid Lyons Memorial Lecture was delivered by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and was widely regarded as a seminal policy announcement. The lecture, including the question and answer session afterwards, was regarded by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet as a staff development and information exercise for those involved in the development of indigenous policy.
—What, listening to this boofhead!
—For that reason, the staff were given the opportunity to go.
—Senator Ray, I believe that is a statement that ought to be withdrawn.
—I withdraw.
—For those reasons, the relatively modest payment for the number of staff that attended—that is, a total of $390—was regarded as a good investment in staff development.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The $390 was a $30 per person fee. Was that fee meant to cover the costs of the function or was there a profit margin included? If so, whom does the profit benefit?
—I understand that—
—They got fed.
—It is a good question. Who gets the profit?
—It is a reasonable question. I understand that lunch was included in the fee, so I doubt whether there was any profit.
—You doubt it but you don't know.
—How do you want to calculate that? What a silly question.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the question was fine; the interjection from Senator Faulkner was silly. I am saying that the cost of these officers attending this staff development opportunity was $30 and the $30 included the cost of their lunch.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. In the last 10 years we have gone from requiring a demonstration of `net economic benefit' to Australia for a foreign takeover proposal to a far more lax test of being `not contrary to the national interest'. I see now that in Australia's individual action plan, which will be taken to the APEC meeting next week, the government intends to limit specific restrictions for foreign ownership to an even smaller number of prescribed `sensitive' areas and is looking at automatic approval for a foreign takeover or investment worth anything up to $50 million. What is wrong with requiring foreign investors to prove their proposal is of `net economic benefit' to this country? What do you think of the fact that foreign investors into our country get far better support from their governments than our own companies get from our government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray has raised the issue of foreign investment and the approvals which are required for foreign investment. As he noted in his question, there are particular areas which are specialised areas and to which particular rules apply, such as, for example, real estate, a very important area. There are other areas where particular rules apply.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Murray, I do not think I have seen the particular proposal that you have mentioned, but I will look closely at what your question has asked. If I can add any further information, I will get back to you after question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, given that we have already cut our throats by putting ourselves at a disadvantage compared to almost all our APEC competitors on economic management tools like tariffs, subsidies, industry assistance schemes and tax assistance schemes, shouldn't we be sure of the benefits this time? Simply, if the government is so sure of the benefits for foreign ownership and takeover, why will it not apply a simple `net economic benefit' test and, incidentally, a `competitive equality' test, so that we will know what is happening is good for us?

—Senator Murray, as you would be aware, we believe that where we allow foreign investment, it is to the benefit of the country. That policy was followed by the previous government and will be followed by this government. Senator Murray, you raised an issue in your first question and I will see whether I can provide additional information to you.

—I address my question to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, is it true that the new deeming provisions on superannuation for people aged 55 will force tens of thousands of Aussie battlers to draw on their superannuation early, thus reducing the capital value normally accruing at the age of 60 enabling them to receive a full or higher part pension at pension age? Therefore, will this not erode national savings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of issues there in relation to deeming, some of which would be better asked of the Minister for Social Security.
—You have no idea.
—Senator Evans has no idea what deeming is. You have a shadow Treasurer who has no idea what deeming is and made a complete dope of himself.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many persistent and continuing interjections on my left, totally disrupting question time.
—As the questioner will know, the issue of deeming is one of concern to this government and the wider community—to make sure that the deeming provisions are fair.
—Savings, Senator, national savings.
—You raised the issue of national savings.
—We are very helpful, aren't we?

—Who wants to ask the question? Does anyone else want to ask the question? It is intriguing that the Labor Party raises the issue of national savings, because the problems with national savings, Senator Reynolds, as you would be aware, basically became a huge problem under your government.
—That is not so. It started 20 years ago.

—Senator Sherry, that is the case. In the last five years, you will be aware, Senator Reynolds, this government spent $70 billion more than it actually raised. There was a massive deficit. As you would be aware, Senator, it was of no help to national savings whatsoever. This government is very concerned that the deeming provisions are fair and are provided in a fair manner.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask senators on my left to refrain from continuous interjecting.
—But it's a joke.
—Order! There are opportunities to discuss the matter after question time.
—It's comedy hour with this bloke.
—Order! I am speaking.
—Come on, dumbo, finish up.
—Senator Faulkner!

—Senator Faulkner is constantly seeking to raise further issues as I seek to answer the question. We have put into place a policy program which we believe will provide increased incentives to boost savings and to deal with the serious savings issue which was left to this government by the former government.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it true that no modelling has been carried out on the additional longer term costs to the pension system or the reduction in national savings? Isn't this measure collecting tomorrow's revenue today?

—Before you accept questions which are handed to you, presumably by a member of the questions committee, it would be well worth while just checking carefully. There is a need to increase national savings. No-one argues with that. That is why we have put into place a policy framework that will assist national savings. You have raised issues in relation to modelling. I will see whether there is any additional information I am able to give you. I am not sure that that can be done. I take your interest in national savings. It is about time the Labor Party did take an interest in national savings.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Yesterday President Clinton, in the presence of the Prime Minister, told me that he would raise the issue of Tibet when he meets China's President Jiang Zemin in the Philippines next week and that, indeed, he always does. President Clinton expressed a concern for recent events in Tibet, including the plight of Tibetan culture. Will Prime Minister Howard also raise the issue of Tibet when he meets the Chinese representatives in the Philippines next week? In particular, will he raise the Dalai Lama's request to discuss autonomy for Tibet with the Chinese government?

—I do not think the Prime Minister will be raising the issue of autonomy of Tibet. As Senator Brown knows, and as I have said in the Senate before, the Australian government takes seriously allegations of human rights abuses in China, including Tibet. At appropriate occasions we make our concerns known to the Chinese. We do it through both bilateral and multilateral forums. Through those means we seek to contribute to the international community's efforts to see that the people of Tibet can be better respected in terms of their human rights and their economic opportunity. Whether the Prime Minister is planning to use this occasion, which as I have also said before is primarily an economic occasion, to raise that issue again, I do not know, but I will seek advice from him in that regard.
—Madam President, on a point of order: during Senator Hill's answer, Senator Vanstone struck a member of her own party.
—You are pathetic.
—Perhaps you should pick on someone your own size. Seriously, is it in order for a minister to behave in that way during question time?
—Order! I did not see anything of that nature occur. I was focusing on Senator Hill. Whether Senator Vanstone was passing something to Senator Alston or not, I have no idea.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is China's occupation of Tibet not a matter of very great economic, as well as social and environmental, concern for 7 million people on the roof of the world? I ask the minister again: will he put it to the Prime Minister that he raise the issue not specifically of autonomy for Tibet but of the request from the Dalai Lama to meet Chinese leadership to discuss the issue of autonomy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I said that I doubted the Prime Minister would be raising the issue of autonomy is that what Senator Brown is seeking of the Prime Minister is inconsistent with Australian government policy. As the Senate knows, the Australian government recognises that Tibet is part of China—a recognition that was implicit when Australia recognised the People's Republic of China in 1972. This is not in any way a judgment on the historical rights and wrongs of the issue but simply an acknowledgment that the territory of the People's Republic of China includes the region of Tibet, and the Chinese authorities exercise the functions of government in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: As a matter of interest, Australia's stance on this issue is in conformity with that of the wider international community. All countries that have diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China recognise China's sovereignty over Tibet. The United Nations also accepts that Tibet is part of China. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. In your answer to a question taken on notice from Senator Forshaw regarding the involvement of the Minister for Finance in Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd you said:

QUESTION.PARA: There was a loan to the directors which is being repaid in a normal manner and the minister has been advised by his accountant that there are no tax implications.

Can you explain how a company loan can be repaid in a normal manner when that company has been deregistered for four years? Have the moneys that have been repaid been vested in the ASC commissioner, as is required by section 576(1) of the Corporations Law? If not, to whom has the money been paid?

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only assume that this question was rejected by the House of Representatives Labor Party questions committee and that is the reason it is being put to me. One would have thought that if you were genuinely interested in an answer to that question, Senator Conroy, it would have been put to the Minister for Finance. But I do not think you are genuinely interested in an answer to that question so you raise it in this chamber. That is possibly the reason why the question was raised here—or else your colleagues in the other place thought it was a hopeless question, Senator Conroy, and were not prepared to have that question listed.
—Now try answering it.

—I have given an answer, Senator Faulkner. The answer simply is that, if you were interested in getting an immediate response to that question, you would have put it in the other place, but you did not. You put it over here. So, Senator Conroy, I will refer your question to the Minister for Finance.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you confirm that the Minister for Finance has sought the reinstatement of Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd in order to cover up his failure to comply with the Corporations Law? Do you believe that Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd should be prosecuted by the ASC for its failure to lodge annual returns for over seven years and, if not, why not?
—I have nothing to add to my first response.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. I refer the minister to conflicting reports in newspapers this morning concerning the chairman of ATSIC, Miss Lois O'Donoghue. One report said that she had been invited to the meeting in Sydney today involving the Prime Minister's wife, Mrs Howard, and the President's wife, Mrs Clinton. Others say she has not been invited. Minister, could you please clarify the situation for the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson for the question. I am able to assure the Senate that Miss O'Donoghue was invited to the meeting in Sydney today. The article appearing in the Canberra Times under the headline `ATSIC Chairwoman left off guest list' was completely inaccurate. Miss O'Donoghue was always on the guest list.

ANSWER.PARA: I do understand that her office initially declined the invitation because she had a commitment in Adelaide this evening. She was, in fact, to attend the MCATSIA meeting. Her office informs me, however, that she has been able to rearrange her schedule so that she would be free to attend the meeting with Mrs Clinton.

I find it curious that the Canberra Times produced this piece of inaccurate nonsense when virtually every other major newspaper in the country reported the fact that Miss O'Donoghue had been invited to meet Mrs Clinton. I note that the West Australian reported that fact—as did the Australian, the Adelaide Advertiser and the Brisbane Courier‐Mail. I am also informed that Miss O'Donoghue today put out a clarifying statement correcting the Canberra Times report. I have seen a draft of that statement in which Miss O'Donoghue makes it perfectly clear that an invitation to attend the meeting was extended to her. I would hope that the Canberra Times sees fit to correct their completely inaccurate report.

While I am on the subject of gross inaccuracies, I should also draw the Senate's attention to another piece of totally inaccurate reporting in the Financial Review today. The `Rear Window' section has the heading `Black art but no black faces'. It says, in part:
Lunch in the Great Hall of Parliament had a more conservative theme. Not an Aboriginal face to be seen and the musical accompaniment was a reworking of Waltzing Matilda.

All senators who attended would know as well as I that not only was Miss Lois O'Donoghue at the lunch but it was also attended by the chairman of the Torres Strait Regional Authority, Mr Getano Lui, and television presenter and actor Ernie Dingo. In addition, the chairman of the reconciliation council, Patrick Dodson, was invited to attend but had to decline because of other engagements. Again, I would hope that the Financial Review would correct this piece of totally inaccurate reporting.

Returning to today's meeting in Sydney involving Mrs Howard, Mrs Clinton and Senator Jocelyn Newman, I might inform the Senate that it is, in fact, a small reception of about 30 Australian women. The reception has been organised on an informal basis. Those attending are generally from the fields of law and health, which are areas of particular interest to Mrs Clinton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: are you also aware of criticism by some members of the Labor Party that the reception today would be a waste of time because it involved so many women from the coalition side of politics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferguson. I have to say that I am aware of some small-minded comments to that effect. I am not aware of who is attending the reception—other than Miss O'Donoghue and Ms Patricia Turner, the CEO of ATSIC. I am delighted to say that they are both present.

BREAK.PARA: I can say, however, that the coalition has an outstanding record of bringing women to the fore. Senator Newman and my colleague Senator Vanstone are both very valuable members of cabinet. The last election, Madam President, saw not only you elected to the presidency of the Senate but 18 female coalition members elected in the House of Representatives—fully on merit, without any quota system as imposed by the Labor Party. We have seven female Liberal senators here—one of whom is celebrating a birthday today. I think we ought to congratulate her on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—On the Labor side, even with their quota system, there are four female members in the House of Representatives. I also note—(Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. With regard to the advice that Minister Fahey's accountant has provided—that there are no tax implications regarding the directors' loan from Lochreagh Investments Pty Ltd to Mr Fahey—will you confirm that the advice categorically states that no liability for taxation arises under section 108 of the tax act? The tax act says, in part, `If a private company pays an amount to an associated person by way of an advance or loan so much, if any, of the amount paid or credited as, in the opinion of the commissioner, represents a distribution of profits shall be deemed to be a dividend paid by the company.' Given this, will you refer this issue to the tax commissioner in order to seek his opinion whether section 108 of the tax act does, indeed, apply to the directors' loan to Mr Fahey and, if you will not refer it, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —There is within the question that Senator Sherry has posed a range of assumptions which may well prove to be quite wrong. Can I point out to you, Senator Sherry, that the advice which has been provided to me and which was read quite well to the chamber by Senator Conroy is this:

ANSWER.PARA: There was a loan to the Directors which is being repaid in a normal manner and the Minister has been advised by his Accountant that there are no tax implications.

That is the advice which has been provided to me. Senator Sherry has raised a number of other questions. The point I made to Senator Conroy applies equally to Senator Sherry. I can only imagine that your colleagues in the other place felt that this was not a question which was appropriate to put to the Minister for Finance. What I will do—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is outrageous. Answer the question here.

—Before you start foaming at the mouth, Senator Cook, the question relates to the Minister for Finance. It relates to the finances of the Minister for Finance. It would not be surprising—most people would regard it as a matter of commonsense—that if the Labor Party wished to pursue these matters, they would raise those questions with the Minister for Finance.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a brief here and a response which I have reread to the chamber. I will refer the matters raised by Senator Sherry to the Minister for Finance and see whether he wants to add anything further. If he does, Senator Sherry, I will come back to the chamber, as I came back last time, and read the response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp, you are right; these are important questions, and I understand your predecessor, Senator Short, had responsibility for the tax act and would expect you to at least have some knowledge of these matters. Is it acceptable under the Howard government for the Minister for Finance to so flagrantly breach the Corporations Law and possibly taxation law on the proviso that it is okay providing you do not get caught? How does Mr Fahey's conduct in regard to Lochreagh Investments conform with the ministerial code of conduct?

—I have got nothing more to add to the response I gave to the original question. Senator, I will refer these matters to the Minister for Finance, which you would expect me to do. I will then see whether there is a response that he wishes to make. Senator, if he has a response which he wishes to make, I will come back to this chamber and read that response to you.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Is the minister aware that Telstra provides as part of its community service obligations a service known as Telelink? People who are isolated in remote country areas, the frail aged and people with disabilities are kept in touch on a regular basis by Telelink, and it has been very successful in helping build social networks, providing security for many who continue to live independently. Minister, are you aware that Telstra in this telecommunications reform environment is winding back the service in some areas and says that it will not take any new participants in Telelink between now and March next year? Will you insist that Telstra, the corporation which announced a profit of $2.3 billion last financial year, continue to meet this important community service obligation and continue to expand the service to meet the needs of these people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of that decision. Let me say that, to the extent that it is a requirement under the existing community service obligations which are imposed by the parliament, there would be no basis upon which Telstra could depart from that obligation. If it is merely an undertaking given by Telstra, then there is nothing that the government can do to force it to reconsider that. I will certainly get further advice for you.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot recall offhand what Telelink is about. But if it is the one that Michael Lee announced a few years back, where low income and disadvantaged groups were given a concession on the cost of calls—I see you are saying it is not. If it is part of the CSO, then it is enshrined in legislation. If it is not, then it is difficult to see why a company should voluntarily accept a social obligation, particularly when it is facing much greater competition, when even now it is under competitive pressure and when it does want to ensure that its products are delivered at the lowest cost. I will simply get further information from you and get back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and ask that he seek out the information as to the benefits of this very valuable service. I would ask also that he look into the possibility of this becoming a service obligation in the post-1997 deregulated environment.
—I have nothing more to add.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. On their return to Australia, did Mr Andrew Robb, Mr Jonathon Gaul and Mr Mark Textor brief the foreign minister on the latest trends in the Conservative Party in the United Kingdom? Did they raise with Mr Major the question of the next Australian High Commissioner to London? Is the photo on page 3 of yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser nothing more than a shameless ploy to induce Mr Major to appoint Mr Downer?

—You can tell when Christmas is approaching in this place. I do think that Mr Downer should be commended for the personal sacrifices that he undertakes to benefit certain charitable interests. Perhaps if more of us had the same courage, the charitable interests would do better.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note, Senator, that you have commended Mr Downer. How do you think the Indonesian government and other governments in the Asian region will react to this perspective of Australia's foreign minister?
—I am not too sure how many read the Adelaide Advertiser , I have to say. I am sure that if they do they would commend the courage of Mr Downer as well.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Can the minister explain how the recent decision to phase out analog mobile telephones has taken account of the interests of rural mobile phone users?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to phase out the analog service over the period up to the year 2000 was one taken back in late 1992 by the then Minister for Communications, Senator Bob Collins. You will recall by that time he had been pretty much pilloried by every editorialist and cartoonist in the country about the satellite licence fiasco. I think that one can also say that this was another example of a decision that was technology specific and a very dangerous thing to do in a deregulated environment, one in which new technologies are constantly appearing out of left field.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, the decision was taken. A lot of water has gone under the bridge since that time. The licence conditions attached for both Optus and Vodafone provided them with very clear entitlements, particularly insofar as any change might be applied by the government. It was not one that would be able to unduly erode the value of the carriers' rights. As far as Vodafone is concerned, their agreement specifically made clear that the government would proceed with the phase‐out. On that basis, they chose to roll out a dedicated digital service. Vodaphone's rights could only be taken away or affected by the minister with their approval.

It is against that background that, when we came into office, we carefully reviewed the implications of that decision and decided not only that might we expose the Commonwealth to claims for potentially hundreds of millions of dollars but also that it had gone too far down the track to reverse it. On that basis, we were particularly concerned to ensure that the interests of rural users were preserved. We were particularly conscious of the fact that Labor had shown no concern for the implications in rural areas.

Our policy approach will not abandon rural Australians. Instead, by the time we get to 1999, there will be a review of the phase-out and the progress that has been made according to the timetable we announced several months back.
