That review will determine what planned service areas should continue to receive a mobile telephone coverage either from GSM or any other technologies which might then be commercially available. On that basis, we will have an infinitely superior policy approach to that of the previous administration, which was simply concerned with blindly implementing technology specific decisions without regard for the interests of rural consumers. On the approach we have adopted, we will be ensuring that those who might otherwise find themselves at the mercy of a decision that might leave them altogether without coverage will not go uncared for. Our policy will ensure that rural communities will get a much better deal as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister whether the changes in the telecommunications regime which are to take effect from 1 July 1997 will increase the likelihood of mobile phone services being provided to those areas of Australia that do not currently have a service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —That will certainly be the case. There will be a number of new technologies coming on the market. From 1 July next year, when we have full and open competition, there will be the opportunity for many new services as well as competition to existing services to be available. We certainly expect that, as the profit margins reduce as a result of increased competition in urban areas, a number of the players will start to focus on meeting what I think is a significant level of unmet demand in rural areas. Certainly already we are seeing the building of cable TV networks or MDS systems in some regional or rural areas. That will certainly accelerate come 1 July next year.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also the very real prospect of some very significant new satellite based services, particularly the low earth orbiting satellites, or LEOS. There are already two major consortia: Iridium, headed up by Motorola, and Global Star, which is an international consortium. Each is prepared to spend several billion dollars. Gates and AT&T have a teledesic commitment as well. There should be plenty of opportunities for rural users. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General. Can the minister say whether any changes to bankruptcy laws will result in a diminishing of assets recovered by creditors? Can the minister further say whether any changes will reduce the capacity of bankrupts to have their bankruptcies annulled? Can the minister say whether any changes to the bankruptcy law will be made in accordance with a very erudite report from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee of which Senator Ellison is now chairman but of which, when this report was made, I was chairman?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cooney for the question. Obviously, one would not seek to introduce a change to bankruptcy laws that diminishes returns, but I will ask the Attorney what he has in mind and whether he has any information on that matter. I will happily recommend to him that he seriously consider the Legal and Constitutional Committee report which was made, as Senator Cooney rightly says, when he was chairman. I will ask him to give proper consideration to that, if he has not already done so. I would expect that he has already done so, so I do not imagine that I will have a long conversation with him. But I will do that and come back to you, as usual, as soon as I can.
—I draw the attention of senators to the presence in the gallery of former Senator John Button. We welcome your return to the Senate and trust that you have an enjoyable visit.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer the minister to a speech by the Leader of the Opposition to the National Farmers Federation at the 39th annual conference in Canberra on Tuesday, where the Leader of the Opposition alleged that the NFF has been blackmailed by the government into supporting the partial privatisation of Telstra. Is not the opposite the truth, where the NFF have recognised, like so many Australians did on 2 March and then followed by the Lindsay by-election, that the partial privatisation of Telstra is not only in the interests of rural Australia but in the national interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a classic example of why this other mob are so far behind at this time. They have no idea which way to go. The bitterness and angst that were obviously apparent from that bilious attack by the Leader of the Opposition clearly demonstrate that they are prepared to write off the bush in future. It is no wonder that we hold 31 seats in rural Australia. We will be able to hold a lot more if that is the attitude that their current leader continues to adopt.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite understandably, the NFF put out a press release very much repudiating that statement. The reason it really sticks in the craw of farmers as much as anyone else is the absolute hypocrisy in the position exemplified by Mr Beazley. He was the one in 1991 who promised Frank Blount that Telstra would be privatised. Mr Blount came to this country on a promise. He came here because not only Mr Beazley but Mr Keating—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—I have had this confirmed from people who worked in the offices of those ministers.
—Who? Name them.
—I am telling you, they are the three ministers. Once again, lap dog Lee was simply carrying out his master's voice obligation.
—Order! I think you should withdraw your manner of referring to a member of the other place.
—I accept that.
—No, I am asking you to withdraw.
—Mr Lee, the Prime Minister's acolyte—
—I ask you to withdraw the previous statement.

—I withdraw it. I have named them and I continue to name them. Mr Lee, Mr Beazley and Mr Keating all made solemn promises to Mr Blount that Telstra would be privatised. In other words, your mob knew that it had to be done in the national interest. You did not have the guts to pursue it at the union conferences or at the ALP national conference. You tried to tiptoe around it a bit, but you basically threw in the towel because you were not prepared to deliver the goods on micro‐economic reform.

ANSWER.PARA: Former Senator Button is appalled up there in the gallery. You can see that he knows the truth as well as everyone else, and he understands it better than most. That is why he ought to make a comeback, and we would give him leave right now. He understands that unless we get Telstra partially privatised then we will be about the only country in the world apart from North Korea which somehow believes in this mindless ideology.

That is why the National Farmers Federation is so incensed and appalled. That is why you have learnt nothing since the last election. You are simply not prepared to take the bush seriously. The NFF carried out a review and 66 per cent of people in the bush surveyed by the NFF said they supported partial privatisation of Telstra because they were very annoyed with the quality of the service they are getting right now. They knew that things could only improve if you went down that track. Why do you want to bash these people? Why do you hate the bush? Why won't you listen to what they are saying? They are saying that they are sick of your hypocrisy; they want you to pursue mainstream approaches on these important issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the environment.

—They understand the importance of the environment. They know that the billion dollar package is the best thing that they have ever had going for them and they want you to facilitate that. If you do not want to do it for your own selfish political interests, you pay the price. I told the Senate a few months ago what some of the leaders of the APEC economies said to me. They were simply appalled at the way in which the ALP was playing politics on an issue when they privatised almost everything else in sight during their term in office.
—Come on! Name them, Richard. Who?

—You would be amazed how many there were. I have not got time to name them all, but the fact is this: if any of that is untrue, get Mr Beazley, Mr Lee and, of course, Mr Keating—who could not be trusted on anything these days, or even earlier—to stand up in the parliament. Get Mr Beazley to stand up in the parliament and deny that he told Mr Blount that some four or five years ago, because you will not and he will not because you know it is the truth.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

Mr Naughten led a successful delegation of members from the Irish parliament to this parliament last year. He received a delegation from our parliament, led by Senator Watson, a few weeks ago. —I have further and very helpful information for Senator Schacht concerning his question to me today regarding the Australian government's attitude to the possible re-election of Dr Boutros Boutros‐Ghali. The answer is that Australia is not opposed to Dr Boutros‐Ghali serving a second term.
—`Not opposed'. Does that actually mean support?
—I thought you would appreciate that, Senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have further information to add to a question Senator Bourne asked me the other day concerning the meeting that got broken up in Malaysia and whether the Australian government had in fact advised intending participants of the Malaysian government's attitude to that meeting, which concerned East Timor. The answer is: no, the Australian government had not advised. It is our view that it is the responsibility of the responsible authorities in the country in which the meeting is being held to advise participants of its policy towards such a gathering.

QUESTION.PARA: I have been given numerous other examples of that information having been, in fact, brought to the attention of the participants by representatives of the Malaysian government, the press and others. I do not think it is necessary to add it to the public record, but I am happy to provide the information to Senator Bourne if she so wishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have further information on a question concerning Mr Max Moore-Wilton—in particular, whether his office had been refurbished since his becoming the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and, if yes, how much had any refurbishment cost. The answer is that the secretary's office has been recarpeted, repainted and had some minor repairs and maintenance done since Mr Max Moore-Wilton became secretary to the department. These changes were undertaken to an office which, since its construction in 1978, has had very little by way of upgrading or refurbishment. In the past 18 years the carpet was replaced only once, and that was in 1988. I am told that the total cost of the work undertaken in the office was just under $8,400 and that no work has been undertaken on the Sydney office used by Mr Max Moore-Wilton since his appointment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation in relation to an answer I gave on 10 October of this year to a question from Senator Calvert regarding the impact of employment levels in Tasmania as a result of proposals for the partial sale of Telstra. On that occasion I said, `Less than two per cent of jobs in Tasmania will become redundant in 1996-97.' I have since repeated that in good faith outside the chamber on at least one occasion that I can recall and it was certainly based on information provided to me by Telstra.

QUESTION.PARA: Yesterday it came to my attention that those figures looked to be quite inaccurate. I have since pursued the matter with Telstra and I would now like to read a letter into Hansard. It is addressed to me and is dated today. It states:
I refer to a response you made to a Question without Notice from Senator Calvert on 10 October 1996 in relation to Telstra planned staff reductions in Tasmania.

It has subsequently come to Telstra's attention that the answer provided understated the impact of proposed cost/staff reduction strategies in Tasmania. Telstra regrets that inaccurate advice had been provided to you on which you based your response and wishes to clarify the position.
The information previously provided did not include the Commercial and Consumer Group of Telstra.

The overall position for the 1996/97 financial year is that the total percentage of planned staff reductions in Tasmania is of the order of 8% of the total number of Telstra staff employed in the state as at the end of 1995/96. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Neal today, relating to private health insurance premiums.

I have to say that the entire response provided and the actions of this government to date on this whole issue are a ringing example of the deceit of this budget. This certainly is a lie that has come home to roost. The fact is that your lies, like vultures, will continue to gather and eventually those lies will tear apart this government because fundamentally the basis of this government is that it has entirely a lack of integrity in relation to this budget.

On budget day and since the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has affirmed that the private health insurance rebate will have some worth when it is introduced on 1 July next year. This is obviously not the case. At a total cost to this community of $600 million, the rebates for health insurance were brought in and they were meant to provide some benefit to the battlers of Australia. But obviously this is not the case.

Originally they were meant to give some relief to the huge premiums payable—$125 for single people, $250 for couples without children and $450 for families with children. But obviously this is not going to be the case because already this is the second round of increases not only since this budget measure was introduced but also since the Prime Minister referred the matter off to an inquiry and assured us that he would look with some askance at any applications by insurers to increase their premiums. But obviously the health insurance industry, like much of Australia, does not give much regard to what the views of the Prime Minister are, because despite his views as expressed the industry has applied for increases—and not just minor increases, but increases of between $190 and $240 for families with top cover insurance.

What does that mean? It means that, for couples without children, already some six months before these rebates come into effect the rebates are worth nothing. For those people who have children, substantially the rebates are of no value. So, if you look at it as a matter of logic, do you think the large proportion of Australians are going to believe that the expenditure of $600 million over four years will be money well spent when the vast majority of Australians are going to be worse off by 1 July with regards to the amount of money that they are paying for their private health insurance? I really do not think so.

When you look at the fact that they spend that amount of money in that area but they are cutting back in other areas of health, you really have to question the government's priorities and whether this government really understands what the priorities of the Australian people are. While the government is spending $600 million on a rebate that does not put money in the pockets of battlers but puts money into the pockets of those private health insurance firms, what is the government doing to the battlers? It is closing down 86 Medicare offices. That is what it is doing. What else is the government doing? It is taking approximately 400 doctors out of circulation, stopping them from getting provider numbers every year. It is cutting $3.12 million out of public hospital funding as a result of only this budget.

PARA.BREAK: The fact is that this government's priorities are wrong, and they are particularly wrong in terms of health. This government took money out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It introduced an additional charge of 50c for pensioners and an additional charge of $2.70 for non‐concessional cardholders for every script. It has cut funds to the Medicare sched ule. It has taken out $400 million over four years. They are not the right priorities; this is deceit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue taking note of this particular answer, or lack of answer, as is the usual case these days from government ministers. One of these days they will be able to answer a question in precise detail. They are certainly not able to at present.
—They will have to get their stockings on first.

—Yes, certainly fish‐net stockings seem to get into it as well. What we have seen is a paltry amount being offered to people to take out private health insurance. Before that comes into operation, we have seen increases in private health premiums that will erode just about the whole amount that is to be returned to people in the form of assistance. What would $125 assistance for single people buy in terms of private health insurance, private health insurance which would exempt people on higher incomes from having to pay an increased Medicare levy? One hundred and twenty five dollars does not buy very much. It might buy one or two months of basic cover for a single person. For a couple, it is $250. What does that buy? About the same. And $450 for a family! That would not even cover the basic premium for a single person.

SPEECH.PARA: The government obviously do not care. They say they believe in families and they talk about families being important, but when it actually comes down to it they do nothing. What does buying private health insurance mean for low income people? It buys them debt, because when you have private health insurance the doctors can charge you what they want—and they will charge way over and above the schedule fee and people will be paying the difference out of their pockets. That is what buying private health insurance means for people. It buys them bills; nothing more, nothing less.

People are going to have to find the money, first of all, to pay for the private health insurance, even with the rebate, because it will not cover anywhere near half of the amount they are going to be required to pay. Then every time they have to use it, they are going to be charged more money.

A lot of people say that this will encourage people into private hospitals. The occupancy rate of private hospitals has not declined; in fact, it has increased in recent years. Some people are choosing to go to private hospitals and they are choosing their method of payment. It might be a variation of self‐insurance, but they feel happier putting the $1,000, $2,000 or $3,000 a year that they would otherwise spend on private health insurance into a bank account and collecting the interest which they can then utilise themselves. They are making those choices and we have to be very aware of that.

To paint this as a method of caring for people is a very cruel and false thing to be doing. It is not really caring for people; it is just transferring. We hear a lot from this government these days about cost shifting. This is another example of cost shifting. This is shifting the obligation of the government to provide health care for all Australians onto the individual. It almost reeks of an implication that when people get sick it is their own fault. This is the whole tenor of the response and the program that the government is promoting. It is a really false and cruel thing to be doing to people, particularly when you see that it is making huge cuts to programs such as the Commonwealth dental health plan that are of great benefit to people on low incomes. If people have good dental health they also have good nutrition, they have an improved health status and they visit the doctor less. But that is not the way with this government.

We also see the government attacking pensioners by increasing their contribution under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, by 50c per prescription, with no commensurate increase in their pension rate, unlike what we always did. If there was an increase in such charges, we increased the pension to cover it. All these sorts of things that this government is undertaking show a government that does not care about average people and that is totally out of touch with the budgets and needs of the average person.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a point that Senator West made which I just cannot let go by without challenging. She said—she can correct me if I heard it wrongly—that, if you have private health cover, you have to find the money first, before you have the operation, and then claim it back later. Is that what you said?
—No, I didn't say that.
—You read Hansard and see if you didn't say it, Senator West.
—Perhaps you should.
—I shall certainly read Hansard and I suggest Senator West read it as well because that is not correct.
—But she didn't say that. Sit down.
—She said it. If I am wrong, I will apologise next time around, but that is how I heard it. You read Hansard and I will read Hansard .
—It is the balance.
—She knows as well as I do that you can have the operation, get your account from the doctor, claim your rebate and send a cheque with it for the balance. But that is not what you said.
—It is the balance that they have to pay.

—Of course it is the balance. Senator West said that you would have to find the money first. You read Hansard . She knows that is wrong and, if she does not know she is wrong, I am telling her she is wrong.

—With a contribution like that to add to our intelligence and insight, how could we go wrong? Heavy irony, Senator! What you do not know about health would fill volumes. What we know is that some interesting points have been made today. The premiums of private health funds have just rocketed again, making absolutely valueless, useless, your great promise of tax rebates to help people with the cost of private health insurance.

BREAK.PARA: The reason people used to take out private health insurance and why it was introduced was to protect people from big bills. The only way you get a medical bill now is if you have private health insurance. It is completely useless. Let me say it once again—you will not hear it, but I do not mind saying it once, twice or three times: the only way you get a bill in health these days is if you have private health insurance. It has been completely defeated in terms of what it was established for—to protect people from very large health costs that could cripple them or their families.

We now have a system that protects people completely from the costs of big bills. It is called Medicare. The only way you get a bill in the health area is if you have private health insurance. That is the principal reason. There are three reasons people have been leaving private health insurance. The first reason is the simplicity, equity, fairness and availability of Medicare. The second reason is that the only way you get a bill is if you have private health insurance. A lot of people have sat down and thought, `I can have this operation for no further outlay under the public system, or I can go into the private system and get a very big bill.'

If you have not seen the letters, I will tell you about the ones that I have received. `Dear Senator, for 30 years I have had private health insurance and have never really claimed against it. The other day I had to use it and now I have a bill of $3,000. How can I pay that back on my pension?' The answer is that they can not. That is exactly what they are saying to us.

The third reason people are dropping out of private health insurance is that the premiums continue to rise, and rise and rise. Mr Howard, not knowing the process, rushed to interfere. `Don't worry,' he said to the people of Australia. `I'll stop the tide of rising health premiums. I'll fix it. We'll have a little committee to inquire.' That was very foolish of Mr Howard, because what he discovered is that that is not how the process works at all.

The process is an estimate of costs and outlays and reasonable financial statements according to certain rules through the department, and it is no more than a rubber stamp by the minister for health. The Prime Minister has no capacity, short of changing legislation, to intrude in that at all. So big‐noting himself on the floor of the House of Representatives has meant that he has finished up with mud on his face, if not egg, because he got it wrong. He can do nothing to stop these latest increases. What they will do will contribute to more people leaving health insurance and therefore premiums having to rise even further.

Senator West has said very properly and very exactly that private hospitals have had increasing use, despite the introduction of Medicare. They said Medicare would be the ruination of them. Indeed, it is exactly the opposite. They still have spare capacity and are desperately looking for custom, and they have had increased use through the private hospital system. So you cannot say that the private hospital system is suffering, but you can say that the cost of private health insurance is now outside the reach of most people.

If people are sensible about private health insurance, they will make a choice not to buy it because it is so expensive and the one thing it guarantees them is a big bill. It is associated with doctor of choice and it is associated with more rapid access to a hospital bed. Under Medicare anybody in this country, privately insured or not, can get into a public hospital according to need and no other criteria. I find it very offensive that that is not the case in private hospitals.

Why should people have to wait a longer time when there is a bed available in a private hospital but no doctor prepared to operate on them for Medicare benefits only? That is the big scandal in this area. That is the scandal that should be addressed, not a cheap handout of $600 million as a straight tax give‐away for people to induce them to keep private health insurance. It is a very bad piece of government economy, and it is not working.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) today, to a question without notice asked by Senator Calvert on 10 October 1996, relating to the proposed partial privatisation of Telstra.

Today Senator Alston, 42 days after a dorothy dixer asked by Senator Calvert, explained that his information was wrong. What I find astonishing is that he asked Senator Calvert, clearly by prior arrangement, to ask a question saying that Senator O`Brien in his maiden speech was wrong about the employment numbers that would be affected by the privatisation of Telstra in Tasmania. We now have an explanation from Senator Alston saying that he was wrong and that, instead of it being two per cent loss of jobs in Tasmania as a result of privatisation, it is eight per cent—116 jobs would go in Tasmania rather than about 20 or 30.

In that answer he gave on 10 October, we had a minister arrogantly rolling around with the figures saying that the opposition was wrong. This was a question he set up for himself to have a go at Senator O`Brien's maiden speech. In three or four days he could have got the information from Telstra, yet it took 42 days to apologise to the Senate that he had it wrong.

This is not the first time the minister for communications has got employment figures wrong. In the estimates hearing, he claimed that since 1991 there had only been a few thousand job losses. Senator Carr demolished that. In the end, he had to disown even what his own office had put before the Senate in the estimates committee, saying, `That clarifying answer was not approved by me.' So he bagged one of his staff members. The next thing he will do is probably blame Telstra, as the letter was sent to him on 21 November, 42 days later.

It is astonishing that Senator Alston could get up in three days to bag Senator O'Brien and his maiden speech, but 42 days later Telstra sends him a note to clarify it. As I say, this is not the first time the minister has got his employment figures wrong in Telstra. The arrogance of this minister—he just blithely throws these off the cuff figures around the place as though they were accurate.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Alston will now blame Telstra for not telling him accurately, but he set the question up. He made Senator Calvert the dummy senator to ask this dorothy dixer so he could abuse Senator O'Brien. But 42 days later he has to apologise because he got it wrong. Senator Calvert was set up to ask the question—

TALK.START.PARA: —From Tasmania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —From Tasmania—to show that there may be only 20 job losses. In fact, eight per cent of 1,460 will mean that 116 jobs will go in Tasmania. The loss of 116 jobs in Tasmania will have a bigger impact than it would on a bigger city on the mainland of Australia. Senator Calvert ought to explain to the Tasmanian constituents that he was part of a minister's effort to mislead Tasmanians about job losses when the government privatises Telstra. He should apologise for this.

Leave granted.

Madam President, this bill will give legislative effect to an agreement entered into by the Commonwealth Government with the State of Victoria to return windfall tax associated with the announced settlement of a long running dispute between the Victorian gas utilities (GASCOR and GENVIC) and their gas suppliers (ESSO and BHP). The dispute concerned the ability of the producers to pass on to the Victorian utilities the impact of the Commonwealth's Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (PRRT).
The Commonwealth has long supported a negotiated settlement to the dispute as being in the best interest of both parties.
The agreement reached between the parties involves, among other issues, the Victorian Government making a payment to the producers of just over $1 billion to resolve the dispute.

A key element underpinning the agreement between the producers and the Victorian Government was the understanding that windfall tax arising from the $1 billion would be paid to Victoria through a payment to GASCOR. The settlement would not go ahead without this arrangement being put in place.

The Australian Taxation Office has determined that the settlement payment made to the producers is subject to both Company Tax and PRRT. This will involve a payment to the Commonwealth of an amount of tax of around $625 million. The Commonwealth has determined that approximately $555 million of that amount reflects windfall tax, that is, Approximately $70 million, representing tax payable on amounts previously unpaid by the gas utilities, but not relating to PRRT, will be retained by the Commonwealth and applied to the Budget deficit.

The genesis of this dispute dates back to the extension of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax regime to the Bass Strait, through the enactment of the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Legislation Amendment Bill 1991.

The act provided that PRRT was to apply on profits recovered from the Bass Strait permit area on or after 1 July 1990, replacing the existing excise and royalty regime. It was expected that the change in taxation arrangements to one based on taxable profits from a petroleum project rather than on production levels would encourage increased activity in the area. This in fact proved to be the case.

It was recognised at the time that the transition to a new taxation regime could cause changes to Victorian gas prices, with possible disruptive consequences for industry and domestic consumers. The then Government provided the Victorian Government with a special grant of $30 million for each of the first two years of application of the PRRT to minimise these transitional pressures.

However, what was not known by the Commonwealth at the time was that clauses in long-term gas supply agreements between the Victorian gas utilities and ESSO/BHP would give rise to a dispute about the ability of the producers to pass on the impact of the PRRT to the utilities. This dispute has been the subject of arbitration over a number of years.

It should be recognised that it has always been the intention that the PRRT should be a tax on above-normal profits (that is, profits over and above project expenditure and a threshold rate of return) associated with offshore projects and should not necessarily flow through to gas prices.

Given the unintended nature of the pass-on dispute, and in order to facilitate its settlement, the Commonwealth has indicated that it should not seek to benefit financially from this settlement. Hence this bill is intended to provide a mechanism to return the windfall tax flowing from the settlement. This should be seen as a fair and reasonable outcome for all parties.
The short time frame for consideration of this issue by the Parliament is unavoidable, given the sensitive nature of the complex negotiations.

The settlement has been structured so that a simultaneous exchange of cheques between GASCOR, ESSO/BHP, and the Commonwealth will be made on the payment day. However, if the payment to Victoria is not able to be made on the contracted day, the Commonwealth has agreed to pay to Victoria an additional amount reflecting interest accruing up to the actual payment date.

The agreement also puts in place a mechanism to ensure that should future events mean that the assessed tax payable on the settlement amount is changed, this will be reflected in a corresponding flow of funds between the parties. It is designed to ensure the Commonwealth would be no better or worse off under these circumstances.

The resolution of this dispute, in a manner acceptable to all parties is to be welcomed. Passage of this special appropriation bill will facilitate the settlement process. It is also expected that the resolution of this dispute will facilitate the opening up of gas markets in Victoria to the benefit of gas consumers.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains an explanation of the provisions of the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in 1997, in accordance with the order agreed to on 29 November 1994.

Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1996 SPRING SITTINGS
Payment of Tax Receipts (Victoria) Bill

The Commonwealth has entered into an agreement with the State of Victoria to pay to them, through their gas utility GASCOR an amount of windfall tax (both Company Tax and Petroleum Resource Rent Tax) arising from the settlement of a dispute between GASCOR (and the other Victorian gas utility GENVIC) and their gas suppliers.

This contractual agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria was signed by the Commonwealth and Victorian Treasurers on 20 November with the exchange of cheques scheduled for 29 November. The appropriation bill is necessary to appropriate part of the funds received into consolidated revenue on that day for payment to Victoria.
The passage of the bill is considered urgent to enable the transaction to be completed as scheduled on 29 November.

The need for the appropriation bill was unforeseen because of the ongoing negotiations between the parties and because the final form of the agreement, and hence the amount needing to be appropriated, was not known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) a major issue is the inequity of the government's budget program. First of all, the teacher professional development program has been cut by $17 million. This simply maintains the item at approximately the same level as last year's appropriation. In relation to teacher programs, teachers are under more pressure than others with government cuts, larger class sizes and so on. It does not make any sense to cut professional development in that way. It is not that the states are necessari ly going to have the extra money to provide that, because their funds are being cut as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Under environment, in relation to the costs of the Great Barrier Reef, the government is pulling money out of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, which does not make any sense considering the same government said that they want to protect the environment by seeing how many reef fish you can take out by not totally destroying the reef. To protect the Great Barrier Reef we want to maintain at least $1 million in funding. This measure is very mean spirited.

Under health, $15 million allocated to maintenance maintains funding at approximately the real level of last year's appropriation. There was a slight budgetary increase, but it is actually a real decrease in national health. In therapeutic goods, the government proposes effectively to reduce access to therapeutic goods. This is just maintaining the real dollar line.

What about the Commonwealth dental program? This is the administrative component, the running cost of the scheme found in Appropriation Bill (No. 1). We introduce it here because it was left out of the requests of other parties. We are happy to support the request for the dental program reinstatement from the other parties.

To reduce the waiting time for elective surgery, we would need an increase of $3 million. Once again, we have seen a mean-spirited proposal. If you are talking about such things as efficiency, you wonder how it might seem to the person who is having to wait longer on the queue.

Once again, what about reinstatement for the national health program, rehabilitation services, transport and regional development? In spite of all their rhetoric in terms of their commitment to regional Australia, this government has gutted funding for regional and local development. This is just a re-establishment of that level of funding.

The re-establishment of the national urban development program, once again, is important for equity and reducing oil dependency in relation to greenhouse reductions. I know this government is busy selling coal as fast as it can but, in fact, the international community is expecting Australia to pull up its socks and do better.

In relation to the integrated local area planning and coastal management, we have had another mean‐spirited response. We want to increase the funding by $1 million, which sets it at last year's level. For better urban design, we would need an increase of $10 million. Greenhouse effects, urban public transport and so on, we would need a $5 million increase.

Then there is the National Railways Commission. It makes no sense to cut railways when we are heading to what, I believe, is a petroleum crisis. This proposed increase brings it to last year's funding level. Last year's program may have terminated, but rail is important and should be substantially improved for energy and farming and mining and industry. If those are industries that you want to support, it does not make any sense to decrease the funding for railways.

Then there is the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. We have a lot of debates in here in relation to the quality of the work done by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. We are not going to be able to maintain that quality if we cut their funding. It will reduce their ability to do the work that they do.
So I commend the request for amendments to the Senate. Therefore, I move:

When a minister like the Assistant Treasurer makes an absolute goose of himself and bungles the passage of the appropriation bills for government, the opposition tends to look on this bungling with great generosity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, sit down, then!

—I will sit down after I have completed my contribution. The generosity of spirit that is demonstrated by this opposition has never been demonstrated by you in the short time that you have been in government for the last eight months, or certainly for the 13 years prior to your election in March. But if Senator Kemp—bozo that he is—the Assistant Treasurer, cares—
—Mr Bozo to you.

—All right; Senator Bozo. If he cares to get up, seek leave and ask for the question to be put again, the opposition will grant leave. But I have to say, Mr Chairman, it is time that this government and Senator Kemp, this incompetent Assistant Treasurer—come on back, Shorty. Come on down. We did not think it was possible, Senator Short, that you could be replaced with a more incompetent, ineffective minister, but John Howard has done it. John Howard has done it with Senator Kemp.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kemp can get up and seek leave—and, as far as the opposition is concerned, it is up to the minor parties and independents to consider their position—for this particular issue to be recommitted. I do not know what the fate of this division is likely to be. I will say to you that the opposition will grant leave for it to be put again. But, Senator Kemp, as far as this appropriations debate is concerned, enough incompetence from you is enough. It has been mishandled and mismanaged right from the start. There is a limit. There is a limit to the capacity of any senator and any opposition to try to dig you out of the holes that you manage to fall in regularly.

Senator Alston's sheer laziness and lack of attention to detail has just cost the government a division—has just ensured that a request has been carried in this chamber. You have got a lot of explaining to do to Mr Costello, haven't you, Senator Alston? We cannot dig you out of Senator Alston's incompetence, but we will try to dig you out of this. I say to you, Senator Kemp: try and get your act together.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has not been a great day.
—It has for us.

—I was, at least in relation to an earlier matter, able to point the finger elsewhere, but in relation to this particular matter my explanation is as follows. I was not conscious of the fact that the bells were ringing. I was not in my office; I was elsewhere. In fact, I was in discussions with one other and those discussions were such that I was effectively oblivious to the sound of any bells until—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it sounds like `Ripleys believe it or not' but I am asking you to believe it. The fact is that I became aware that the bells had been ringing the moment they stopped. I then immediately asked, `What bells were those?' and, of course, because the bells had stopped ringing, we were not able to tell. I was almost immediately put out of my misery by a phone call from my office advising me of what had transpired and I immediately returned to the chamber. I simply say mea maxima culpa. It was not my intention to be absent. It was pure misadventure.
—Didn't you have a pager?

—I did not have a pager. I did not even have a digital telephone in my back pocket. If it makes it easier, Mr Chair man, I will do my best to walk around with technology attached to me so that it does not happen again.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I can confirm that it has not been a great day for Senator Alston. Firstly, Senator Alston came in here after question time with his tail between his legs to indicate what I think was a very serious error that he made in the conduct of his ministerial duties in that he misled the Senate in relation to job losses in Telstra in Tasmania. He got it very badly wrong. The two per cent—according to Senator Alston—job losses, the 28 jobs in Tasmania, turn out in reality to be at least eight per cent job losses.
—The biggest in Australia.

—The biggest in Australia, with 116 workers affected—116 jobs. I want to say to Senator Alston at the outset that it has not been a great day for you, but it has not been great news for those workers in Tasmania either. I find Senator Alston's explanation that he was `oblivious to the sound of the bells' a little difficult to believe.
—Has it ever happened to you?
—No, it has never happened to me. I have never missed a division in the time that I have been in this chamber.
—Never?

—I have never missed a division in my time in the chamber, but it has happened to other senators. We can all run the gauntlet and suffer the misfortune of missing a division. So I take Senator Watson's interjection, because that is the fundamental point. On the last six occasions in this chamber that a senator from one of the major political parties has missed a division, five of those occasions have involved coalition senators—five out of six.
—Who was the other one?

—One out of six was a Labor senator. On each and every occasion that has occurred, including the life of this parliament, the Labor Party either in opposition or in government has taken the view that a vote should be recommitted. On the one occasion it happened that a Labor senator missed the division, what was the response from this mob on the other side?
—Miserable.

—It was miserable. It was basically as ungenerous and vindictive as you would expect. What the then Labor government had to do was go through a series of 12 divisions in this place to right the wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say to Senator Alston, Senator Hill, the current Manager of Government Business and the former Manager of Government Business, whom you had the good sense to dump, that that is not the way we do business. I hope that the pattern has become entrenched, with the opposition showing good sense in terms of the procedures and processes in this place. I hope in the future we will see the same approach if a Labor senator misses a division. And I note that it is more and more becoming the practice, depending on which side of the chamber they are voting, for the Democrats to be paired for a division. It is a perfectly reasonable demand from the Labor Party.

Let me say that this is not the spirit you have demonstrated in the past. It is not the way you do business. It is about time you thought very carefully in your own party room about some of those issues. I am pleased that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) from the other chamber has come in here to tell this mob how to run the show. He might not be much good over there, but he has to be better than the way this mob operates.

I make that as a very serious point to the government in terms of the way we do business and the way that they have done business in the past. It is a serious situation to have a vote recommitted because the Assistant Treasurer of Australia was on the telephone and did not believe it significant enough for the regional economic development program of the budget to be taken to a vote. That is what happened just now. It was not important enough for the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate to come into the chamber and vote on the cut to the Commonwealth dental health program for health card holders. I genuinely believe the cut to that program is without doubt the most despicable, the most contemptible, the most vicious and vindictive in this budget.

What we are talking about is administrative money and running costs. When we get to Appropriation Bill (No. 2), we will be able to deal with the substance of the program. This request before the committee at the moment is about running costs. I can assure the government that we are serious about the dental health program. We are serious about seeing the program reinstated for the disadvantaged, underprivileged and low income people in our community.

We are serious about the dental health benefits that this program delivers, and we are serious about proper process in this chamber. It is for that reason that, if Senator Alston rises to his feet to ask for leave for this particular matter to be recommitted, from the opposition's perspective we will grant leave. But I hope he and the government understand the spirit with which the opposition will grant leave.

I hope, Senator Alston, that you have found both your misleading of the parliament earlier in the day and this most recent experience of missing an important division in this place in the committee stage of the appropriation bills a sufficiently humiliating and humbling experience. I hope you will give some consideration to that experience in the way you and your colleagues on the front bench approach your parliamentary responsibilities.

It is for those reasons that the opposition will grant leave for this question to be put to the committee again, if Senator Alston asks for leave. But, let me say, we will be demanding, if and when an opposition senator or a senator paired with the opposition misses a division, which has happened once—out of the last six occasions we have had a senator miss a division—not to have the miserable response that we have had previously from the coalition. The Labor Party has had to right the wrong through 12 divisions. On the five occasions your side have dropped the ball, when your own team has let you down, you have been granted leave by the Labor Party.
Think about it. Think about the difference between the way we operate and the way you operate. Think about the difference between our respect for this parliamentary institution and yours.

PARA.BREAK: The first request relates to medical research institutes capital funding. Medical research institutes are important. Australia has a reputation for reasonably good medical research. This could be interpreted as an anti-intellectual campaign against research in education as well as an attack on the quality of health. National public health was de creased in real terms. This request maintains it. A further matter is reducing waiting times for elective services. Waiting time is an central issue in public hospitals. With a $3 million cut from Appropriation Bill (No. 1), this makes for a $23 million reduction in funding for reducing waiting time. It is not acceptable, and I do not think it will be acceptable to the general public.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of Medicare agreements and other health services, Medicare has never been a program favoured by the government. The reduction here will effectively result in increased costs for services for people on Medicare. A number of government initiatives are designed to make Medicare payments a base payment on top of which an increasing level of supplementary payments are added by doctors. Limiting doctors and limiting an increase in Medicare coverage creates pressure for doctors to move from bulk-billing to billing with top‐up payments that must be paid in full by patients, who then must take the receipts to the Medicare office to get a partial refund. It is the kind of thing that Senator Crowley was talking about today and which Senator Panizza found difficult to understand.

Another issue is referral services for women escaping domestic violence in rural and remote areas. Well, how mean can you get! We are asking for the funding to be maintained by $0.5 million. This service is an item where underspending has been common and where there seems to have been a general unwillingness to implement policies, and this means both governments. Unfortunately, domestic violence is on the upswing, particularly in rural areas, where it often results from isolation, a lack of employment and increasing difficulties and so on. We believe that it is entirely appropriate to maintain funding for this item. It is not a big ask.

In terms of the social housing subsidy program, we are asking for $3.5 million. We started to provide recurrent funding to the states for financing rental accommodation and shared equity programs for low and moderate income earners. Last year, the program was refocused to develop the policy of private sector leasing, which I disagreed with. It included schemes, such as in New South Wales, to buy and build 260 dwellings that would be used for community housing schemes. The government has cut this program and is pushing instead for private sector provision. I disagree with the move to private sector leasing on public housing. I do not think any moves to provide funding for community housing or rental housing for low income earners should be cut back.

Another issue is the implementation of the noise amelioration program for Sydney airport. That is fairly self‐explanatory. This maintains funding at the current level. The people of Sydney would be pretty ratted off that it is not being kept up to that level. In terms of the national mental health program, $30 million is being asked for. The mental health program has been discontinued. This is not appropriate at all, given the problems of mental health and the problems created when mental patients are pushed into halfway houses. We do not think the situation is acceptable. It is not acceptable for the government to terminate the national mental health program without replacement.

The residential care for older people program involves $2.5 million. This is simply another example of government attacking the most vulnerable sectors of the community. Our request is that the funding stay at least at the nominal level of last year's funding. The supported accommodation assistance program is within the crisis accommodation program. The supported accommodation assistance program has been designed for a range of people who would otherwise not be able to afford or have access to basic housing. I therefore ask the Senate to support our requests for amendment to Appropriation Bill (No. 2).

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Industrial Relations Commission and Australian Industrial Registry

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Hogg:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the last annual report of the Industrial Relations Court of Australia, although it may, in effect, be the second last because there may be a report in respect of these last few months. This court was a great initiative of the previous government. It was established on 30 March 1994 and it really has not had time to show to the limit the sorts of things it could have done. I am looking at the case notes of some of the cases that it has dealt with since it came into existence: the Tweed Valley Fruit Processors case, for example, and Christie v Qantas Airways Ltd, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It was, I think, good of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Campbell) the other day, when dealing with the industrial relations bill, to acknowledge that the judges of this court were of the foremost quality and that they had, in effect, performed their functions in a quite outstanding way. Fortunately, those judges will now go into the Federal Court. They were all members of that court and they will carry out their functions in that jurisdiction.

I noticed in the report that the retirements of Justices Northrop and Keely have been referred to. In recent times, they have turned 70 years old. They were quite outstanding judges and quite outstanding barristers when they were at the Victorian bar and I would like to acknowledge my respect, and no doubt the respect of the Senate and the parliament, for the work that they have done. Also, I notice that during the year there was appointed from the Victorian bar Justice Shane Marshall and Justice Anthony North—or Tony, as he was known—quite outstanding advocates and people who, had the court remained, would have proved great judges of the industrial court. I have no doubt that they will become great judges of the Federal Court.

I think the previous government showed great initiative in setting up this court. Senator Cook, who has had vast experience in the industrial area, would agree with me. He was a member of the cabinet that set up this court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was the minister at the time.

—A minister at the time. I think it was a wise decision and I think the decision to abolish the Industrial Relations Court is a sad and most unfortunate one. I think Senator Cook would agree that industrial relations and the judging of matters to do with industrial relations is a discrete area of the law and one that can best be advanced by judges who practise in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, it has gone now and I wish all the judges of that court great success in the future. I also mention Justice Peter Gray, and Justice Donnell Ryan, two people I was at the bar with, who are quite outstanding jurists and quite outstanding intellects.

We have been crossing the floor on votes all day and while we were over the other side I noticed a notice pointing out that Senator Patterson has her birthday today. In the true generosity that we show on this side of the chamber, you will no doubt join with me in wishing Senator Patterson all the best for her birthday. May she have many more of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to identify myself with the remarks of Senator Cooney with respect to this report. Senator Cooney has lauded the establishment of the Industrial Relations Court and, rightfully in my view, identified, acknowledged and praised the very fine work of many of the learned and distinguished judges who have sat on the bench of the industrial court. This was, as Senator Cooney said, an initiative of the former government. At the time that this court was legislated for, I had the honour of being the Minister for Industrial Relations and presented that legislation to the chamber.
—I am sorry I did not mention your authorship of this great initiative.
—Thank you, indeed. It was nonetheless I as the first person in the collective of the government who had the honour of doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important on this occasion to reflect just a little on some of the underpinning reasons why an industrial court, rather than an extended bench of the Federal Court, was the chosen format of the former government. One of those key reasons was touched on by Senator Cooney himself when he said that industrial law is a discrete practice of its own. It certainly is. If you blend it with all of the other responsibilities of the Federal Court, it would be wrong to automatically assume that the Federal Court's mind will not be as competent as that of an industrial court. I certainly do not make that allegation. The Federal Court is an extraordinarily competent jurisdiction. It is nonetheless true that over time judges sitting in this discrete area of law as an industrial court hone their sensitivities and knowledge of this area of law more expertly than will judges sitting in a wide jurisdiction such as the Federal Court.

The argument that has been put by those from the conservative side of politics—that industrial relations should not be treated separately but be part of the wide practice of law—is fallacious in the sense that the argument is often mounted as if industrial relations were just another part of trade or industry or corporate law. It is not. Industrial relations is not just a mechanistic operation. It involves people in the workplace interacting together and disputes arising with very potent legal implications between them.

I do not think you can practise industrial law with the same mind‐set as would be brought to other areas of the law, for the very sound reason that the human factor is a much more potent consideration here than it might be in other areas where the dispassionate mind of a bench can direct itself. So I think there is an extremely good case to have a bench dedicated to this field of legal practice. I do think not immediately but over the longer haul the ability of Australian jurists to come to grips with some of the underpinnings of industrial relations will weaken, and that will make the nation weaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your initiative will be proved right; there is no doubt about that.

—Thank you for that interjection, Senator Cooney. We are now embarking on a voyage of discovery in Australia with the new industrial relations act. Many things have been claimed for this act. Very few things about those claims are proven. A lot of those things claimed are theoretical. They do not have any basis in practical experience. It is at that very time that you will need a bench able to thread its way through the complexity of this field of jurisdiction and across the precedent more than any other.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is at this time that I join with Senator Cooney in lamenting the passing of the Industrial Relations Court. I commend, as he has done, the very fine efforts of those who have graced its benches over the years and wish them well in the new jurisdiction of the Federal Court. (Time expired)

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Dangers of Radioactive Waste entitled No time to waste . I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE DANGERS OF RADIOACTIVE WASTE

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that in order to conform with international standards on separating the regulatory body from the regulated industry, the Australian Institute of Radiation Protection as proposed regulator should have no substantive operational functions or commercial activities in nuclear science (Paragraph 2.88).

The Government notes this recommendation. The Government is currently considering proposals for an independent body for the regulation and licensing of nuclear and radiation related activities of Commonwealth agencies including the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO). This may take the form of an Australian Institute for Radiation Protection (AIRP) formed by merging the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL) and the Nuclear Safety Bureau.

The Committee recommends that the Minister responsible for the proposed Australian Institute of Radiation Protection be required to act to ensure that the administrative arrangements avoid conflicts of interest (Paragraph 2.90).
The Government notes this recommendation.

The Committee recommends that the Government should structure the proposed Australian Institute of Radiation Protection to maintain an arm's length relationship with the industry as far as possible having regard to international best practice, and the industry be required to provide the information the regulator needs to perform its functions (Paragraph 2.94).
The Government notes this recommendation.
The Committee recommends that the proposed Australian Institute of Radiation Protection structure should include appropriate community representation (Paragraph 2.99).
The Government notes this recommendation. Current proposals for an Australian Institute for Radiation Protection include provision for community representation.

The Committee recommends that the proposed Australian Institute of Radiation Protection legislation should include a provision to the effect that `any person may take action in court to restrain a breach of this Act' (Paragraph 2.102).

The Government does not accept the recommendation which it considers excessive given existing established appeal provisions (including through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act). The Government will ensure that future deliberations concerning the roles and functions of the proposed AIRP will include consideration of appropriate appeal mechanisms.
The Committee recommends that the Government review current procedures for developing national guidelines to ensure that they are prepared in a more timely manner (Paragraph 2.111).

While acknowledging Australia's good track record on implementing agreed international standards, the Government accepts this recommendation and will review the consultative process between the Commonwealth, States and Territories, other interested parties and the public, to ensure the timely development and promulgation of national guidelines.

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth together with the States and Territories should act to expedite revision of national codes and development of a nationally agreed regulatory scheme (Paragraph 2.111).

The Government notes this recommendation and points out that a suitable consultative structure already exists through the Radiation Health Com mittee, which facilitates the Commonwealth, States and Territories developing and adopting codes of practice and guidelines uniformly across Australia in a timely manner. The Committee is a consultative body comprising Commonwealth, State and Territory representatives and others appointed for their expertise. The Committee covers the matters within its responsibility very effectively.

The Committee recommends that Commonwealth regulation of Commonwealth bodies under the proposed Australian Institute of Radiation Protection legislation should conform to a nationally agreed scheme (Paragraph 2.111).

The Government notes this recommendation and notes the Committee's view that it is important that, to the maximum extent possible, outcomes of regulation in Australia should be compatible across jurisdictions.

The Committee recommends that the Australian Customs Service should consult with the Australian Radiation Laboratory and the State and Territory radiation authorities to develop better procedures for recognising radioactive imports and for co‐ordinating licensing procedures (Paragraph 2.121).

The Government accepts this recommendation in principle, but does not accept the underlying proposition that administration of the current control regime is significantly deficient. Furthermore, proposed consultations with State and Territory agencies should be undertaken, in the first instance, by their Commonwealth counterpart, the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL).

The information referred to in the Report provides no sound evidence of deficiencies in Australian Customs Service processing of goods subject to this control. The radiographic inspection system and thickness gauge probe that were cited in the report as examples of imports that were incorrectly cleared by Customs, were dealt with in accordance with the relevant legislative requirements.

There has been and continues to be considerable liaison between the Australian Customs Service and ARL regarding administration of Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulation 4R. ARL has ongoing liaison arrangements with its State and Territory counterparts.

The indication that Customs officers are unaware of the type of goods that may contain radioactive materials is incorrect. Customs targets a wide range of radioactive materials, and goods containing radioactive materials, based on extensive lists and computer profiles developed in consultation with ARL. In excess of 30 000 importations covered by Customs Entries have been targeted in the last four years. Although it is practically impossible to ensure that every potential infringement of any regulatory regime is prevented by the relevant law enforcement agency, Customs' current arrangements for administering this control are appropriate and effective.

The Committee recommends that an up to date inventory of all existing and potential radioactive waste be prepared and that this be maintained to detect any changes to the current accumulation rates (Paragraph 3.51).

The Government accepts the recommendation in principle. Planning for national waste management facilities would benefit from the most comprehensive information available on radioactive waste holdings. Accordingly the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has already approached State and Territory Governments for updated information on radioactive waste holdings within their jurisdiction. However, as the Committee acknowledges, some States are more advanced than others in recording this information. In view of jurisdictional issues the Commonwealth can do no more than exhort State and Territory Governments to provide updated information.

The international Convention on the Safety of Radioactive Waste Management currently being drafted contains clauses that will require signatories to the Convention to provide details of radioactive waste inventories.
The Committee recommends that the transportation of significant amounts of radioactive materials should require an assessment of the most appropriate transport mode (Paragraph 5.20).

The Government accepts the recommendation and notes that these arrangements already exist. Transport of radioactive materials within Australia is controlled by the requirement that the consignor adheres to the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances 1990 which requires notification between relevant competent authorities of the mode of shipment where the quantities are significant.

The Committee recommends that State governments and local councils en route should be fully notified of the route and contents of radioactive waste consignments and should be given sufficient practical knowledge to be able to devise and implement contingency plans (Paragraph 5.21).

The Government accepts the recommendation in principle. Transportation of significant amounts of radioactive materials should require consultation with appropriate State and Territory Government agencies and an assessment of the most appropriate transport mode in line with the relevant codes of practice. This consultation accords with current practice, however, it takes place with State and Territory Government agencies rather than local government councils as the relevant expertise and responsibility for contingency plans rests with the State authorities rather than with councils.

Transport of radioactive material has been practiced with a high level of safety internationally and within Australia for many years. There are well developed internationally accepted codes of practice for the safe transport of radioactive material by land, sea and air. These codes of practice are updated periodically and endorsed by international organisations such as the International Atomic Energy Agency, the International Maritime Organisation, the International Air Transport Association and the International Labour Organisation. The codes include requirements for consultation. Australia has adopted these international codes of practice for the transportation of radioactive material.
The Committee recommends that a feasibility study be conducted into the suitability of disposing of the low level contaminated soil from Fishermans Bend in an active uranium mine (Paragraph 6.102).

The Government accepts the recommendation. Studies of drums of contaminated soil from Fishermans Bend show that the radioactivity in this material is from uranium ore and tailings diluted with natural soil. Accordingly, it would be appropriate to consider disposal of all of this material at an operating uranium mine subject to confirming the cost, operational feasibility and safety of such an operation.

The Committee recommends that a feasibility study be conducted into disposing in an active uranium mine of that portion of the ANSTO waste that is suitable for disposal at a municipal tip (Paragraph 6.103).

The Government accepts the recommendation on the basis that the feasibility study also covers possible disposal at a municipal tip. Disposal of suitably classified radioactive waste with municipal waste is an accepted practice in many countries. Some jurisdictions in Australia also allow disposal of certain radioactive waste in municipal tips in accordance with the National Health and Medical Research Council Code of Practice for the Disposal of Radioactive Wastes by the User (1985).
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government ascertain the extent to which the States and Territories could benefit from disposal of low level wastes in uranium mines (Paragraph 6.105).

The Government accepts the recommendation. The interest of State and Territory Governments in this proposal will be canvassed through the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee on Radioactive Waste Management.
The Committee recommends that appropriate maximum emission levels as well as average monthly limits be imposed on emissions of tritium and iodine 131 from ANSTO (Paragraph 6.120).

The Government does not accept the recommendation. The annual doses resulting from all gaseous emissions are very low and well below the internationally agreed limits of 1 mSv and the dose constraint adopted by ANSTO of 0.3 Msv for members of the public. At these very low levels, any health impact depends only on the total quantity of radioactivity emitted and not on its rate of emission.

Appropriate discharge limits already apply to effluent discharges from the Lucas Heights Science and Technology Centre. The discharge monitoring process and compliance with limits is audited by the Australian Radiation Laboratory (ARL) and is expected to be the subject of a licence agreement with the proposed Australian Institute for Radiation Protection.

ANSTO has been required to comply with monthly discharge limits for liquid effluent discharges to the sewer since connection to the sewer in 1980. Since that time liquid effluent discharges have had to comply with maximum concentration limits specified in the NSW Radioactive Substances Regulations 1959 under the terms of a trade waste agreement with the then Water Board and its successor Sydney Water Corporation. Since September 1995 the discharges have also had to comply, at the Cronulla Sewage Treatment Plant, with the radionuclide reference activity levels based on the World Health Organisation Drinking Water Guidelines (1993).

Airborne emissions from all stacks at ANSTO are continuously monitored and assessed, against weekly operational levels for each stack and the maximum annual public dose limit recommended by the International Commission on Radiological Protection and adopted by the National Health and Medical Research Council. The use of an annual dose limit for site‐wide airborne discharges was accepted by the then NSW Radiological Advisory Council.
The Committee recommends a national above ground storage facility be established which has the capacity to take low, intermediate and high level radioactive waste (Paragraph 7.18).

In recommending a single facility, the Committee seems to confound the particular and exclusive requirements for safe storage of the various categories of radioactive waste. Nevertheless, the Government accepts in principle the recommendation of a storage facility for long lived intermediate level waste (Category S waste) which is not suitable for near‐surface disposal. This would include waste to be returned from reprocessing of Australian research reactor fuel at Dounreay (Scotland). Establishment of such a facility will be raised in the Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee on Radioactive Waste Management to assess the extent of State and Territory support for the proposal.

For low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste, international standards and practice clearly indicate that near‐surface disposal is appropriate rather than storage as recommended by the Committee. Accordingly, the Government intends to proceed with the study commenced by our predecessors to identify a disposal site for low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste. The study will also consider the proposal that this repository be co‐located with an above ground storage facility for long lived intermediate level waste in order to secure the benefits of shared infrastructure.

In recommending above‐ground storage of all categories of radioactive waste (Recommendation 17 and Paragraphs 6.47 and 6.57), the Senate Committee has given considerable weight to the hope that technology will be developed for destruction of radioactive materials. Transmutation may eventually be possible in the context of high level actinide wastes from the reprocessing of spent nuclear power reactor fuel. However, it is unrealistic to expect this technique to be applied to low‐level wastes. In any case, transmutation still results in some radioactive tails being produced.

There is also evidence in the Committee's report of confusion between "disposal" and "storage" of radioactive waste. For example the Committee contends that: "The international nuclear community has been unable to come up with an answer on how to dispose of radioactive waste other than that classified as exempt" . This is patently incorrect. Many near‐surface disposal facilities for low‐level and short‐lived intermediate level wastes are operating overseas at present as acknowledged by the Committee (Paragraphs 6.69, 6.73, 6.74). One is currently operating in Western Australia.

Unnecessary storage of radioactive waste rather than disposal imposes an unnecessary burden of management on future generations. The International Atomic Energy Agency's Safety Fundamentals include the principle: "Radioactive waste shall be managed in such a way that will not impose undue burdens on future generations." Safe disposal of radioactive waste is the management approach that best satisfies this fundamental principle.
The Committee recommends that the national facility be adequately engineered to withstand all possible climatic conditions, no matter how unlikely (Paragraph 7.35).
The Government will ensure that there is a thorough safety assessment of national radioactive waste management facilities.

The Committee recommends that the public, particularly the local community, should be involved in consultation on the construction of a national storage facility and the transport arrangements to any such facility (Paragraph 8.62).

The Government accepts the principle of consultation with the public, particularly the local community, in relation to the construction and operation of national radioactive waste management facilities. Public comment has been an important element in phases 1 and 2 of the national radioactive waste repository siting study and will be applied to further phases of this study.

The Committee recommends that a management committee for the facility be established including an equal number of representatives from the local community and the users of the national storage facility, together with a representative from the Australian Institute of Radiation Protection and one from the relevant State or Territory authority. This Committee should oversee the design, construction and management of the facility (Paragraph 8.63).

The Government accepts the need to establish a broadly representative management committee in relation to all national radioactive waste management facilities. The principles of involvement of the public and State and Commonwealth scientific experts have been closely adhered to in the national radioactive waste repository siting study and will be applied to further phases of this study.
