The Committee recommends that the managers of the national storage facility be required to produce an annual report to Parliament (Paragraph 8.64).

The Government agrees in principle with the recommendation. The Government will take into account the recommendations on reporting procedures in the National Health and Medical Research Council Code of Practice for the Near Surface Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Australia (1992). The Government recognises the need for adequate reporting on the operation of national radioactive waste management facilities.

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government establish a Committee with representatives from a cross section of relevant bodies to recommend the allocation of research funding for radiation issues. The Committee could comprise representatives from the Australian Institute of Radiation Protection, the National Health and Medical Research Council and Commonwealth authorities, State and Territory authorities, the academic community and industry with relevant expertise (Paragraph 9.22).

The Government notes the recommendation to establish another committee. The Government endorses the principle that decisions on research funding for radiation issues should be made by a group with broad representation.

In preparing its response to the Senate Select Committee Report the Government has taken into account the dissenting report by Senators Bell and Margetts. The Government considers that the dissenting report exaggerates the potential hazards presented by the radioactive waste produced in Australia and takes an unduly pessimistic view of management options for this material.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Dangers of Radioactive Waste, I wish to note the government response and to particularly note that the overwhelming majority of recommendations made by the select committee have been accepted by the government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Dangers of Radioactive Waste. It is at least pleasing to see that the government have noted a lot of the recommendations. They have not thrown them out of hand but will consider a number of the recommendations. There are still some unsatisfactory responses, and that includes the important recommendation No. 17 that a national above‐ground storage facility be established with the capacity to take low, intermediate and high level radioactive waste.

SPEECH.PARA: My personal view in relation to storage facilities was mentioned in the dissenting report that was signed by former Senator Bell. I was not of the opinion that there should be a national repository. I thought it would be more appropriate to have state based, locally based or in situ based properly designed facilities. While we still do not know how to handle radioactive waste, we certainly cannot dispose of it.

The government accepts in principle the recommendation of a storage facility for long lived intermediate level waste which is not suitable for near surface disposal. It would seem that they are looking at that for waste such as that to be returned from reprocessing of Australia's research reactor fuel at Dounreay. I certainly would not like to see us burying that. I think it would be correct to say that we should have an above‐ground, properly engineered facility for that.
But the government response states:
For low level and short‐lived intermediate level radioactive waste, international standards and practice clearly indicate that near‐surface disposal—
for which read `burial'‐
is appropriate . . .
Low level does not necessarily mean short term. So you have low level and short lived intermediate level radioactive waste.

One of the problems that came out during the inquiry was that a lot was lumped in together in relation to radioactive waste. In fact, most of what the government considers as waste in Australia is classified as low level and short lived intermediate level radioactive waste. So, with the exception of the waste that we will get back from the fuel rods from Dounreay—lucky us!—it seems that they are still talking about digging a hole and burying most of the rest.

I do not consider that that is properly engineered. In Esk in Queensland they do have a facility which is engineered. It cost them a few million dollars—not a huge amount of money—but it is monitored and regularly controlled. They do seem to have taken a great deal of care to try to get the community involved in the process. I would not say that all of the community are thoroughly enamoured of the idea, but at least they have worked on dealing with the level of community concern.

I do not think a dollar‐driven approach to dealing with radioactive waste—which is what this seems to be at this stage—is ever going to meet community approval anywhere in Australia. I know that, during some of the hearings, one community group said, `Don't worry, we don't want it, but Western Australia does.' I can guarantee you that the vast majority of the community in the goldfields does not.

This is partly due to the fact that there is this assumption that when radioactive waste is out of sight it is out of mind. The people who would like to make money out of accepting radioactive waste are certainly not going to be around for the thousands upon thousands of years that that radioactive waste stays active. They are certainly not going to have to deal with it. They may think that, if they dig a hole and put trees on the top, people will forget that it is there after a while. Perhaps they will, but it will still be there. We have not yet found ways of dealing with it.
I am also disappointed to see that recommendation 18 states:
The Committee recommends that the national facility be adequately engineered to withstand all possible climatic conditions, no matter how unlikely.

I do not think that is an unreasonable thing. At a time when there is a growing consensus about climatic change, you should not, for instance, choose an area in what is generally an arid zone and engineer the facility working on the assumption that the area is arid.

Even the goldfields area in Western Australia, often considered a target point for governments wanting to get rid of waste of all sorts, cannot be guaranteed to be arid. They have had some quite substantial rainfall events within the last two years. They may have been one in 100 year events, but two or three occurred in the last year. The indications are that there is a band of rainfall which is more likely to happen in areas like the goldfields due to climatic change.

So the committee was asking that you do not go just on the law of averages and say, `This place is generally arid, let's produce a facility and engineer it for what we would like to think it might generally be.' I do not think that is smart and I do not think that is meeting the needs of the community. Heavy rainfall and floods do occur around the goldfields from time to time, as Senator Panizza would know.

If you wanted to get the community on side, the way to do it is not by saying, `We will engineer this facility on the assumption that this is an arid area.' I am not offering the goldfields in any manner, way or form. Although the government continues to say that it is going to ensure a thorough safety assessment, it is not making people feel very assured at the moment considering it is still saying things like, `"Adequately engineered" means we looked for an area which is distant from large communities and has an arid climate.' I do not think that is acceptable to the people living in those areas and I do not think that it is an acceptable method of risk assessment, especially in a time when there is ample and growing evidence of climatic change.
I would like to mention briefly another point. The government's response devotes an entire five lines to the not insubstantial dissenting report. It does not deal with the issues—it just says:
. . . the dissenting report exaggerates the potential hazards presented by the radioactive waste produced in Australia and takes an unduly pessimistic view of management options . . .

It does not deal with the issues. It does not deal with the points. It does not answer my concerns nor those of former Senator Bell and the great number of people who gave written and oral evidence to the inquiry. I find that very disappointing and I will follow up with questions to the relevant minister to find out why such an inadequate response to those serious concerns was considered to be appropriate in relation to such an important issue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade entitled Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma and seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

The Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade tabled its report Human Rights and Progress towards Democracy in Burma in October 1995. The Australian Government's response to the recommendations of the report follow.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to ratify the major human rights covenants, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and the International Covenant on Economic and Social Rights (ICESCR).

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

Accession to the major international human rights instruments, including the ICCPR and ICESCR, represents a substantial commitment by member states to the promotion and protection of fundamental human rights. Australia has strongly encouraged universal ratification of human rights treaties as the best means of securing the implementation of established human rights standards. At the World Conference on Human Rights in Vienna, Australia promoted the inclusion of appropriate language in the Vienna Declaration and Program of Action on the importance of universal ratification. Australia has also supported United Nations efforts to promote universal ratification by co‐sponsoring appropriate resolutions at the UN General Assembly (UNGA) and UN Commission on Human Rights (CHR).

In the specific case of Burma, Australia is a traditional co‐sponsor of resolutions on human rights in Burma adopted by both UNGA and CHR which specifically call on the Government to ratify ICCPR, ICESCR as well as the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman and Degrading Treatment or Punishment (CAT).
In an apparent response to international pressure, including that of Australia, Burma has now withdrawn the reservations it had entered concerning the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

On a bilateral level, the Ambassador in Rangoon has made a practice of taking all appropriate opportunities to urge the Government of Burma to ratify the major human rights covenants, stressing the importance Australia and the international community accord these instruments. Australia has made representations on the importance of treaty ratification to a number of countries in the region in the context of promoting greater effectiveness of the human rights treaty system. Further bilateral representations in Burma and other Asia Pacific countries on universal ratification of key UN human rights instruments are being planned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to relinquish government control over the media and to encourage a free and vigorous press, in compliance with the recommendations of the UN Special Rapporteur.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

Australia strongly supports multilateral human rights mechanisms such as Special Rapporteurs appointed by the UN Commission on Human Rights to investigate specific country situations such as Burma, and encourages the countries concerned to abide by the provisions of these mechanisms.

Australia is a traditional co‐sponsor of resolutions on human rights in Burma adopted by both UNGA and CHR which specifically call on the Government of Burma to promote and protect fundamental human rights including the right to freedom of expression.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government should urge the Government of Burma, in accordance with its obligations as a member of the UN and using the UN human rights conventions as a framework to:
(a) include within its new constitution specific guarantees for the protection of the rights to freedom of expression, religion, association, assembly and the press; and

(b) repeal all laws which prohibit free association and particularly the free participation in the political life of the country (SLORC orders 2/88, 4/91, the 1950 Emergency Provisions Act, the 1957 Unlawful Associations Act, the 1962 Printers and Publications Act and the 1975 State Protection Law.)

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

At the multilateral level, Australia is a traditional co‐sponsor of resolutions on human rights in Burma adopted by both UNGA and CHR which reaffirm Burma's obligation to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms as stated in the Charter of the United Nations and elaborated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Covenants on Human Rights and other applicable human rights instruments. These resolutions refer specifically to the need to ensure that these principles are respected in the drafting of the new constitution. In multilateral forums, Australia continues to promote the need for Burma to adopt as a fundamental principle constitutional guarantees for the promotion and protection of fundamental human rights as set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Australia has co‐sponsored successive resolutions adopted by CHR and UNGA which urge the Government of Burma to enable all citizens to participate freely in the political process in accordance with the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The Australian Government will continue to directly urge the Government of Burma to respect the rights to freedom of expression and association and to ensure that these rights are included in the constitution that is currently being formulated in the National Convention. It should be noted that the principles being drafted by the National Convention do include provisions providing for some of these freedoms, although, given the current pace of the Convention's deliberations, it may be some time before these principles become law.

The importance of freedom of expression and political openness have been prevalent themes in discussions between the Governments of Australia and Burma. The Australian Government will continue to express its view that it is through open and genuine dialogue between the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC), the National League for Democracy (NLD), the other political parties and ethnic groups that the political aspirations of the people of Burma are best addressed. This message is, and will remain, a central feature of our dialogue with the Government of Burma at Ministerial and officials level. It is important that Burma's political development occurs in an atmosphere that permits freedom of expression and political organisation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to ensure that all trials are conducted according to internationally accepted standards of justice—that they are open and accessible, that all defendants have counsel of their choice, and that sentences are commensurate with the offence.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

At the multilateral level, Australia is a traditional co‐sponsor of resolutions on human rights in Burma adopted by both UNGA and CHR which reaffirm Burma's obligation to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms as stated in the Bill of Rights and other human rights instruments including the right to equality before the law, to a fair and public hearing by an independent and impartial tribunal, to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of a defence and to communicate with counsel of the defendant's own choosing.

Bilaterally, the Australian Embassy in Rangoon has consistently made known to the Government of Burma and its judicial organs Australian concerns about the judicial process in individual cases, and has confidentially briefed the UN Special Rapporteur and media representatives on developments in such cases. Representations have been made to the Burmese Government by the Embassy in a number of specific cases.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to:
(a) ratify the Convention Against Torture and Cruel, Inhuman and Degrading Treatment or Punishment (CAT);
(b) eliminate from its prisons all practices involving physical abuse or torture;
(c) institute proceedings against all officials guilty of the abuse of prisoners;
(d) give training to prison officers, police and military personnel in the standards expected of such personnel in the human rights instruments and humanitarian law; and
(e) allow representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross full, private access to prisoners in Burmese gaols.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed
Comments made under Recommendation 1 apply to part (a) of this recommendation.

The resolutions adopted by the UNGA and CHR, which Australia co‐sponsors, make specific reference to the need to ensure the physical integrity of prisoners and to eliminate the practice of torture. The resolution on Burma adopted by the 51st session of the Commission on Human Rights has a specific clause reminding the Government of its obligation to put an end to the impunity of perpetrators of violations of human rights, its responsibility to investigate alleged cases of human rights violations, to bring them to justice and to prosecute and punish those found guilty (1995/72, operative paragraph 12).

CHR resolution 1995/72, which Australia co‐sponsored, makes specific reference to measures which have been taken by the Government of Burma in co‐ordination with the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) to provide training of military personnel in international humanitarian law, and requests it to intensify its efforts in that regard and to extend them to police and prison personnel. In an apparent response to pressure by the international community, Burma has ratified the Geneva Conventions, and the ICRC has undertaken a series of training programs to sensitise the Burmese Armed Forces to the implications of this action.

While these are encouraging developments, the Australian Government recognises that there is considerable scope for much greater activity in this area. We will continue to urge the Government of Burma to develop policies and programs, with the assistance of international agencies, that will further educate relevant officials in humanitarian law.

Australia has strongly and repeatedly urged the Burmese Government to agree to providing the ICRC full, repeated and confidential access to prisoners in all Burmese gaols. It is a co‐sponsor of UNGA and CHR resolutions urging the Burmese Government to co‐operate fully with the ICRC.

The Australian Government was disappointed to learn in June last year that negotiations between the ICRC and the Government of Burma on access to political detainees by the ICRC broke down after several years of discussion. The ICRC stated that the reply it received from the SLORC to its offer of services was "not satisfactory, as it took no account of the customary procedures for visits to places of detention followed by the ICRC in all the countries where it conducts such activities." On receipt of this response the ICRC informed the Government of Burma that it acknowledged the failure of the negotiations and would close its office in Rangoon in July 1995. The ICRC said that "it was prepared to resume the dialogue on a constructive basis as soon as the Myanmar authorities invited it to do so."

The Australian Government registered with the Government of Burma, through its Embassy in Rangoon, its strong disappointment with the failure of the negotiations and its hope that the negotiations would resume and reach a satisfactory conclusion that permitted the ICRC access to prisons. We understand that while agreement on access has not been reached, the Government of Burma has not ruled out the possibility of agreement and there is scope for negotiations to resume. The Australian Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to resume negotiations with the ICRC.

The Australian Government will also continue to make bilateral representations about specific detention cases. In July 1996, for example, Mr Downer expressed concern to Burmese Foreign Minister, U Ohn Gyaw, about the circumstances surrounding the death in incarceration of Leo Nichols, a high‐profile democracy activist and political prisoner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to:
(a) bring the conduct of its military officers into compliance with accepted standards of behaviour in accordance with the Geneva Conventions and the international human rights conventions;
(b) take proceedings against members of the military guilty of arbitrary killing, rape or the beating of civilian porters or villagers; and
(c) control the military to ensure that there is no confiscation of property.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

CHR resolution 1995/72, which Australia co‐sponsored, acknowledges measures which have been taken by the Government of Burma in co‐ordination with the ICRC to provide training of military personnel in international humanitarian law, and requests it to intensify its efforts in that regard and to extend them to police and prison personnel.
Australia has consistently raised specific allegations of gross human rights violations by the military with the Government of Burma and urged that they be brought to a halt.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to:
(a) comply with the standards it has agreed to under the Geneva Conventions, in respect to the treatment of civilians during armed conflict, and under ILO Convention 29 in relation to forced labour;
(b) institute the necessary legal changes to the Village Act and the Town Act to prevent the continuation of the practice of forced labour in Burma;
(c) agree to the provision of expert advice by representatives of the ILO for the institution of improved laws and systems relating to labour practice in Burma; and

(d) comply with the requests of the ILO Committee on the Application of Standards to institute new laws relating to the existence of free trade unions in Burma—allowing the formation of unions independent of the government, the right of workers to join unions of the own choice, the right to strike and the release of union officials currently in prison for union activity sanctioned under ILO Convention No 87.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

Representations on forced labour and use of civilian porters have been central themes of the bilateral dialogue between the Government of Australia and the Government of Burma. The Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to fully comply with its obligations under the Geneva Convention and to comply with the requests of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Committee.

As the Committee's report indicates, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade informed the Committee by supplementary submission in August 1995 that the Government of Burma issued a directive in July last year that the use of forced labour at the village/township level was to cease and that all projects were to be carried out with paid labour. While it is difficult to assess accurately the extent to which uniform application of this directive has occurred, the decision indicates that the Burmese authorities are responsive both to internal opposition to the demands of corvee labour and to expressions of international concern at the continuation of the practice. The Australian Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to eliminate the use of forced and unpaid labour.

It should be noted that the provision of technical assistance by the ILO is more likely to be effective if it is provided within the appropriate tripartite framework, namely where trade unions are allowed to exist and function freely. It is therefore also important in this context that the Government of Burma comply with the requests of the ILO Committee to adopt the necessary measures to guarantee freedom of association. It should also be noted that the ILO Committee decided to leave it to the International Labour Office to determine whether an ILO mission would be appropriate and the timing of such a mission.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian delegates to the ILO continue to raise these issues and press the Government of Burma for reform of its labour laws to bring them into line with the requirements of the ILO.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

Burma ratified both ILO C.29, the Forced Labour Convention, 1930 and C.87, the Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948 on 4 March 1955, thereby incurring binding obligations to comply with the provisions of these Conventions.

The complaints to the ILO Committee on the Application of Standards are long‐standing in nature. Although the Government of Burma told the ILO Committee in June, 1995 that the process of amending the Village Act and the Town Act has commenced, concerns remained about the delay in addressing this issue and the failure of the Government of Burma over many years to act on other observations of the Committee. The ILO Committee took the very serious step of noting its concerns in special paragraphs of its report. The Burmese cases were also mentioned in the press release issues by the ILO summarising the significant issues addressed by the 1995 Conference.
In light of the above, it is essential that the Government of Burma continue to be urged to comply with its obligations until sufficient evidence of such compliance has been demonstrated.

The Australian Government member on the ILO Committee on the Application of Standards in June 1995 strongly urged the Government of Burma to guarantee full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms and to meet without delay its obligations under C.29. Australia also supports the strong consensus resolutions on Burma at the Commission on Human Rights.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) contribute to the United Nations Drug Control Program (UNDCP) in support of the expansion of crop substitution measures;
(b) examine the feasibility of contributing to the UNDCP program by offering law enforcement training; and

(c) encourage its dialogue partners in ASEAN to pursue with the Government of Burma long term solutions to the problems of trafficking in women and drugs through fully negotiated political settlements in the border regions in conjunction with the ceasefires.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

Since mid‐1993 Australia has funded the employment of an "Associate Expert" by the UN Drug Control Program (UNDCP) in Rangoon through its program of development assistance, and intends to continue this funding in 1997. The duties of the Associate Expert include managing the development and monitoring of crop substitution projects in Burma.

Current Australian policy restricts aid delivery in Burma to humanitarian grassroots projects delivered through NGOs and UN agencies. There is no direct government to government bilateral aid program. If, in the future, the Government decided to expand aid delivery in Burma one of the options for consideration would be an increased contribution to UNDCP's crop substitution activities.

The Australian Federal Police (AFP) delivered a three week training course in Australia in September‐October 1994 to six Burmese law enforcement officers (three police officers and three legal officers from the Attorney‐General's Department) on anti‐narcotics measures. The training was delivered at the request of UNDCP which funded the project. The program was directed principally towards Australian investigation and prosecution of narcotics and financial crime.

The possibility of Australian aid funding for law enforcement activities and agencies in any country always raises general policy issues relating to the role of law enforcement agencies in that country, particularly in relation to democracy and human rights. In the case of Burma, the association of human rights abuses with law enforcement makes law enforcement training an option that requires very careful consideration. However, should a decision to expand aid to Burma be made, one of the options AusAID would examine would be the feasibility of offering narcotics law enforcement training through the UNDCP.

The Australian Government will continue to encourage relevant ASEAN Governments to urge the Government of Burma and ethnic groups in the border regions to expand ceasefire agreements into broader political agreements that seriously address the legitimate political, economic and social aspirations of all people in Burma. It is in this context that problems such as trafficking in women and drugs are best addressed and long‐term solutions identified and implemented.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Thailand to:
(a) ratify the international human rights conventions relevant to the issue of trafficking in women, particularly the ICCPR;

(b) implement the provisions of its existing anti‐prostitution legislation by instituting prosecutions against those who traffic in women and girls for the purposes of prostitution and any police or army officers assisting in the trade;

(c) ensure that the victims of trafficking, women, girls and young men, are protected and rehabilitated and that support for Thailand in this endeavour should become a focus of the Australian aid program to Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Agreed in part
(b) Agreed
(c) Agreed

(a) The Government has urged all countries in the region, including Thailand, to accede to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and other major human rights instruments. The Government has not made specific proposals to Thailand on the ICCPR but, in the context of promoting greater effectiveness of the human rights treaty system, has made representations on treaty ratification to a number of countries in the region and is considering making these representations more widely.

The Australian Government supports international action to address the trafficking issue and shares the growing concern in the international community regarding the exploitation of women in the sex industry. The UN General Assembly has expressed its grave concern over the worsening problem of trafficking in women and girls, particularly the internationalisation of the traffic, and has requested that Governments take specific steps to address the problem.

The Government is aware of international meetings of non‐government organisations and individuals concerned about the growing international traffic in women were held in Manila and Brussels in March 1993. Both meetings sought a new international convention on trafficking in women to replace the 1949 Convention on Prostitution, which now is seen as outmoded. The Government is considering what further work might be done to develop a new Convention on trafficking which makes the distinction between forced prostitution and prostitution entered into voluntarily.

It is important to note that one major obstacle in tackling the issue of trafficking is the lack of any authenticated data available to determine the extent of the problem. For this reason, decriminalisation of prostitution should be considered as a viable strategy in the elimination of trafficking. Decriminalisation would provide an avenue for monitoring the conditions of prostitution. Such a position is in keeping with the distinction in the Convention to Eliminate All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) between the exploitation of prostitution and prostitution per se . Decriminalisation would also assist in shifting the focus of prosecution away from women subjected to trafficking and towards the organisers of trafficking (see (b) below).

(b) The Government will continue to support the Government of Thailand's efforts to strengthen its anti‐trafficking legislation and enforcement procedures. The Government of Thailand is developing legislation aimed at halting trafficking in women and limiting prostitution, particularly child prostitution, in Thailand. The Australian Government, through the Embassy in Bangkok, maintains close contact with both the Thai Office of Judicial Affairs and the National Commission on Women's Affairs in the Office of the Prime Minister in connection with the proposed legislation. The draft legislation has received the support of the Cabinet and is currently waiting to go before parliament.

The Government supports shifting the focus from the prosecution of women subjected to trafficking towards prosecution of those responsible for trafficking. The Government also supports efforts in other countries to improve the quality of domestic law enforcement including at the village level and in back areas.

At the Second Asian and Pacific Conference on Women in Development in Jakarta in June 1994, Australia strongly supported the following action set out in the Jakarta Declaration for the Advancement of Women in the Asia and Pacific, (Section E, Part 1): "Child prostitution and forced prostitution must be made illegal and heavy punishment imposed on traffickers and agents. Laws should be reformulated to shift the bias against prostitutes that exists in many countries".

(c) It was agreed at the High Level Consultation on Australia's program of development assistance for Thailand, held in Thailand in November 1995, that Australia's program should have four main areas of focus: Education, Health—focused on HIV/AIDS, Energy, and the Environment. While in general the funding of rehabilitation programs will have to be the responsibility of the Government of Thailand, there is some scope within this framework for support for Thai endeavours regarding the victims of trafficking.

The Government recognises that action must be taken beyond legislative and rehabilitation measures to address the root causes of trafficking in women. Programs designed to advance the economic and social status of women are crucial factors in this regard.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Attorney‐General's Department, in coordination with other relevant State and Federal agencies,
(a) review all legislation relating to prostitution in Australia;
(b) consider the need to enact legislation which would target traffickers in women and children.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

The Government regards the trafficking of women and children into forced prostitution as a grave violation of women's and children's human rights and a manifestation of violence against women and children.

A recent report by the United Nations Secretary‐General defines trafficking as the transportation of women and girls from one place to another with the end goal of forcing those trafficked, through deception as to either the nature of their work or the conditions in which they will work, into sexually and economically oppressive and exploitative situations for the profit of recruiters and crime syndicates. Consistent with this definition, force is the defining element of trafficking not the nature of the work performed.

The Attorney‐General's Department is currently preparing a discussion paper outlining possible domestic legal strategies which can be taken to target traffickers. This paper, along with strategies raised in the United Nations Fourth World Conference on Women's Platform for Action, will support development by relevant Commonwealth agencies of a co‐ordinated strategy to address issues associated with the trafficking in women and children. The feasibility of proposing a review by the Commonwealth, States and Territories of legislation relating to prostitution in general and in particular the impact of that legislation on trafficking will be considered within this forum. All strategies developed should focus on supporting the human rights of the women and children subjected to trafficking and prosecuting the perpetrators of trafficking.

The Model Criminal Code Officers' Committee will be developing a chapter of offences against public order in 1997. Prostitution, along with other issues, will be canvassed in the discussion papers and reports on this chapter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) consider accession, perhaps with a reservation on Article 6, to the 1949 Convention for the Suppression of the Traffic in Persons and the Exploitation of the Prostitution of Others;
(b) encourage Australian Embassies to maintain tight visa and passport processes and procedures with a view to limiting fraud;
(c) offer assistance to regional countries to improve the security of their passports;
(d) put in place programs which would recognise Australia's responsibilities for the protection and rehabilitation of the victims of trafficking; and,
in cases where the women are the victims of the crime of trafficking,
(e) consider this as a factor in any application which is made for a humanitarian visa.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

Australia has not ratified the 1949 Convention for the Suppression of Traffic in Persons and the Exploitation of the Prostitution of Others as we believe that some of the views expressed on the issue of prostitution are outmoded.

With regard to other instruments relevant to trafficking in women, Australia has ratified the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW) and the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CROC) and supports the establishment of an Optional Protocol to the CROC on the sale of children, child prostitution and child pornography.

All effort is made to minimise the level of fraud in the administration of visas to Australia. A number of officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) with specialist skills have recently been posted overseas to key posts to assist with the investigation of illegal entry rackets and the identification of individuals involved. One such officer has been posted to Bangkok.

The Australian Government Publishing Service is well positioned to respond to requests for assistance from regional countries wishing to improve passport security and is able to supply passports of similar quality to the Australian passport. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade would be pleased to discuss its secure procedure methods and is able to assist the relevant authorities of regional countries by providing them with details of Australian companies that are able to provide passport systems with similar security levels to the Australian passport.

The Government views the illegal entry for prostitution as an ongoing concern having wider law enforcement, community welfare and social justice ramifications. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is examining appropriate measures to ensure that victims of trafficking are handled sensitively in the context of Australian immigration law and procedures.

Contact is maintained with representatives from the sex industry and with representatives from the Global Alliance Against Trafficking in Women, to assist in devising strategies for addressing these issues. DIMA continues to work with the Australian Federal Police on investigations relating to women from South East Asia abusing the visitor visa system to enter Australia to work in the sex industry.

Trafficking organisers are devising increasingly complex methods to circumvent law enforcement strategies. It is recognised that the focus of any legislative change should be towards punishing the organisers and those who traffic women into Australia. To date, however, the women involved have been reluctant to provide information which might assist in the identification of recruiters and organisers.

In the course of research and investigation into organised crime in Australia, the National Crime Authority (NCA) has found links between the entry of Asian prostitutes and organised crime. The NCA is coordinating law enforcement action against South East Asian organised crime; DIMA assists in this activity through cooperation on a daily basis and through assistance in the formulation of national law enforcement situational assessments and strategies.

Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program provides resettlement places for persons who are refugees (as defined in the 1951 Convention and 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees), and for persons who suffer severe discrimination resulting in a gross violation of human rights and for those whose lives have been severely disrupted by war or civil strife. Economic hardship, leading to exploitation of women and children through prostitution, is not of itself sufficient to qualify a person for consideration under Australia's Humanitarian Program.

While persecution on the grounds of gender is not recognised under the 1951 Refugee Convention and 1967 Protocol, DIMA has developed guidelines for the sensitive handling of applications by women for humanitarian entry to and refugee status in Austral ia. The Guidelines for Stay in Australia on Humanitarian Grounds cover procedural issues, to ensure that sensitive consideration is given to women applicants, particularly victims of sexual abuse; to ensure that female spouses of applicants have the opportunity to make separate claims; that departmental officers are culturally sensitive and show respect for family relationships; and that wherever possible same sex officers and interpreters are used, particularly when cases involve claims of a sexual nature.

The guidelines will also offer guidance on the issues of gender persecution in assessing applications, which takes account of the fact that persecution can be experienced differently by women than by men. They will also be revised to include gender issues among the circumstances for the exercise of Ministerial discretion.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to accede to the UN Chemical Weapons Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

Burma is an original signatory of the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC). It signed the convention at the ceremony in Paris in January 1993 when the treaty was opened for signature. Burma has not, however, ratified the Convention as yet. The CWC is not yet in force, but it is expected to come into force during 1996.

Australia has consistently urged Burma to sign and ratify the convention. Burma has been a country of focus under Australia's Chemical Weapons Regional Initiative (CWRI). This began in 1988 with the purpose of promoting regional support for the CWC treaty regime. Most recently, experts from the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) and DFAT conducted bilateral consultations on CWC implementation in October 1995 in Rangoon (as part of a wider round of consultations in the region, which included visits to Jakarta, Bandar Seri Begawan, Vientiane and Bangkok).

The latest consultations provided an opportunity to discuss with Burmese officials the detail of CWC ratification. This will involve a complex domestic implementation process, including measures ranging from preparing enabling legislation to the establishment of a CWC national authority. In consequence, a number of signatories, like Burma, have not been able to ratify the convention quickly, despite a clear commitment to eventual ratification. There is little doubt that Burma will accede to the CWC in due course.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Thailand to:
(a) ratify the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol; and
(b) permit the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to provide greater assistance to the refugees on the Thai—Burma border.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

The Australian Government has and will continue to encourage the Government of Thailand and all countries in the South East Asian and South Pacific regions to ratify the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and the 1967 Protocol to that Convention, if they have not already done so. During the later half of last year the Australian Government supplied 18 of its overseas missions, including Bangkok, with information kits on the 1951 Convention to pass to host governments, while encouraging them to accede to the Convention.

While the Government of Thailand has not yet ratified the Convention, the Australian Government appreciates its actions in permitting the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and a variety of international NGOs to operate in Thailand, delivering assistance to people from Burma who have fled military activity and human rights abuses to obtain temporary sanctuary in Thailand.

The UNHCR works with NGOs and donor countries to provide assistance to those who have obtained sanctuary in the camps along the Thai/Burma border. The Australian Government has recently renewed its representations to the governments of both Burma and Thailand to allow an acceptable form of international monitoring of the return of the displaced people when conditions permitting their safe and voluntary return exist.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government explore ways, within the current humanitarian program in Burma, to assist in the wider dissemination of information about HIV/AIDS.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

Information dissemination about HIV/AIDS is included in current NGO projects funded by Australia in Burma. In recognition of the growing problem of HIV/AIDS in Burma, the Australian Government provided $1.06 million for expenditure within Burma over the past three years to help combat the spread of the disease. The funds have been provided through NGOs working within Burma, and through UNICEF.

In August 1995 the Australian Government launched a manual—Community Action on HIV: A Resource Manual for HIV Prevention and Care —which is designed to assist NGOs and donor agencies involved in implementing and managing HIV/AIDS projects throughout South East Asia.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee endorses the call of the UN Special Rapporteur for the revision of the 1982 Citizenship Law to eliminate the creation of second class citizenship, especially for the Rakhine Muslim people.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government endorses the call of the UN Rapporteur for the revision of the 1982 Citizenship Law to eliminate the creation of second class citizenship, especially for the Rakhine Muslim people.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian diplomatic representatives and officers from AusAID make a specific evaluation of the repatriation and resettlement of the Rohingya refugees by regular visits to the Arakan State and the UNHCR projects established to ensure their successful resettlement.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Government agrees that it is important to assess the repatriation and settlement of the Rohingyas who have returned from Bangladesh to Rakhine State and this is a priority for the Embassy in Rangoon. Close liaison with UNHCR is maintained by the Embassies in Rangoon and Dhaka. Despite the remoteness of the region and difficulties of access the Embassy has made two visits, one by the Ambassador, to evaluate first‐hand the return program since its implementation in late 1994. In addition, a Canberra AusAID officer undertook a mission to the Burma/Bangladesh border in October 1995 to evaluate the UNHCR's program of voluntary repatriation. The second visit by the Embassy evaluated specifically the resettlement within Rakhine State.

While it is clear that Rakhine State is not free from human rights abuses, it is equally clear that the repatriation program has been successful. The continuing violation of human rights in Burma is not restricted to the Rohingyas and the abuses that they suffer are endemic in Burma, ie the Rohingyas are not persecuted because of their religious beliefs or ethnicity, although these factors have contributed to their economic and social marginalisation. Anchoring the returnees is dependent upon long‐term solutions to the country‐wide human rights problems and the lack of economic opportunities. Rakhine remains a poverty‐stricken state with a substantial number of landless agricultural workers who have limited opportunities to be self‐supporting. This will present a challenge to the Government of Burma and UN agencies and others intending to assist in development of Rakhine State.

Officers from the Embassy in Rangoon will continue to visit the area. In addition to visits, our missions in Rangoon and Dhaka receive reports from UNHCR and NGOs concerning the situation in the border camps and in Rakhine State.

PARA.EMPHASIS: In responding to demands for self‐determination in Burma, the Australian Government and its ASEAN dialogue partners include on their agenda for discussions between Foreign Ministers and between Heads of Government the importance of protecting minority rights as the most effective way of ensuring the stability of the state.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

The concept of self‐determination is an evolving one at international law. The Australian Government's view is that self‐determination encompasses the continuing right of peoples to decide how they should be governed and to participate in the political process. It is neither a static nor an absolute concept, but it would not, for example, ordinarily involve the right to secede or otherwise realise separate sovereignty where the peoples concerned are able to participate meaningfully in the government of the State in which they live—particularly where the participation and fundamental human rights of indigenous peoples as well as their special position are respected.

The Government strongly holds the view that the political fragmentation and armed insurgencies that have plagued Burma since independence are best resolved through a process of reconciliation that takes into account the legitimate aspirations of all the peoples of the country. The Government notes that ceasefire agreements have been reached with 15 of the 16 main ethnic insurgent groups, although one to these arrangements has broken down since signature. The Government believes that a true and lasting stability will result from effective protection of minority rights and must go beyond a mere cessation of military activity.

The members of ASEAN are interested in the cessation of ethnic hostilities in Burma. ASEAN wishes to see a politically stable system of government in Burma. Minority rights are, and will remain, an issue of central importance in Burma's political development. As such, the issue will continue to feature in discussions at Ministerial level between Australia and the Governments of the members of ASEAN.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government continue to press the Government of Burma to:
(a) recognise the popular legitimacy of the NLD and builds (sic) on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's call for power sharing on a South African model; and
(b) begin negotiations with Aung San Suu Kyi with a view to bringing about this end.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government believes that Burma is now at a critical stage of its political development. The Government is disappointed that the Government of Burma has not responded to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's overtures to commence a meaningful dialogue on the country's political future following her release from house arrest in July last year. It shares Aung San Suu Kyi's assessment that dialogue undertaken in a spirit of genuine reconciliation is the manner in which the political aspirations of the people of Burma can best be addressed.

The Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to acknowledge the legitimacy of the National League for Democracy (NLD) as representing the political aspirations of the majority of the people of Burma. The Australian Government commends the actions of prominent citizens of Burma who have also publicly addressed the desirability of a dialogue between the SLORC and the NLD.

While an examination of the recent political experience of South Africa may contain useful lessons for political leaders in Burma, the Australian Government does not wish to be prescriptive on this issue. There are a number of countries in the East Asian region from which useful lessons might also be drawn.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to include a greater number of the National League for Democracy representatives and a more representative group of delegates from the ethnic minorities in the deliberations of the National Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government has frequently expressed its concerns about the composition and procedures of the National Convention to the Government of Burma. Given the events of late November 1995 the possibility of increased NLD participation in the National Convention now appears even more remote. Following the resumption of the National Convention on 28 November 1995 the NLD announced that it was suspending its participation in the Convention because the SLORC had not responded to its call for a dialogue. In the absence of a dialogue the NLD view was that it would not be possible for the National Convention to successfully achieve its aim of drafting a constitution consonant with democratic principles that would lead to a genuine multiparty democracy. On 30 November the Panel of Chairmen of the National Convention revoked the delegate status of the NLD delegates. The decision was made pursuant to the Convention procedures which permitted revocation of delegate status if a delegate was absent without leave for two consecutive days.

The UNGA resolution on Burma adopted in December last year, which was co‐sponsored by Australia, called specifically for the composition of the National Convention to include representatives elected in the 1990 elections.

It is the Government's firm view that the ceasefire agreements the SLORC has reached with the ethnic insurgent groups need to be broadened to comprehensive settlements that address the legitimate political, economic and social aspirations of the people.
The Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to adopt a more open and inclusive approach to consideration of the country's constitution and future political arrangements.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to provide observer status to the international press, diplomatic representatives and representatives of the Inter‐Parliamentary Union to the proceedings of the National Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to adopt a more open approach to political discussion. The legitimacy of the National Convention's product is likely to be enhanced by open debate and greater transparency in the proceedings reported by international observers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government press the Government of Burma to begin immediate negotiations with Daw San Suu Kyi and the leadership on the NLD.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The response to Recommendation 19 is relevant. The dominant theme of the Australian Government's dialogue with the Government of Burma since the release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in July last year has been its call for the Government of Burma to commence a meaningful dialogue with the leadership of the NLD about the political future of the country. While Aung San Suu Kyi and other NLD leaders were under arrest or detention the primary focus of attention was securing their release. Since the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and other prominent NLD figures last year the focus has intensified on the need for meaningful dialogue on substantive political issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to:
(b) comply with the request of the Inter‐parliamentary Union for information on the names and numbers of all political detainees;
(c) allow private access to delegates of the IPU or the ICRC to these detainees; and
(d) repeal those laws which include ill‐defined offences against national security (see paragraph 5.44) which have been used for the purpose of eliminating opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government will continue to urge the Government of Burma to release all remaining political prisoners, to provide full disclosure on remaining political prisoners, to permit international organisations access to political prisoners and to liberalise its approach to the organisation of political opposition. The Government has made frequent representations on these issues and will continue to do so.

Only the SLORC knows for sure how many political prisoners are being held. It is difficult to keep track of who has been detained, and for what reason, and who has been released. For example, the SLORC has announced the release of over 2,000 prisoners detained for political reasons since 1992, but not all of these would fit the usual ideas about what a political prisoner is, and very few of them were named, making record keeping difficult. The best estimate is that, on average, there are certainly many hundreds of prisoners who are being held for political reasons at any one time and the figure may well be over the thousand mark. But the numbers do go up and down. During 27‐29 September, the Burmese authorities may have detained up to 800 National League for Democracy (NLD) supporters in a crackdown to halt a planned NLD party congress, although most of these have now been released.
The response to Recommendation 5 is also relevant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government urge the Government of Burma to enact laws which would ensure freedom of assembly and information so that all citizens of Burma may participate fully in the political process.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The UNGA and CHR resolutions on the situation of human rights in Burma, traditionally co‐sponsored by Australia, strongly urge the Government of Burma to ensure freedom of assembly and information, and to allow all citizens to participate fully in the political process.

The issues of freedom of assembly and information and the repeal of ill‐defined national security legislation have been, and will continue to be, prominent themes in the Australian Government's representations at Ministerial and officials levels to the Government of Burma.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government continue to work through the United Nations for change in Burma and that at all times the government give full support to the work of the Special Rapporteur on Burma in his endeavours to persuade the Government of Burma to comply with existing UN resolutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Government is committed to pursuing change in Burma both through the United Nations and through bilateral contacts. It will continue to give the Special Rapporteur and the Secretary‐General's Special Representative its full support on their visits to Burma and in meetings of the UN General Assembly and the Commission on Human Rights.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Given that the United States, Japan, the European Union and the Commonwealth of Nations encompass most of the developed and the democratic states of the world, the Australian Government should continue to work bilaterally and through all relevant multi‐lateral forums to gain an acceptance of the need for political reform as a prelude to investment in Burma or development assistance to Burma.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

The Australian Government supports dialogue with the SLORC and does not consider that isolation of the regime makes sense. Accordingly, it does not advocate further sanctions against the regime, for which there would be little international support in any event. The Government hopes, though, that other Governments, in their exchanges and dialogue with the Burmese Government, will use the opportunity to convey that political reforms and an improved human rights performance would not only be worthwhile for their own sake but would facilitate Burma's re‐integration into the regional and international community.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government continue to press the ASEAN countries to:

(a) maintain the constructive aspects to their engagement policy by pressing the Government of Burma towards further reform—the end to forced labour, the release of political detainees, dialogue with Aung San Suu Kyi and the liberalisation of the procedures of the Burmese National Convention, established to draw up a new constitution; and
(b) that these reforms should precede the entry of Burma into ASEAN.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part

The Australian Government continues to discuss with ASEAN members, through bilateral meetings and participation in the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) and the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference, our concerns with the situation in Burma. At the ARF in July 1996, for example, Mr Downer worked with other foreign ministers to arrange for the ARF Chairman to convey to the Burmese Foreign Minister, U Ohn Gyaw, the shared concerns of ARF members about the slowness of political reform in Burma with a request that U Ohn Gyaw respond in the ARF plenary session. The Burmese Foreign Minister subsequently responded through a statement to the plenary session of the ARF. This initiative demonstrated to the Burmese delegation that such concerns were widespread, amongst ASEAN and non‐ASEAN members alike.

Burma was granted observer status to ASEAN and membership of the ARF in July 1996. It subsequently submitted an application for full membership of ASEAN, and has indicated it would like to join in 1997.

The Australian Government's view is that the issue of when and under what conditions Burma should join ASEAN is a matter for ASEAN members to decide. Whether or not Burma is a member of ASEAN, the Australian Government will continue to make known its concerns about the situation there, and encourage political and human rights reform.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government continue to encourage the Government of Thailand to take up the issue of democratic reform with the SLORC as a matter of mutual interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed

The Australian Government will continue to encourage the Government of Thailand in its contacts with the Government of Burma to promote positive reforms while recognising that, as a key neighbour, Thailand's perspective on developments in Burma will at times differ from that of Australia. The Thai Government has adopted the "constructive engagement" approach towards Burma. This approach is based on the premise that positive developments in Burma are more likely to result from encouragement than pressure.

However, it remains the view of the Australian Government that a judicious mixture of encouragement and pressure is warranted. Thailand, with its vigorous democracy, is well placed to illustrate the advantages of an open society.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) take every opportunity to express its concern to the Government of China about China's supply of arms to Burma;
(b) urge the Government of Japan to continue to press the Government of China about the size and nature of its arms sales internationally; and
in the light of Japan's Overseas Development Assistance Charter and its aid program with China,
(c) remind the SLORC that the level of arms expenditure is a significant inhibition in the willingness of the international community to resume development assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part
The Australian Government has encouraged actual and potential exporters of arms to Burma not to undertake such activities. Australia does not export arms to Burma.

The Government will continue to express concern to the Government of China about its arms sales to the Government of Burma. It will also encourage the Japanese Government to continue to make known its concerns about conditions in Burma.
The Australian Government's views on the level of arms expenditure in Burma and the implications this has for the development of the country are well known to the Government of Burma.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) The Australian Government should actively encourage Australian business to act at all times in a manner consistent with Australian law and human rights objectives, including environmental and women's rights; and

(b) consistent with a whole‐of‐government approach to human rights and the need to provide business with practical assistance, the Australian Government should ensure that those government departments, agencies and services, such as AUSTRADE, which routinely deal with and/or advise Australian companies:
(i) are fully appraised and routinely updated on Australia's human rights objectives and relevant human rights intelligence;
(ii) provide appropriate advice to companies on human rights matters; and
(iii) establish in cooperation with business organisations a human rights code of practice; and

(c) the Australian Government should pursue at the ILO the development of a convention to require the application of consistent health and safety standards for workers in multinational enterprises, ensuring that the same high standards apply to workers in developing countries as to those in the country of origin of the enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Agreed
(b) Agreed in part
(c) Agreed in part

(a) In the course of facilitating and encouraging trade between Australia and foreign countries, Australian Government agencies actively encourage Australian companies to act in a manner consistent with the law, both in Australia and in other countries, on all matters relating to the conduct of their respective business.

(b) Australian business organisations have ample opportunity (as do other elements of the Australian community) to develop an awareness of the importance of human rights issues in the Government's foreign policy. The Government works to ensure that Australian enterprises with an interest in investigating commercial opportunities in Burma are aware of the Government's policy of neither encouraging nor discouraging trade and investment with Burma and are also aware of the Government's specific concerns about continuing human rights abuses in that country. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Embassy in Rangoon include political and human rights issues in the briefings provided to Australian businesses that request information on Burma.

The Government recognises that the development of voluntary codes of conduct could assist businesses to cultivate both a sense of ownership and an awareness of the human rights and other issues involved in their operations overseas.

(c) The activities of multinational enterprises have been a matter of concern to the ILO since the 1960s and an instrument to regulate their activities has already been adopted. Follow‐up machinery to oversight the implementation of the instrument has also been established.

In 1977, following intense discussion on the desirability of developing international instruments to regulate the conduct of multinational enterprises and define the terms of their relations with host countries, the ILO's constituents reached a consensus which resulted in the adoption of the Tripartite Declaration of Principles concerning Multinational Enterprises and Social Policy (the Declaration).

The Declaration sets out principles in the fields of employment, training, conditions of work and life and industrial relations which governments, employers' and workers' organisations and multinational enterprises are encouraged to observe on a voluntary basis. These principles include specific provisions on safety and health and are reinforced by certain ILO Conventions and Recommendations. The social partners are urged to bear these in mind and apply them to the greatest extent possible.

The follow‐up machinery consists of periodic reports by governments on the effect given to the Declaration (after consultation with employers' and workers' organisations) and of a procedure for the examination of disputes concerning the application of the Declaration through requests for interpretation of the meaning of its provisions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government support the establishment, as outlined in the ACFOA proposal to the inquiry into Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights, of a Human Rights Centre for Dialogue and Cooperation in Australia. This centre might be established in conjunction with the Peacekeeping Centre recommended in the Committee's report on Peacekeeping tabled in December 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: Under consideration

In A Confident Australia the Government made a commitment to encourage the establishment of a Centre for Democratic Institutions in Australia to assist in the promotion of human rights within the Asia‐Pacific region. This issue is currently being examined and options developed. In this process, ACFOA is being consulted.

Australia is a founding state of the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (International IDEA). The Australian Government provides funding support for International IDEA. The Institute was established in February 1995 and has its headquarters in Stockholm, Sweden. It has identified the promotion and consolidation of democracy world‐wide as one of its work programs. International IDEA argues that the observance of human rights is a key element of the civic culture which enables democracy to flourish. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is a member of the Board of International IDEA.

PARA.EMPHASIS: As long as there is no move to establish a dialogue with Aung San Suu Kyi and the NLD, no broadening of the procedures of the National Convention, no end to forced labour, nor the release of political prisoners, the Australian Government:
(a) continue to direct its assistance program to the people on the border; and
(b) consider an increase in health and sanitation programs for the people in the camps.

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Agreed in part
(b) Agreed

The Australian Government is committed to providing humanitarian assistance to people from Burma who have obtained sanctuary in Thailand and Bangladesh. In 1995‐96 Australia provided $1 million for relief supplies and medical programs to those in the camps in Thailand and $1.75 million for food, medical and rehabilitation programs for the Rohingyas who sought sanctuary in Bangladesh.

The Australian Government also responds to the undeniable humanitarian need within Burma. While there is no direct bilateral aid program the Government will continue to provide funding delivered through the UN and NGOs addressing health and anti‐narcotics issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that AusAID set aside some of its funding to Burma for educational programs directed at the development of civil society and an understanding of democratic processes amongst the people in the border camps

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

AusAID is currently funding scholarships for 20 exiled Burmese students who obtained sanctuary in Thailand and are now studying in Australia. These students are expected to return to Burma to assist with the development of their country when conditions permit.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government:
(a) increase the intake of students from Burma in this category to a minimum of 12 per year;
(b) encourage students to undertake, possibly through the TAFE system, skills based courses relevant to the future development needs of Burma.

SPEECH.PARA: (a) Not agreed
(b) Agreed

The rationale for the scholarship program is to provide exiled Burmese students with a tertiary education in order for them to better contribute to political leadership in Burma. This assumes that they will return to Burma. It is possible that they will assess political and social conditions in Burma at the time they complete their courses as not conducive to their immediate return as they are supporters of opposition groups and so may not be well placed to contribute to the country's development.
Funds are not available to support a further intake of students in 1996‐97. The question of intakes in future years will be addressed in the context of future budgeting circumstances.

All Burmese students on AusAID scholarships in Australia undertake courses which have been selected to be relevant to the development needs of Burma. All courses may be considered to be skills based. The TAFE and equivalent institutions are used according to the academic capability of the student.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government increase numbers in the Special Assistance Category for people from Burma residing in Thailand to bring it up to the level of the intake from Rangoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The allocation of places in the Special Assistance Category for people from Burma residing in Thailand has been maintained at its 1995‐96 level of 200 places. The allocation of places for Burmese in Burma is 50 places for 1996‐97.

The Special Assistance Category for Displaced Burmese in Thailand was established in 1993 with an initial allocation of 50 places. This allocation was increased to 100 places in the 1994‐95 programme year and again increased to 200 places in 1995‐96.
The Burmese in Burma SAC was established in September 1992. The number of places allocated in 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 was 500. This has been reduced in 1996‐97 to 50 places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government use its influence with other countries and with the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank to discourage reinvestment in Burma until political reforms in line with the banks' good governance policies have begun, in particular, the end to forced labour, the release of political prisoners, dialogue with Aung San Suu Kyi and changes to the structure and procedures of the National Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: No action is currently necessary; the Government will determine its position if and when circumstances require action.

The World Bank and the Asian Development Bank have not approved new loans to Burma since 1988, although the World Bank continued to disburse funds to Burma for loans approved prior to 1988. The last World Bank loan to Burma closed in June 1995. The ADB has had its lending in abeyance since 1986 due to civil disturbances. The ADB has made periodic country consultation missions to Burma to discuss matters of mutual interest. However, no new loans or technical assistance projects have been discussed.

As the World Bank and the ADB are not reinvesting in Burma, Australian influence to achieve this end is not necessary. With regard to Australian investment, Australia's position is to neither encourage nor discourage investment in Burma.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Australian Government should suggest the value of a regional forum for the examination of the problems associated with modern government with a view to developing strategies and programs of assistance for the enhancement of good government. Such issues as systems of bureaucracy and administrative practices, legal services and court systems, parliamentary practice or policing might be addressed in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Agree to explore further dialogue option.

The Government seeks to establish international mechanisms for contact and dialogue wherever possible. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and other ministers regularly discuss human rights and good governance issues in bilateral meetings in the region. As well, the two delegations to China and the Australian Parliamentary Consultative Delegation's visit last year to Vietnam have succeeded in establishing dialogue on a number of issues of mutual concern, including that of human rights.

The Government also gives a high priority to encouraging the establishment and strengthening of national human rights institutions in countries in the region. Through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Australia has provided a substantial degree of cooperation and technical assistance on national human rights institutions to a number of countries including the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand and Papua New Guinea. As well, the Government has contributed $300,000 to the UN Voluntary Fund for Technical Cooperation for the purpose of strengthening the domestic infrastructures which support human rights and, in particular, national human rights machinery in the Asia‐Pacific region.

The Government has long supported the development of Asia‐Pacific human rights arrangements which would complement the UN human rights machinery and national institutions established in a number of countries in the region for the promotion and protection of human rights. In this context, the Government has been, over recent years, in consultation with other governments on the prospects for a structured dialogue, which might eventually extend to regular meetings at a ministerial level. The Asia‐Pacific is the only region of the world which is still without such an arrangement. The Government believes a regional arrangement would foster greater understanding, cooperation and maintenance of universal human rights principles amongst the diverse and varied social systems and cultures in the Asia‐Pacific. The Government's experience on this subject suggests that although there is interest by many countries of the region in closer cooperation on human rights some of them are not ready to formalise this and that further work will be required before such an arrangement could be set in place.

To advance work on a regional arrangement, three UN‐sponsored meetings have been held, in Manila in 1990, Jakarta in 1993 and Seoul in 1994. At the meeting in Seoul, while there was no consensus on the establishment of a formal regional mechanism, there was a general desire that discussions should continue. A resolution supporting regional activity was introduced by the Republic of Korea and supported by Australia at the 1995 session of the UN Commission on Human Rights and was adopted by consensus. At a meeting of national human rights institutions held in Manila in April last year, participants, who represented national institutions not governments, affirmed their support for regional cooperation in the promotion and protection of human rights. The Government considers the strengthening of the networks that are developing between national commissions in the region will assist in the establishment of a regional human rights body.
The Government will continue to look for opportunities to extend dialogue on human rights within the limitations of available resources.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that when any decision is made in the future to begin development assistance to Burma it should be in the form of project assistance which has as its objectives the protection of rights and the principles of openness and accountability which are being sought in the benchmarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed
Future development assistance options for projects in Burma will incorporate the objectives of the protection of rights and the principles of openness and accountability.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE DISSENTING REPORT OF SENATOR MARGETTS
