That any ministerial level contact be limited to those occasions when the Australian Foreign Minister and ministers of the Burmese regime are present at multilateral fora outside Burma such as the ASEAN ministerial meeting, or at the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed

While there are no plans for Australian Ministers to visit Burma and the last official visit by an Australian Foreign Minister to Burma occurred in 1983, the Australian Government does not wish to rule out the possibility of a visit in the future and does not accept that Ministerial contact should be limited to the Minister for Foreign Affairs only.

The Australian Government will continue to encourage the Government of Burma to institute positive change in the country. To encourage the Government to change it is necessary to talk to its members. The Australian Government has regular contact with Ministers and senior officials through our Embassy in Rangoon. The Government does not rule out increased Ministerial contact as an effective means of furthering the objectives of our relations with Burma.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian government "hold the line" on the benchmarks and not resume ministerial contact (other than as described in Recommendation 1, above) until significant progress is made on the benchmarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed

The "benchmarks" policy of the previous Government was not related to the issue of Ministerial contact between the Governments of Australia and Burma. In mid‐1994 the former Minister for Foreign Affairs enunciated a series of "benchmarks" which identified specific issues of concern about the human rights situation in Burma. The Australian Government sees the benchmarks not as a rigid list of requirements all of which have to be met before the Burmese Government can be given a tick of approval, but rather as a helpful guide to areas where real progress would be seen not only as desirable, but also as essential by both the people of Burma themselves and most international observers. We recognise that progress is likely to be incremental: what is important is that improvements are made and that there is identifiable movement in the direction of a more open and democratic society.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian government inform the public of the major sources of heroin being imported into Australia as a means of mobilising public opinion against the SLORC.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed

The Senate resolution of 2 March 1994 requested the JSCFADT "to inquire into and report on the human rights situation and lack of progress towards democracy in Myanmar." While there has been an opaque relationship between political developments and narco‐insurgency in Burma since independence, it is understandable that the Committee elected to focus on issues of more central importance to the human rights situation in Burma.
Action by the Australian Government to inform the public about Burma as a source of heroin is unnecessary because Burma's position as the key source of opium and heroin is well known.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian government urge the United Nations and individual countries to recognise Daw Aung San Suu Kyi as the rightful leader of a democratic government of Burma and establish contact with her.
That, in the event that government officials plan to visit Burma, such visits are predicated on the itinerary including a meeting with Ms Suu Kyi prior to, and following, discussions with the SLORC.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed
It is the practice of the Australian Government to recognise States not Governments.
The Australian Government supports the efforts of all those in Burma who are working to improve the human rights situation and working for democracy.

The Australian Embassy in Rangoon maintains contact with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, her advisers and other leaders of the National League for Democracy. If senior officials plan to visit Burma in future, it would generally be appropriate for them to request a meeting with Aung San Suu Kyi, but it would not be helpful to make any possible future visits conditional on access to Aung San Suu Kyi.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) That the Austrade office in Rangoon be closed until such time as significant progress is made on the benchmarks released by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1994;
(b) That the Country Economic Brief be withdrawn from circulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Not agreed

The Australian Government's policy is to neither encourage nor discourage trade and investment with Burma. This means that there is no active promotion of trade and investment links with Burma. However, it does not inhibit Australian business from visiting Burma and exploring the scope for pursuing commercial opportunities there. The Australian Embassy in Rangoon and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade continue to respond to requests for advice and information.

The Embassy in Rangoon does not have an Australian based Austrade officer. The Austrade office is staffed by a locally engaged officer and one administrative support staff. The office is not visited by Austrade officials from Australia or elsewhere in the region. The function of the Austrade office is reactive: it responds to requests for information, advice and assistance with administra tive matters. If the Austrade office was closed the Embassy would continue to receive requests for information, advice and assistance. While closure of the Austrade office might have some limited symbolic value, it would have minimal effect on Australia‐Burma trade and investment and would have no effect on the Government of Burma's human rights policies and practices.

The production of a Country Economic Brief (CEB) on Burma is consistent with the Government's policy of neither encouraging nor discouraging trade and investment with Burma. The CEB does not attempt to provide a comprehensive coverage of all political and human rights issues. As the name implies, a CEB addresses economic and commercial issues that may be of interest to Australian enterprises. The Australian Government's concern about the human rights situation in Burma is mentioned clearly on pages 4 and 5 (the first two pages of text) of the Burma CEB. Material on Australian Government policy on Burma, our view of political developments and our concern about the human rights situation is readily available in other documents supplied by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade without charge to inquirers. It is the practice of our Embassy in Rangoon to include political and human rights issues in the briefing it provides to Australian business visitors.

The awareness Australian enterprises have of Australia's Burma policy may be a factor in their reluctance to engage Burma with the enthusiasm and commitment demonstrated in other East Asian economies. While there is some evidence of an increase in interest by the Australian business community in the commercial potential of Burma this interest is cautious and tempered by concerns about political stability. It remains the case that there is not a lot of Australian business interest to discourage.

Our current bilateral trade with Myanmar is small. The total value of our exports to Burma in 1995/96 was $A13.2 million. The total value of imports from Burma in the same period was $A6.8 million. Our foreign direct investment in Myanmar is also small: the level of new direct investment since 1992 is probably less than $US10 million although no reliable figures are available. Direct investment from Myanmar into Australia is negligible.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Australian Securities Commission be given a reference to conduct an inquiry with a view to creating a code of practice covering such matters as international law, international treaties and conventions, human rights and environmental obligations for Australian businesses operating outside Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in part
For general comment on this issue see the response to Recommendation 30 above. In addition, it may be useful to consider the following points:

There are two existing multilateral codes of conduct for transnational corporations covering human rights and environmental matters—the ILO Tripartite Declaration of Principles for Multinational Enterprises and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises. These codes are comprehensive.
In this context, there are arguments to suggest that a code that would "add value" may be targeted at specific practices (eg: forced labour) and not cover the whole field.

The Government sees some value in a voluntary code and would support and assist business in developing such a code. However, the Government has serious misgivings about the desirability or the enforceability of a mandatory code. If a mandatory code is not being contemplated here, then we would have reservations about the Securities Commission being the appropriate body to create the code. Any movement in this direction should take full account of the importance of industry involvement in the development of any code.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: PORT OF SENATE RURAL AND REGIONAL AFFAIRS AND TRANSPORT LEGISLATION COMMITTEE

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTRALIAN QUARANTINE AND INSPECTION SERVICE
On 9 November 1994, the Senate asked the Committee to inquire and report on :
"The administration and management of all aspects of the operation of the Australian Quarantine (and) Inspection Service"
Following receipt of written submissions, the Committee conducted extensive public hearings. Its report was tabled in May 1996.

On 14 December 1995, the former Government announced an independent Committee of Review of Australia's animal and plant quarantine policies and programs—the Nairn Committee. Its terms of reference also cover some of the issues addressed by the Senate Committee. On taking office, this Government strengthened the scientific capacity of the Review Committee through the appointment of one extra member. The membership of the Committee and its terms of reference are attached (Attachment A & B). The Committee is to report in November 1996.

As this is the first major scientific review of Australia's quarantine systems since the Lindsay Committee reported in 1987, the Government will consider those recommendations of the Senate Committee which deal with quarantine policy issues in the context of its examination of the Nairn Committee Report.
The Senate Committee report has been provided to the Nairn Committee for its consideration.

The Government endorses the view of the Committee that a strong and effective AQIS is central to our dual goals of maintaining an effective quarantine system that protects our advantageous plant, animal and human health status and increasingly building on our reputation as a provider of safe, high quality food products to world markets.
The Government makes the following response to the Committee's specific recommendations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that AQIS should ensure that industry is fully aware of the costs associated with providing services and the methodology used to recover them.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : Agreed. AQIS will continue to convene its Industry Charging Review Committees to ensure that all members of relevant industry organisations are kept fully informed on costs and methodology used to determine AQIS charges.

Recommendation 2: The Committee recommends that AQIS carefully monitor the effects of the implementation of third party delivery arrangements, particularly during the first year of operation. AQIS should give particular consideration to the effect, both in terms of charges payable and efficiency of documentation provision, on exporters not based in major centres .

Response : Agreed. Since the Committee's report AQIS has introduced third party auditing provisions into its Dairy export program and third party inspections into its Live Animal export program, in both cases with the full support of the relevant industries.

There are contrary views within the horticulture industry as to the benefits of third party inspection systems. Accordingly, AQIS has not implemented the proposed system pending further consideration of the issues by the Government and further consultation with industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that AQIS develop strategies to better explain and disseminate information on its risk analysis and management approach to quarantine and inspection.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : The Nairn Committee is examining the basis of Quarantine Policy in Australia. It is considering the current approach to risk management processes. The Government's response to the Nairn Committee will inform and explain future approaches to quarantine decision making by AQIS.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4: The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, recognising that scientific and technical expertise must increasingly underpin the operations of AQIS particularly in quarantine, undertake a review of AQIS's resources and capacities and, if necessary, increase staffing and resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : Agreed. This is being addressed by the Nairn Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5: The Committee is concerned that the scientific research on the basis of which AQIS must make an assessment of risk should be comprehensive and relevant to Australian conditions. The Committee recommends that assessments of risk should not be made until such research has been done.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : Agreed in principle. Quarantine decision making must be based on the best available scientific and technical information. That expertise however, does not always reside in Australia; nor is it feasible in every case to ensure that research is "comprehensive and relevant to Australian conditions." Often, this would require the importation of live viruses to test their impact in Australia, which may represent a greater risk than the importation of the product itself.

In quarantine decision making it is usual for there to be incomplete scientific data available to aid assessment. This lack of data can relate to how the disease in question could be established and maintained in the Australian environment. The Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) Agreement allows conservative measures to be implemented where there are significant information gaps. This is consistent with the approach AQIS has taken.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6: The Committee recommends that AQIS should have wide‐ranging consultations with relevant industry groups before publishing a draft IRA. The Committee considers that such an approach will protect the integrity of AQIS's scientific reputation, reduce the likelihood of protracted and acrimonious debates, and ensure stable investment environments in the relevant industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : Future processes for the conduct of major risk analyses will be determined in light of the Nairn Committee Report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7: The Committee recommends that AQIS review NAQS in order to ensure that any incursion will automatically trigger coordinated and clear strategies and responses. These should include contingency plans, consultation and coordination between State and Federal agencies. The Committee considers that this is a significant lesson that can be learned from the incursion of the papaya fruit fly.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : AQIS commissioned a review of NAQS in January 1995. The review was carried out by Professor Malcolm Nairn and Dr Ian Muirhead and the report was presented to AQIS in August 1995.
In the wake of the papaya fruit fly incursion and Japanese Encephalitis outbreak in 1995, the Government has agreed to strengthen AQIS activity in Northern Australia, including the NAQS program

‐ additional resources totalling $14.6m have been provided for a range of activities over the next three and a half years to June 1999, including increased scientific effort, increased resourcing for Torres Strait and Cape York quarantine border activity, and an expansion of public awareness.

NAQS is collaborating with QDPI in developing an on‐going containment strategy for the papaya fruit fly and other exotic fruit flies in the Torres Strait, under the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management (SCARM) auspices. The program is to be carried out by NAQS, under contract from QDPI which retains the primary responsibility for response to incursions. NAQS is developing projects to address the risks posed by other high‐risk pests such as red‐banded mango caterpillar, mango weevil and banana skipper. Research projects are being commissioned into monitoring and detection methods for Japanese encephalitis, screw‐worm fly and Asian honey bee.

In addition, the SCARM has established a Task Force on Incursion Management to identify key exotic pests for which surveillance is to be undertaken and develop early warning systems and to update emergency response plans to manage exotic plant and animal disease incursions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8: Other matters relating to quarantine were raised during the Committee's hearings in Cairns. The Committee considers that these matters deserve further consideration and therefore recommends that AQIS:
. investigate whether it is appropriate and feasible to establish a quarantine post at the Jardine River, Far North Queensland;
. note concerns that a road block for traffic traveling north from Cairns to Cape York has not been established; and
. ensure that Commonwealth departments with responsibility for land management issues, including wilderness and native title, are aware of relevant quarantine concerns and strategies.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : In considering whether to establish a quarantine control point at the Jardine River, it is relevant that the river itself is not a natural barrier to birds, insects and other animals which either fly or swim across or can walk across in the Dry.

With the strengthening of quarantine operations in the Torres Strait and Northern Peninsular region it is not considered that a checkpoint at the Jardine River would be required for international quarantine reasons. Notwithstanding this, a major public information campaign funded by AQIS is in place in the Northern Peninsular area involving FM radio announcements, brochure distribution, announcements on ferries and signage in campgrounds.

The Queensland Government is responsible for intra State quarantine issues. They advise that papaya fruit fly (PFF) road‐block inspections at Laura, on Cape York Peninsular Development Road, began stopping motorists heading south through the road‐block from August 16 1996 to further restrict the possible movement of plant pests and diseases from the Peninsular area. The inspectors are presently undergoing training to enable them to detect high risk fruits, plants and plant material. The move was prompted by the recent detection of black sigatoka disease in banana plants at Weipa and industry concerns that the disease could inadvertently be transported to major growing areas.
AQIS has written to Commonwealth departments and agencies responsible for land management issues, including wilderness and native title, alerting them to relevant quarantine matters and strategies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9: The Committee recommends that, as a matter of priority, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy establish a task force, comprising relevant government officers, industry groups, in particular representatives of the meat industry, union officials and other relevant parties to identify and address critical issues in industrial relations between industry and AQIS with a view to achieving a co‐operative working relationship based on efficiency, flexibility, trust and good‐will.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: The Government is committed to reform of AQIS's meat inspection program to ensure it delivers an efficient and effective service to industry. A statement outlining future processes for implementing the necessary reforms is attached (Attachment C).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10: The Committee recommends that, as a matter of priority, AQIS carry out its commitment to the Committee to extend workshops on client focus to all staff. The effectiveness of these programs, particularly in relation to the prevention of situations such as developed at the Traralgon abattoir, should be closely monitored and, where necessary, follow up programs should be instituted and the Committee informed of the results to enable it to make its own assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : There are five major elements to AQIS's Client Focus Program of which client focus workshops are one element. The program also included a client feedback system, the development of a charter of service, client surveys, workshops and assisting clients to improve their access to export markets.

In March 1994, the then Minister announces the implementation of the Client Feedback system. AQIS has distributed over 20,000 pamphlets to clients encouraging their use of the system. The system allows clients to have direct access to senior departmental and AQIS management, where they feel this is necessary. Most matters referred to AQIS, however, have been able to be dealt with effectively by the relevant senior managers in AQIS's regional operations. The AQIS Client Feedback pamphlet was recently updated and re‐released in September 1996.

The second element of the client focus program is the development of a charter of service for AQIS. This will reflect AQIS's commitment to its industry clients in relation to its services and document performance standards by which AQIS services can be judged. The charter had been developed in general framework form and is currently being redrafted into more program specific forms to include commitments specific to AQIS service units which establish both quantifiable as well as qualitative service standards.

The third element of the client focus program is a process of formal client surveys. These provide a structured process of feedback on aspects of AQIS's operations. An initial pilot survey of the export meat industry and import brokers was conducted during 1994.

During 1995 and 1996, these surveys were split into 3 phases. Phase 1 involved fish (land‐based), dairy, eggs, dried fruit, poultry and domestic meat industries and was completed in September 1995. Phase 2 involves imported foods, customs agents, import clearance and live animals. The final report from this phase should be completed by the end of November 1996. Phase 3 involves horticulture, grains and export meat and is expected to commence in November 1996.

The fourth element of the client focus program are staff workshops and training. During November and December 1994, 270 staff participated in pilot workshops to improve their understanding of what the client focus program is all about and to assist the development of a charter of service. They were also to provide the basis for future training for all staff and the development of associated training materials.

The client focus kits developed as training materials for these workshops have been updated. The kits provide a resource tool for senior managers throughout AQIS to use in an integrated way during the course of regular training and development activities.

In addition, competency based training programs have been developed for quarantine inspection staff who have transferred from State to Commonwealth based employment during the last twelve months and for new recruits. This course incorporates several modules on important elements in providing better quality service to AQIS clients. These include Communication Skills (21 hrs formal training and 10 hrs on‐the‐job training); Conflict Management, Negotiation and Liaison Skills (14 hrs formal training and 14 hrs on‐the‐job training) and Client Service Delivery (7 hrs formal training and 14 hrs on‐the‐job training).

An important part of AQIS's initial training and development activities in relation to client focus activities had been to concentrate on fraud and ethics training for all field based staff. This has been undertaken by the Business Ethics and Security Investigations Unit (BESIU) of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It covers the Australian Public Service `Guidelines of Official Conduct' and uses tailored case studies to examine such issues as conflict of interest and acceptance of gifts and benefits. A pilot course was conducted in SA in late 1995—with full implementation of the course commencing in January 1996. To date, over 400 staff have participated in the training. It is intended to deliver the training to the remaining AQIS staff within the next eight months.

The fifth element of the client focus program is a more pro‐active approach to assisting Australian industries gain or improve access to export markets. It involves sitting down with particular industries to identify technical barriers to Australian exports and assisting them to work through importing country requirements. This is being reinforced with additional resources going into the `Supermarket to Asia' concept. The Government has agreed to provide funding to AQIS for this program to the extent of $2 million per year over the next three years. AQIS will allocate these funds to technical market access activities and other identified priority issues. Some resources will also be devoted to stationing AQIS officers in Asia to implement and facilitate the program on the ground.
The continued implementation of a client focus program along the lines outlined represents an integrated response to the Committee's recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11: The Committee recommends that the Government undertake a review of staffing and resource levels, so that the integrity of Australia's quarantine and inspection services can be maintained. The Committee also makes specific recommendations on staffing and resources in relation to scientific and technical expertise, and international liaison.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Committee reported, the Government has
‐ allocated an additional $14.6 million to enhance scientific, technical and operational resources in Northern Australia over the period to 1998‐99;

‐ increased funding for the Airports program to enhance quarantine security from the $11.054 million allocated by the former Government in the 1995‐96 Budget to $14.325 million in 1996‐97 rising to $16.359 million in 1999‐2000;

‐ allocated an extra $6 million over the next three years from 1996‐97 to employ additional scientific and technical staff to address technical barriers to market access for Australian exports into Asia.
Other resources issues will be considered, as necessary, when the Nairn Committee has reported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12: The Committee recommends that AQIS develop and maintain more effective channels of communication to on‐site inspectors, ensuring that they are routinely informed of the outcomes of the investigation of matters raised by them and whatever remedial action has been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Response : Agreed. AQIS, through its Compliance program has implemented a variety of systems to improve communications with on‐site inspectors in relation to feedback on incident reports lodged. These enhanced systems include new written notifications, a regular Compliance newsletter and more emphasis on personal contact and understanding between Compliance and Inspectorial staff.

When an incident report is lodged with the Compliance program by on‐site inspectors, the Regional Compliance Manager acknowledges receipt in writing to the on‐site AQIS officer. Often Compliance staff and inspection staff discuss these issues over the telephone or meet in person to clarify and progress resolution of incident reports.

The Compliance program is also working to improve interpersonal communications through an enhanced approach to investigation of incidents which indicate the existence of systemic problems. Compliance staff are more often working directly with on‐site inspection staff in investigations or providing assistance at operational task groups.

A Compliance newsletter has been developed and is distributed fortnightly to each of the program groups. The newsletter covers items of interest, prosecution results and general items of interest concerning investigation and Compliance activity. This newsletter has been well received by field staff.

All AQIS staff must ensure that communication processes are continually improved as the organisation moves from the traditional command control inspection systems to the new team based quality and HACCP based systems. Whilst the Compliance program is working to ensure feedback to inspection staff the requirements of the criminal justice system must be complied with and the integrity of the privacy of clients protected.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13: The Committee recommends that AQIS urgently review how its procedures and performance contributed to the adverse findings of the US Food Safety & Inspection Service review of Australian export meat establishments. The Committee further recommends that the implementation of the results of this review must be given the highest priority to ensure continuing and sustained operational compliance to Australian Export Meat Orders and overseas requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Consequent to the USDA review of November/December 1995 AQIS immediately met with the Australian meat processing industry and developed a comprehensive Scheme for Corrective Action (SCA) which contains modified procedures and some new procedures with immediate and long term objectives. The essential elements of the SCA are :

‐ the use of performance triggers to identify establishments with apparent performance problems which are then subjected to intensified AQIS review and categorised according to findings. The results can be delistment, suspension of all or part of export operations, on review classification, or acceptable. Classification other than acceptable requires a detailed Corrective Action Plan.
‐ introduction of improved product and process monitoring systems
‐ awareness training for industry and AQIS staff on all aspects of the SCA and quality assurance (QA) systems (including HACCP)
‐ integration of systems so that they are compatible with ARMCANZ decision's mandating the introduction of HACCP‐based QA systems in the meat industry and the USDA `mega‐reg' requirements; and
‐ evaluation of AQIS performance and determination of its contribution to any deficiencies in compliance.

The elements of the SCA will be monitored in conjunction with industry. Performance triggers have been tightened after the initial intensified review activity to levels that are now being used on an ongoing basis.

In relation to AQIS performance, training of all key AQIS personnel has almost been completed. It has been conducted jointly with key industry staff thereby ensuring all parties receive the same message to assist in achieving consistency and sustainability.
ATTACHMENT A
Australian Quarantine Review Committee
Membership Details
Professor Malcolm Nairn: Chairman; Vice Chancellor—Northern Territory University 1989‐96; Dean of the School of Veterinary Studies at Murdoch University
Andrew Inglis: Operates a mixed grain and grazing property in South Australia; current Chair of the Grains Research and Development Committee; Member of the Australian Wheat Board
Carolyn Tanner: Senior Lecturer in Agricultural Economics, Sydney University
Peter Allen: Entomologist; Member of the South Australian Animal and Plant Control Commission
ATTACHMENT B
Terms of Reference—Australian Quarantine Review Committee
The Committee's terms of reference are to:
Review Australia's animal and plant quarantine policies and programs having regard to:
(a) the advantageous animal and plant health status which Australia has and the benefits and costs which flow from preserving that status;
(b) Australia's international obligations;
(c) trade impact of Australian quarantine policies; and
(d) environmental considerations.
Make recommendations on:
(a) any appropriate revisions in Australia's animal and plant quarantine policy framework;
(b) revisions to the quarantine risk assessment process, including the potential for greater use of quantitative methods of assessment;
(c) the capacity for existing quarantine programs to deliver the requisite level of quarantine protection determined by the Government;

(d) the adequacy of existing consultative processes to ensure that industry and community groups are appropriately informed and their views taken into account in policy development and program delivery; and
(e) the appropriate balance between cost‐recovered and community service funded program elements.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor General:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report No. 14 of 1996‐97—Performance Audit—Evaluation Process for the Shared Systems Suite: Office of Government Information Technology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 347th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled Annual Report 1995‐96 . I seek leave to have my tabling speech incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
I am pleased to have the opportunity to table the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' Annual Report for 1995‐96.
This report has been prepared as a means of reporting to the parliament on the activities and performance of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) during 1995‐96.

The report covers work done by the current JCPA, which was appointed on 29 May 1996, at the commencement of the 38th parliament, and work done by the JCPA which operated during the 37th parliament (under the chairmanship of Mr Les Scott).

The period July 1995 to January 1996 was an extremely busy period for the former JCPA: inquiries were undertaken and reports prepared on accrual accounting, cash management, the administration of specific purpose payments, whole of government reporting and fiscal reporting legislation.
In addition, the JCPA:
examined the reports presented by the Commonwealth Auditor‐General in the financial years 1993‐94 and 1994‐95;
monitored the work of the Tax Law Improvement Project;
commenced a review of legislation to replace the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 ; and
held hearings on the draft Taxpayers' Charter prepared by the Australian Taxation Office.
In the period since its reappointment the JCPA has:
presented a report on its review of the audit reports presented in 1993‐94 and 1994‐95;
prepared a report on the new income tax assessment legislation; and
commenced a review of the audit reports presented in 1995‐96.
In my view the committee's reports have made constructive contributions to a range of significant matters in public administration. In particular the committee's work has resulted in:
renewed efforts to introduce commercial accounting principles and practices throughout the Commonwealth public sector;
the preparation of whole of government accrual based financial reports; and
agreement by the Government to reform the Commonwealth's budgetary and fiscal reporting systems.

In addition, reports from the JCPA have led to many less visible changes in accounting policies and procedures, both within individual agencies which have been the subject of JCPA inquiry, and across the Australian Public Service.

These are significant achievements and I would like to thank my colleagues on the committee, in particular the chairman, Mr Alex Somlyay, and the secretariat staff for their contributions to the work of the committee.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate in the Income Tax Rates Amendment (Family Tax Initiative) Bill 1996 and the Family (Tax Initiative) Bill 1996.
Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Gallery of Australia has recently been in the news because Mrs Howard took Mrs Clinton there yesterday and Betty Churcher showed Mrs Clinton around the gallery. The National Gallery is a public building that we can bring visitors from overseas to with some pride—the same as this building in which we are now legislating, which you, Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds, have adorned so well over the years, as has Senator West, Senator Watson, Senator Panizza, Senator Foreman and Senator Woodley, and as Senator Hogg will.

SPEECH.PARA: Public buildings symbolise the public estate. Great public buildings symbolise a nation and are, therefore, to be kept in mind, praised and elevated as much as we can. They symbolise the public nature of our community. There is too much time and attention paid these days to private assets. We think the big thing is to own the bigger car and the bigger house—that what we own as private people is what we should have pride in.I think that is against community spirit in a subtle or perhaps not so subtle way.

We ought to bring to mind that public buildings are, in a certain sense, what the nation is judged by—for example, the Eiffel Tower, Westminster Hall in London and the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We ought to concentrate on these things more than we do because they are the symbol of our identity as a nation and as a people rather than looking too much at what we own privately. When we concentrate only on private ownership, what we are doing is concentrating on what is, in a certain sense, selfish and limited and on what does not have that expansiveness that we should have as a nation of people.

I speak to this report on the National Gallery of Australia because the National Gallery of Australia, along with many other symbols, shows that we can have pride as a community, that we can work as a community and that we can expend public monies on things that give us pride as a nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Housing and Regional Development

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I will briefly comment that we will no longer be seeing any major, significant financial reports from that part of that department called Regional Development because it was basically abolished by this government in July‐August this year. It just indicates the commitment that this coalition has to regional development—no care and no consideration. It was done in a most callous, off‐hand way; they reduced the staff from 220 to six. It has a budget now of $5 million but we do not know what the criterion is for how that budget will be expended. I am still waiting for questions on notice to be answered to explain what that criterion is going to be.

Now the department disagrees with me and they disagreed with me during the estimates hearing when I asked how they could continue to maintain the name of the Department of Transport and Regional Development when, in fact, they had abolished the Regional Development. They informed me, `No, Senator, there were still six staff there; so there is a presence but it is a minute one.' How you can have part of a department's title for six people is quite beyond me but what the impact is going to be on rural and regional areas of this country has yet to be estimated.

The regional development program it had undertaken was getting regions together—getting groups of councils and interested people active and involved and caring about their communities and working out the priorities for the development and the future of their region. That has ceased. The funding to those organisations has been cut back dramatically. In a very short time, some of them will be running out of funding and not be up for any recurrent funding.

That is the callous, uncaring sort of attitude you see from this government . You see it very clearly because we know that the National Party members are very concerned about regional development. We see their Liberal colleagues just walking right over them, taking no notice of them and abolishing things that are of benefit to the bush. The government is to be condemned for this. It is very sad when you read through the Senate estimates Hansard and discover just how the department was abolished, just how people were told they had no jobs and were going to be forced to take redundancies.

It happened when one afternoon the minister made the decision, went over and told the people. Some were away at staff development conferences. This is a great way to have staff development, to be told you are going to get the DCM—don't come Monday. It is very sad that department completed its wind‐up this week. When the announcement was made, the Public Service certainly attempted to get its support mechanisms there to help people. That did not happen until the next day, so people were forced to go home, to have to tell their families and their spouses and their friends that they were going to be without a job and they spent a night of wondering what their future was going to be.

When people lose jobs and people are retrenched, that is almost the same as losing a family member. People have to grieve but the people of this department were not allowed to. The minister did not give them adequate support to get on with the grieving as soon as they were told what their future was. That is something which the department and the coalition government are to be condemned for—that lack of caring and compassion for people whom they are putting off.

This program and people have been very good. The people have worked hard. The program has been very successful and has done good things for the bush but this government does not care and has abolished it. It is sad to see this financial statement come to this chamber for the last time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to pay a compliment to this particular council; I have to admit to being the Leader of the Opposition's representative on it. This is a little‐known organisation which performs a highly commendable role and actually does a great deal in fostering a better understanding of parliamentary systems within Australia and also overseas. This organisation has a number of counterparts overseas and fosters greater understanding and cooperation by the process of exchange visits. On a number of occasions you would have seen young people being shown around the building, functions being held for young people and opportunities for politicians to meet young people who are politically active in their own countries.

Ten years ago I had the honour to be part of a delegation of this council to the United States to observe the 1986 mid-term elections and, more particularly, to view the gubernatorial race that was taking place in the state of Kansas and the senatorial race taking place in the state of Missouri. This was an opportunity that I relished and I have benefited from greatly. That was the time that I actually learnt and understood how the American political system works and just how different it is to the Australian political system.

This visit was an opportunity to make friends with opposition members, members from the Democrats, the National Party and the Liberal Party—major political parties who send delegates. It was also an opportunity to make friends in the United States and to make contacts there. Several years later one of the people we met in Missouri came to Australia as a delegate from the United States political exchange program. It was delightful to be able to meet and greet a fellow friend, somebody we had met before. A few years after that the escort person from the United States—someone who had been our escort person when we had been in the states—came back to visit Australia. I was able to continue the relationship and the friendship with Andy when I visited and greeted him and his wife when I was in the States again last year.

It is this sort of meeting, greeting, understanding and getting to know people at a personal level that stands international harmony and goodwill in excellent stead. It is the sort of thing that we need more of, particularly as we are seeing so much these days one of the Independent members from the other House wanting to talk about differences that people have and differences in other countries. This program shows you their differences and their culture, but also the similarities and enables you to meet these people as friends and equals.

There are a number of countries involved in this program. The United States program has been going the longest. We are now building one with Japan. The Japanese were out earlier this year. We have had the German delegation here. Hopefully, shortly a delegation will be coming from the United Kingdom. We are also working to get delegations from Korea and a number of the South-East Asian countries.

As I said, this is a very important program because it provides people with the opportunity to mix and to greet and to understand. There have been many people from both sides of this parliament who have had the opportunity to travel to the other countries that are involved in this program.

This program works very closely. It is not all government funded. It is a program which also receives funding from the private sector. I think it is this mix of private and public sector involvement that also lends to it being a very vitally important program for the education and the greater understanding that parliamentarians and young political activists actually have in how politics works in other countries. It leads to a much greater understanding and important friendships and links between Australia and many overseas countries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority covers a very important organisation, which looks after one of the major wonders of the world in Australia. This organisation is responsible for maintaining the reef off the coast of Queensland in its pristine condition. I know that it is very dear to the heart of Senator Reynolds, a senator who resides in North Queensland and who shares my appreciation for the reef.

The sad part about this report is that the government has decided to change the structure of an environmental management charge which was previously levied by the Labor government. The charge was a nominal $1, which was devoted to research. Now we see that the government has moved away from that and is seeking to increase the charge. I believe it was recently reported that the charge would rise from $1 to $2 from 1 January 1997 and there would be an additional $4 charged from 1 January 1998.

This increase in the levy was seen by the government as being a compromise but, really, it is not a compromise for the tourist operators, as I understand it. It really leaves them in no better position than they were when the government first announced the increase in the levy. The tourist operators in the areas that I visited are particularly small operators and to bear any increased cost is fairly horrendous indeed.

The current proposal by the government in respect of the reef tax, as it has become known, is to see that increase phased in by 1 January 1998. If one looks at the packages that the tourist operators have out on the Great Barrier Reef, one sees that those packages have fixed prices until April 1998, some three to four months after the last $4 will apply. I believe that this has left a number of operators in that area fairly disconcerted and disillusioned with a government that had promised them earlier in the year, as part of its major election promise, that there would be no increase on taxes in the tourist industry.

It is with regret that one sees that happening and that one sees that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is going to have a major role as a tax collector rather than as an overseer, a purveyor, of the maintenance of the reef in its pristine condition. I see that this is a most unfortunate thing to be happening to this great authority. I think the authority has, over a period of time, shown its commitment to the environment, shown its commitment to the management of the reef and should not be in any way distracted from its major charter, which is the preservation and the maintenance of the reef in as pristine a state as one could reasonably expect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: —I would certainly endorse the comments of the previous speaker, my colleague Senator Hogg. This tax that has been imposed is a very discriminatory tax. It is a tax that has been directed at northern tourism but not southern tourism. Earlier in this debate Senator Cooney made some very appropriate remarks about the National Gallery, but I note that there is not a 500 per cent surcharge on visitors to the National Gallery. Nor would I advocate that, I would like to emphasise.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that we have a government that is treating tourist attractions in a discriminatory fashion. If it is good enough to impose a 500 per cent increase on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, if tourists visiting the reef have to pay that impost, why would we have differential standards for the National Gallery? It gets something in the order of $24 million for its running costs. I am a great supporter of the Australian National Gallery, but it is the discrimination between different types of tourist facilities dependent on where they are located that I find unacceptable.

The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is world renowned. It has an outstanding reputation in its field of research. The Great Barrier Reef Wonderland and Aquarium that operates from Townsville itself has run extremely effectively for many years now. It does not get the kind of financial assistance that the National Gallery, the Australian War Memorial or the Sydney Maritime Museum get.

Although Senator Ian Macdonald from North Queensland has recently been appointed as a parliamentary secretary—and it is welcome that the government has at last recognised that they need a voice from the north in cabinet—he seems to have been unable to influence Senator Hill to date in terms of amending this decision. The decision to phase in the 500 per cent increase is not the answer.

The question is: are we going to have a 500 per cent increase on all tourist attractions in Australia? Is that what we want? Is that reasonable? If the answer is no, it is no for the reef, it is no for the National Gallery and it is no for the War Memorial. It is not differential. It is okay for the reef, yet we have a different standard for other tourist attractions.

I am very regretful that it seems that the government is determined to press ahead. It will make it very difficult for some of the small operators. It is something that I find totally unacceptable because it is discriminatory. I do not believe that this government should be singling out the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for differential standards in terms of the imposition of this 500 per cent increase. It is in fact a tourist tax that applies only to tourists visiting North Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak on the issue of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I do not have quite the same appreciation of its work that the two previous senators who spoke had. I think they were a little over the top in their praise of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I think there are some problems with that authority, but the Democrats certainly do not want it to be abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: If it can be improved and if it can be funded properly, then certainly it will play a very important role in the future. It has played an important role in the past. There is no way we want what is happening at the moment to be a way in which the government can gut the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. That thought has crossed my mind. There is no way that the inquiry, which the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) has signalled, will be allowed to be simply a way of abolishing the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority or so rendering it ineffective that it might as well be abolished.

In terms of the reef tax, which is bound up with this whole issue, again, the Democrats hear the arguments put by the previous speakers. I am fairly swayed by them, but we still have one question in our mind—that is, ought not those who use the reef and those who do damage to the Great Barrier Reef also pay for its maintenance and upkeep? That is the question.

The problem with the proposal the government has made is that they are only fixing on one user; that is, tourists. They are an easy target. There is an obvious way of collecting the tax through them. What the Democrats would like to see is all people who impact on the reef contributing towards its maintenance and upkeep.

TALK.START.PARA: —Therein lies the dilemma.

—That is the dilemma exactly, Senator Hogg. That is why I am certainly tending towards the arguments you are putting in this debate. I have to say that the Democrats have not yet arrived at a final position, because we are wanting to hear the arguments on this whole debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The other concern I have is that these taxes—as with many of these taxes introduced by a government, supposedly to do a particular thing—are simply another revenue raising device, rather than being a device which will raise funds to protect the reef. Again, this is one of the problems when you connect something like a reef tax to funding for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. What you are really saying to the marine park authority is, `If you increase the number of tourists and collect more reef tax, you will be better off in terms of your own revenue.' That is a real catch-22.

I believe that kind of connection ought not be made. That device would make it too easy to interfere with the running of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and change its character from one which is given the task of protecting the reef to one which simply issues licences for more tourists. In fact, by that very device you increase the damage to the Great Barrier Reef.

So what I am saying is that we have some real concerns about what the government is doing in terms of this reef tax and its intention for the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in the future. We are concerned as to whether or not it really is going to take account of those members of the coalition in North Queensland who made a lot of noise about how they were going to turn this around and what they were going to do. In fact, it is pretty easy to roll the environment minister. I was surprised that he just did not roll over, because he seems to do it—

TALK.START.PARA: —He likes having his tummy tickled.

—I see. Is that the problem? He seems to roll over on most issues to do with the environment, but on this one they have not been able to get him to roll over. So that must say something about their influence in these kinds of decisions. I think Senator O'Chee is going to speak, so I will finish there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Senator Woodley. You have been gracious; however, I do intend to set you right on a few facts, Senator. They basically relate to the proposed changes to the environmental management charge.
—Tax.
—The environmental management charge, I hasten to advise honourable senators, was introduced by the then government—the Labor Party.
—Tax.

—Of course, at that point, Senator Reynolds, the Labor Party refused to call it a tax. You said it was a charge. I remember your defence of these matters very clearly. It was quite clearly the case that the Labor Party introduced it.

SPEECH.PARA: What the budget sought to do was quite similar. It sought to increase the charge to meet the increased cost of operating the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. The proposed increase was from $1 to $6. I make no bones about that fact. As a result of work that has been done—for example, by Mrs Kelly, the member for Dawson; Mr Neville, the member for Hinkler; Mr Entsch, the member for Leichhardt; and me—we went to the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and we said, `There are some problems. We really believe the first thing we should do is have a meeting with the industry and with the people who were affected.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You rolled over.

—Senator Conroy, of course, was not here when the Labor Party introduced the environmental management charge, because the Labor Party never bothered to talk to industry. Not once did the Labor Party consult with the tourism industry on anything that it did in North Queensland, because the Labor Party is full of people like Senator Conroy, who just make a decision from the blissful ignorance of Victoria or wherever they come from.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing we did was sit down with members from the industry. They said, `Thank goodness we have a government that is willing to discuss government decisions.' So that is the first thing that those on the other side of the chamber should bear in mind: that the industry accepts that this government is much better in terms of consultation than the Labor Party ever was or ever could dream of being. After all, let's face it: who would want to go to a consultation with some of the people we have on the other side? There are a few good senators on the other side. I will exempt them from that but, I tell you what, there are a lot of very poor ones on the other side as well.

The industry met with us. We organised a meeting in Brisbane with the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) and the minister responsible for tourism, Mr Moore. That meeting was also very successful. The industry asked for a number of things—and I do not think I am spilling the beans here. They asked for a review of the operations of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority; they asked that the charge be deferred or reduced; and they said they really believed it was important that the industry kept on talking to the minister.

So that process of consultation continued. Most importantly, the industry identified that they were willing to live with an increase in charge, provided they could defer it so that it did not impact on forward sales that they had already made or were committed to making.

I remember, for example, Ed Green from Reef 2005 phoning me up one evening and saying, `Look, Bill, the industry will be happy if you take this charge to just $2.50 next year.' I said, `Ed, it's a bit of an ask, but we'll do whatever we can.'
Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Conroy, you are welcome to phone Mr Green and ask him whether he suggested it should go to $2.50. The industry had a meeting about this and decided $2.50 would be reasonable for the 1997 calendar year. We brought it in at $2. From 1 January 1998—
—You are a double legend.
—It is less than what the industry thought would be reasonable. The industry got better than what they wanted, Senator Conroy. They certainly did not want to talk to you people.

SPEECH.PARA: We then said that we would bring in the rest of the increase on 1 January 1998, but separate it. The industry said that the Labor Party told them they were not allowed to separate the charge when it was in government, because the Labor Party would increase the charge again. That was the way the Labor Party operated. It was just thuggery. We said that we would allow them to separate the charge, and they will not be responsible for collecting it. Finally, the industry got what they wanted when we agreed that we would have a review into the operations of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to find ways to save money for the authority and for the operators. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This report is very timely. The report shows that there is going to be an increased amount of complaints over the next financial year. That is going to require an increase in funding for the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. It is a very important tribunal. I had spoken many times with the tribunal over the last four years of my life before I entered parliament. I am very concerned that, with the increase in the superannuation tax that this government has introduced—

TALK.START.PARA: —Another tax.

—That is right, Senator Woodley, another tax. This tax is really going to mean a lot of people are going to be disadvantaged. A lot of people are going to be forced to lose money because this government does not want to introduce a sensible administration scheme. That will mean a huge increase in the number of complaints at the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. It has no chance—no chance whatsoever—under the current funding levels of coping with that.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a steady increase. As this legislation has been used more and more by members of the funds, the demands on the complaints tribunal have been increasing. That is shown in the report. There will be further increases as more and more members of the funds are unfairly taxed because this government will not come to its senses and introduce the new tax via the PAYE system.

What is obvious to everyone but the government is that it should be levying this tax via the employer. It is a simple two-step process—the employer notifies the tax office of who is above the threshold and then the tax office advises the superannuation funds who the levy or tax should be put on. It is that simple. But the government has got itself in a real mess on this one. They cannot afford to do that. They have made this bogus promise that they were not going to increase taxes.

They have walked into government and have suddenly discovered that the one that applies to superannuation was not a core promise. It is one of the three out of 10 that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talked about—the three out of 10 where people have been forced to pay extra. We support that. We do not have a problem with that. But if you are going to administer it, you have got to do it fairly. There is no point in putting a tax on everybody to slug the 300,000. That is what is going to happen.

The Transport Workers Union fund has about 120,000 to 130,000 members, and not many of them will be up for the surcharge. But every one of them is going to be paying to find out who is. It may be only 1,000 members, but all 120,000 members are going to be affected. All of them are going to feel fairly aggrieved, and they have a right to be aggrieved. You have the situation where the complaints against funds must rise. People are going to start to ask questions about the way the funds are managed, the way that this unfair tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't come within the jurisdiction of the complaints tribunal.
—That is right—
