DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Chairman of the Senate of the Republic of Ireland

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with great sadness today that I learnt about the sudden death of Senator Liam Naughten, Chairman of the Irish Senate. Last month I was fortunate to lead a parliamentary delegation to Ireland. During our visit, we spent many enjoyable moments with Senator Naughten. The warmth of his welcome and his generous manner left an indelible impression on all delegation members.

BREAK.PARA: Just yesterday I received from Ireland a marvellous photograph of the delegation with Senator Naughten and the Speaker of the Irish parliament, Sean Treacy. That photograph brought back many fond memories of our visit. It is therefore very sad that, one day after receiving that photograph, I was told about Senator Naughten's tragic death through a motorcar accident.

Today I have written to the Speaker of the Irish parliament offering the delegation's deepest condolences. In that letter I indicated what a great loss Senator Naughten's death is for the Irish parliament and the Irish people. Anyone who has spent any time in the Irish parliament would know the high regard with which Senator Naughten was held. While his death is a great loss to the Irish people, it is an even greater loss to his family. I have asked the Irish Speaker to pass on the delegation's sympathies to Senator Naughten's widow, six sons and two daughters. In the times ahead, we can take some comfort from the fact that Senator Naughten was so highly regarded both at home and abroad.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: President of the United States of America

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the successful visit to Australia, including to Canberra yesterday, by President Clinton, the President of the United States of America. Overwhelmingly, we must all be very pleased with the success of the visit. It certainly demonstrated the close friendship and relationship that Australia and America have, both at a diplomatic governmental level and, above all, at a people level.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of matters, image wise, were small irritants on the side. The government mishandled the arrangements to invite a cross-section of Australian women to have a private meeting with Mrs Clinton in Sydney today. I do not think it looked good that invitations were hurriedly being reissued or issued today to such people as Senator Kernot, the Leader of the Australian Democrats. There is also the argument that, while it appeared that a balanced list was drawn up, there may have been a process whereby either the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), his wife or his office went through and added people to the list and took other people off it. There has been a rather unseemly side to that, which could have been avoided. I do not think that reflected well on us in Australia.

I also have to say that there are some other images about the visit that I personally thought—though others would disagree—were a bit out of date. I noticed that one article in the paper today commented on the fact that Mrs Howard and some of the spouses of government ministers wore gloves and hats, as in the 1950s. Maybe I resonate to that a bit, but others probably would not. Again, they are minor issues.

The issue I really want to raise is that of the speeches made by both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) on two public occasions yesterday. It has been reported in the press today by a number of commentators that they thought Mr Beazley's speeches were in many ways superior, had more emotion about them and were more memorable than the speeches by the Prime Minister. I got the transcript of both the speeches by Mr Beazley and the Prime Minister, Mr Howard.

We all acknowledge that Mr Howard is an excellent parliamentary debater. He is very good at speaking off the cuff. In jousting in parliament and in responding to interjections, he is as good as any parliamentarian. He is recognised on all sides as being an excellent parliamentary speaker. But it is clear that on occasions, such as the one we had yesterday, where he was speaking on behalf of all Australians, his reliance on being able to make a good speech off the cuff fails him and, therefore, Australia.

It is not the first time that people have commented on this. As Leader of the Opposition last year, he spoke off the cuff in his televised address in reply to Mr Keating's address about the theme of Australia as a republic. It is clear that Mr Howard is missing out on a number of opportunities to present Australia in a way that people, including our guests here, such as President Clinton and Mrs Clinton, would regard as memorable. It seems to me that the Prime Minister should not rely on making speeches off the cuff on such occasions. He should, as Mr Beazley did yesterday, prepare a speech and speak to it. He should memorise it, if necessary. He should have a speech that has some memorable phrases and images in it.

One noticed yesterday that Mr Beazley, in his speech at the luncheon, mentioned his knowledge of, and interest in, American history. He said that President Clinton was the first Democrat President elected from the south for two terms since Appomattox. He also mentioned General MacArthur in his speech to parliament in the House when welcoming Mr Clinton. He also used the occasion to reassert our interest in President Clinton's commitment to a non-racist society, et cetera. That was all done in a quite appropriate and very effective way, with people saying that they were memorable images.

In both his speeches, the President, without doubt one of the most effective personal communicators of any politician in the world today, spoke from notes, but he did it in a way that made it appear he was speaking off the cuff. He is very skilled at that. He mentioned in his speech at the lunch that Benjamin Franklin had given a special order that Captain Cook was not to be interfered with by the American navy at the time of the War of American Independence because Captain Cook was recognised as a major explorer. Again, in his own speech in the chamber, on several occasions he touched everybody by raising a level of emotion and commitment on issues that everyone would feel strongly about.

It seems to me—I do not want to be accused of partisanship, although I will because I am a Labor senator—that there was nothing memorable in the Prime Minister's remarks. There was nothing memorable that would be recorded and taken down as a direct quote. There was nothing that people would say reflected the occasion. There was nothing that in several years would be remembered or recorded and replayed.

I call on the Prime Minister to stop trying to make off the cuff speeches on such occasions. He should at least prepare a speech and give it great thought. With the help of staff, et cetera, he should work through it properly so that it reflects well not only on him as Prime Minister but on all Australians, as he is our Prime Minister. The Prime Minister should accept the fact that, on such occasions, speaking off the cuff in a parliamentary style is not appropriate. You cannot interject on the Prime Minister at such occasions. You cannot rely on the robust nature of a parliamentary forum styled in the Westminster system to create life. In your speech, you have to create your own images and points of contact with the audience.

I thought both of the Prime Minister's speeches yesterday reflected his competence in welcoming somebody but did not represent the significance of the occasion. The occasion was only the third visit of an American president to Australia in our history. It is only the second occasion when an American president has addressed both houses together. It is also an occasion where a major luncheon was held, with over 600 people present. It was an occasion when the remarks made by all speakers—both Mr Howard and Mr Beazley, and the President—were recorded on television and played around Australia. Segments would certainly have been played overseas, including in America. I wonder what grab or section of the speeches that Mr Howard made people will remember.

Some might say it is gratuitous advice by a member of the opposition, but I do think that Australia is not getting good value from our Prime Minister, who thinks that the best way to do this, because he is a good parliamentary debater, is to speak off the cuff on such occasions. I think he should have spent time with appropriate staff writing speeches. Remember that the great speeches of all time that we recognise—whether they are from Lincoln, Churchill or even his own political mentor, Mr Menzies—were not memorable speeches off the cuff; they worked at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —They crafted them.

—That is a good word. They crafted them. They rewrote them. They pencilled in additions and deletions. That is how they did the great speeches. That is why they are memorable. None of us, no matter how good we are, can make speeches off the cuff, no matter how much material we have around us.

SPEECH.PARA: You need time to craft the memorable phrase that sinks in and that resonates with the audience. I think the Prime Minister would do better in the future to work at crafting a good speech, because, when he speaks on such occasions, he speaks for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw attention to the ramifications and the effect that one of the announced budget measures is now about to have. It is the one in the health budget to make cuts of $75 million to compensate for cost shifting between the states and the federal government in the sector of health care.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a recognised thing that, over the years, cost shifting from the state governments to the federal sector has occurred. Nobody denies it. It is very difficult however to quantify. That is something that we attempted to elicit during the estimates procedures. We wanted to know what procedure was undertaken to measure what was cost shifting and what were, in fact, the normal increases that would be expected to be occurring as we have an ageing population and we wanted to know the impact of an ageing population upon our health care system, which will see an increase in that happening. Certainly, at estimates we were told that the minister—and this was at the end of September or early October—had not yet determined the basis on which the adjustments to the Medicare hospital funding grants for individual states and territories would be calculated.

We have been told that there was some methodology to be used. The methodology to be used to derive an estimate for the cost shifting was to calculate the growth rate in services per capita in each state and Australia from 1994‐95 to 1995‐96 and to calculate a new national average growth in services per capita for 1995-96, excluding the two high growth rate states of Victoria and Western Australia. It goes on with some further calculations to be undertaken. Using the above method, an amount of $75.2 million was calculated for cost shifting in 1995-96.

This week we saw the results of that exercise. As I just said, the two high growth rate states were Victoria and Western Australia. Which is the state that has copped the slug in this $75 million cut? It is the state of New South Wales. I know we are the most populous state, but we are not the state in the last 18 months that has been indulging heavily in cost shifting. In the last 18 months we have had a Labor government in that state, and that government has endeavoured to abide by the spirit of the agreements. But, for its troubles in the last 18 months, New South Wales is being cut by $34 million. That $34 million is for this financial year. This financial year is one‐quarter or more over. This means that this state is going to have to find $600,000-odd per week from its health budget to just maintain current services.

I do not know how that is possible, because $34 million equates to something like the treatment of 17,200 patients, 400 hospital beds and 900 doctors and nurses. This state cannot afford to suffer this. But what is Victoria's cut going to be? It is one of the big ones that is into cost shifting. It is going to be cut by $24 million. Queensland is going to be cut by $5 million, Western Australia is going to be cut by $9 million and Tasmania is going to be cut by $3 million. Something shonky has gone on here. We heard in evidence in estimates that the two biggest cost shifters in recent times are Victoria and Western Australia. What are they doing? It looks to me very much like New South Wales is being penalised because it is the only state that has a Labor government. The rest have all got their friends up here, as they are the same colour as the states.

We know that New South Wales was a big cost shifter when this was first highlighted in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Who was in power from 1988 to 1995 in New South Wales? It was the coalition. They are having two bob each way. They have had it in New South Wales, where they attacked the system. They ran down the system, they cost shifted and they did not abide by agreements. You get a change of government and they are abiding by agreements, but they are of a different political colour from who is now in Canberra.

What in fact is happening is that cost shifting. We are being penalised in New South Wales by a Liberal government for the sins of a previous Liberal government. It is not at all fair. It is not the way to be running a health system.

When we have asked for the calculations, we have been told that there is no real way to get information about cost shifting because allegedly nobody admits to it, and I suggest that is fairly accurate. But we know from the Senate estimates procedures that the two big cost shifters are Victoria and Western Australia. I suppose they do not want to talk about the Western Australian one too much because it is in the middle of a state election. I wonder whether Western Australia has received its letter.

The letter came into effect in New South Wales at the beginning of this week. New South Wales received the letter, I understand, only late last week. The first instalment was 19 November. The first time the government heard of the precise amount of this cut was in a letter to a New South Wales health officer last Friday. There was not even the decency for it to be minister to minister; it was health officer to health officer. So the biggest state in this country has been treated rather shabbily.

You have to also remember that this is just another health cut that this budget is indulging in. The government has already cut the dental health program by $36 million. We tried valiantly today to get that money back, but we were unable to. There is the $7 million efficiency cut. There is the slashing of special purpose programs, such as women's health, which has copped a $5 million cut. These are the sorts of things that have been happening.

I cannot understand why Victoria has a cut that is $10 million less than New South Wales. When you are dealing with those figures, the populations of New South Wales and Victoria are not that different. When you are dealing with the fact that that is the government of the state that is now into big cost shifting, then you see that what has happened is pretty shonky and pretty rotten.

In 1995-96 the Medicare payments in New South Wales rose by 1.2 per cent. That can be attributed to the ageing of the population and not to cost shifting. Since 1995, the Labor government of that state has honoured its commitment to public hospitals and increased the funding to health by $632 million. The New South Wales Labor government share of the health budget has risen from 46 per cent to 49.7 per cent. It is now being expected to foot more of the bill. What has happened is disgraceful and shameful.

There is no way I can see any explanation of how this formula was worked out and why, when they were working out the parts of the formula that we have seen, the methodology, they have excluded the two high growth states: Victoria and Western Australia. I could ask my colleagues here who are from those two states precisely how their Liberal coalition state governments are eroding the health systems there. We in New South Wales, with the Labor state government, do not want to go down that path; we do not want to see those sorts of things happen.

But it is quite apparent that the federal coalition government wants to see New South Wales have to erode its health services. When you are asking the state to cut $34 million out of its health budget, you have to look at the implications and the impact that is going to have upon health in that state. It is pretty appalling that we are being expected—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to say how disappointed I was today that there was no debate on the Commonwealth dental health program and the cuts which will remove that. The cutting of funding to this program is perhaps the most short-sighted and poorly considered decision to be made by any health minister in recent years. It is a decision which is not only going to have a damaging effect on the dental health of many Australians but also ultimately going to cost this government money.

BREAK.PARA: There can be little doubt that the Commonwealth dental health scheme was—and we need to use that word now—cost effective and efficient. It provided a limited range of services to a tightly targeted population, and I think it has been very clear that we are not talking about a middle-class welfare.

The program is limited to health care card holders and it aims to improve their access to dental care with the long-term goal of—in the words of Kaye Roberts from the University of Adelaide—`moving patterns of care from emergency to basic, from extraction to restoration and from treatment to prevention'. This scheme was introduced by the previous government after the national health strategy found that while low income earners did not have a higher rate of dental decay than the rest of the community they were twice as likely to have all their teeth extracted and that in middle age they were five times as likely to have a tooth extracted and less likely to have received a filling.

Similarly, the 1994 evaluation project for the Commonwealth dental health program showed that nearly one in 10 health card holders aged 65 years or more no longer had any natural teeth, compared with just over one in four non-card holders. The cause of this staggering difference in dental health was, according to the national health strategy, unequal access to dental care, with low income earners delaying dental treatment because of the cost and seeking dental care only as a relief from pain. The strategy found that, while in the general community 50 per cent of people received dental treatment at least once a year, public dental services were treating only 14 per cent of low income earners, and then that was mostly for pain relief.

This is the data which underpinned the setting up of the dental health scheme. That is what this scheme is about: getting people to the dentist before the pain becomes unbearable, before the decay goes too far and while they still have a chance of saving their teeth. But the value of the scheme extends beyond that personal level. As Mike Morgan of the Association for the Study of Community Dentistry wrote in a letter to the Age shortly after the budget:

From recent NHMRC estimates, the long‐term cost borne by the community for the treatment of dental disease is higher than the cost of treating the effects of diseases such as heart disease, diabetes and most cancers . . . Loss of a program specifically designed to reduce dental costs and eliminate pain makes no economic sense and precious little humanitarian sense.

What will happen to those unemployed people who had their teeth repaired under this scheme in order to increase their job prospects, for instance, in order to look more respectable for interviews? What happens now to homeless people in Kings Cross who were treated as part of this program after a survey showed that 85 per cent of them had dental problems including decay, toothache and abscesses? What about the boarding house residents, people with mental illness and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in remote areas—all of whom received care under this program?

I will tell you what is going to happen to these people.Within 12 or 18 months we will be back to the same level of crisis as we had in 1994 when this scheme was first introduced. We will be back to months or even years of waiting for basic dental care and we will be back to public dental care meaning emergency care with high numbers of extractions and very low numbers of fillings.

It is very clear that, at the end of the day, the states and our public hospitals will not be able to cope with the demand for basic dental services following this cut. And what is more, the government, it seems to me, does not appear to be particularly concerned about what will be the likely outcome. When Senator Lees, my colleague who is responsible for this portfolio, asked the department during estimates committee hearings just how the withdrawal of around 40 per cent of public dental funds was going to contribute to the efficiency of Australia's health system and the dental health of Australians generally, this was the response:
It is anticipated that the States will continue their traditional role of providing public dental services and will allocate their programs an appropriate funding priority.

It was a bit difficult to see just how the department could actually make that blithe assumption given that, at another point during the estimates, it also told the committee that it had undertaken no formal consultations with the states as to what their plans might be.

The fact of the matter is that the Commonwealth dental health program was set up in the first place precisely because the states were not providing an adequate service for low income earners. It is a bit much to be coming in here now and arguing that that same program can be abolished simply because it is the traditional responsibility of the states to provide dental services to low income earners. That is clearly not good enough.

I remind honourable senators that they have just passed legislation authorising the Commonwealth to take back responsibility for child immunisation from the states for this very same reason: they just were not doing their job properly. Yet we have the same minister wanting to wash his hands of the responsibility for dental health and to duckshove it back onto the states without giving them any additional funds with which to cope with such a service.
One further point I want to draw to the attention of senators is that, in estimates, the department made this important acknowledgment:

In general terms it should be noted that the reduction in Commonwealth dental health program funding will result in less emphasis being applied to strategies which focus on increasing access by special groups—as there will be reduced resources for caring for these clients.

The special groups to which the department is referring are homeless young people, people with intellectual disabilities, Aboriginal people, the survivors of torture and people living in remote areas. By the department's own admission, that is who will be most hurt by the decision to end this funding. That is why the Democrats were requesting the House to reverse this decision and that is why we would like to see every single coalition backbencher stand up and be counted on this particular funding cut.

With so much at stake, it is not good enough for the government to hide behind the excuse that there was a budget black hole which, somehow, had to be filled. If that is the argument which coalition senators and members want to use, then perhaps they can also offer their constituents an explanation as to why the government can find $500 million to spend on private health rebates, most of which will go straight back into the pockets of the private health funds, but, at the same time, it cannot find $130 million to ensure that disadvantaged Australians do not live in pain, do not have to wait 12 months or more to see a dentist and do not lose their teeth because they cannot get decent dental care.

The impact of this bill on dental health will be instant and it will be destructive. There is no alternative. The states will not pick it up—we all know that. Had there been debate today, I would have implored the government to look at this measure again. If there is any single item in this budget package, the appropriation bills, that should have been reconsidered, it is this. The Commonwealth dental health program ought to have been supported in this house and in the other house and I think we owe it to a great many Australians to now explain why it is that Australia cannot afford this program.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Dental Health SchemeDeath of Chairman of Senate of the Republic of Ireland

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with what Senator Allison has said—that the abolition of the dental health program is one particular initiative that will come back and bite the government later on.
—It can't. No teeth left!

—There will be a lot of teeth on this one, Senator Conroy. Once the electorate really do find out the impact of this very regressive measure, they will be taking it out on the people who sit on the opposite side of this chamber. I did not stay for the adjournment tonight to gnash teeth about the matters that were contained in the budget. But, unfortunately, my contribution to the budget debate had to be put to one side because of the mismanagement of the legislative program by the government—we really were in a shemozzle this afternoon in this chamber and, of course, the people in the other place had to wait around until we finished deliberating in very quick time the matters that it contained. That really is not the right way to do things on matters as important as the cuts to programs that Senator Allison has mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: My task tonight is to add to the words of the President of the Senate just after question time and to the words of Senator John Watson earlier tonight in this adjournment debate to express some sympathies to the colleagues and family of Senator Liam Naughten, the Chairman of the Senate of the Republic of Ireland. Senator Naughten died in a car accident on 16 November aged 52, the same age as me.

It was not so long ago—indeed, over 12 months ago—that Senator Liam Naughten sat alongside the then President of the Senate in this very chamber when he visited our country as the leader of the parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Ireland. I had occasion to meet him, as did many of my Senate and House of Representatives colleagues. I found him to be a particularly warm human being, a very relaxed individual, which was surprising when one found out that he and his wife, Mary, had eight children between them. As a father of three, I found it amazing that someone could keep their humour and personality with that number of offspring to look after, particularly as some had passed their teenage years and some were approaching. But he was a wonderful human being, and I was shocked when I heard the news of his all too early demise.

I have been able to obtain a copy of the obituary that appeared in the Times from the Internet, which is relayed into this building. I want to quote from part of that obituary. Liam Naughten was unique in many respects in that he served in both houses of the Irish parliament. He first went into the Senate, which has a different method of electing senators than we have this country. Sometimes it is easier and sometimes for some it is even more difficult to get a seat in the Senate. He served in the Senate and was later elected to the lower house, the Dail, the House of Representatives over there. The obituary reads:

He lost his Dail seat in 1989 in a bitter battle that became legend. He and John Connor, his Fine Gael running mate, were neck‐and‐neck for the last place in the three‐seat constituency. The votes were counted and recounted for three days. The whole county waited for the news.
This is two colleagues from the same political party battling for the seat. The obituary continues:
Naughten lost the seat by one vote.

But, in keeping with Naughten's gentle but resilient personality, the two men did not remain enemies for long. He was known for his friendship across the political divides and was close to John Bruton, the current and present Taoiseach. He was loved for his warmth and modesty by the people from all walks of life. He listened carefully and understood everybody's point of view.

He was re‐elected to the Seanad in 1989 by county councils around Ireland. He sat on the agriculture panel and became deputy chairman of the body almost immediately. He took over the chairmanship last year following the death of Sean Fallon, his friend and neighbour from Fianna Fail, the other side of Irish politics.
There are many sides in Irish politics, like there are here. The article continues:
His election as cathaoirleach was a unanimous one.

His greatest political moment came in November 1995 when President Clinton visited Ireland. Naughten formally thanked the President for addressing both Houses of the Oireachtas or Irish Parliament. It was a moment in Irish history that, understandably, made the Roscommon farmer very proud.

I am sure it made his wife, Mary, and his six sons and two daughters proud to see him in that very noble position and in undertaking the task of welcoming President Clinton to Ireland and to the Irish parliament.

BREAK.PARA: He will be sadly missed by his wife, Mary, who accompanied him to Australia on the delegation lastyear. Indeed, he will be sadly missed by his colleagues in the Irish Senate and in the whole of the Irish parliament. There is a notice of motion on the books, as the President referred to in her contribution to the chamber after question time. Hopefully, on Monday when this Senate resumes it will be carried unanimously. Our sympathies can then be conveyed to the parliament of the Republic of Ireland and onto Senator Liam Naughten's family.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 8 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff, other than staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, were employed in or attached to the office(s) of the Minister and each of his or her Parliamentary Secretaries as at Tuesday, 8th October 1996.
(2) What were the total salary costs of such staff.
(3) What was the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of such staff.
(4) What were the titles, roles and duties of such staff and what public service (or equivalent) classifications did they carry.
(5) Under what programs were they employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 8 October there were two staff employed in the office of the Minister for Finance.

(2) and (3) The salaries of the two staff, including ministerial allowances, totalled to $65,182.56 to 8 October 1996. This figure makes up the bulk of the financial cost to the Commonwealth of the employment of the staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 22 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Government announce in July 1996 that the export of woodchips from so-called `degraded' forest on private land `would be permitted only if the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with the Minister for the Environment, were satisfied the forest in question does not contain high conservation values which could potentially meet shortfalls in a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) reserve system'.

(2) Did the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations make the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy solely responsible for deciding what is a `degraded' forest and for deciding whether to issue an `degraded forest licence'.
(3) How will the Minister for the Environment be satisfied that forests on private land are not of high conservation value before any application for a `degraded forest licence' is considered.

(4) What criteria and information will be used to determine: (a) whether a forest is `degraded'; (b) what conservation values it has, irrespective of whether it is considered to be `degraded'; (c) whether it is required for the reserve system; and (d) whether it has archaeological or cultural values that require protection.

(5) Given that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is solely responsible under the regulations for determining whether a forest is `degraded' and is constrained by the regulations in the matters he can consider before issuing a licence, what legally enforceable power does the Minister for the Environment have to ensure that the Minister can prevent the issue of a licence which is considered to be environmentally detrimental.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes, but as announced in July, the Government has determined that decisions in relation to issuing degraded forest licences will be made in consultation with myself. It is the general policy of the Office of Legislative Drafting (OLD) not to refer to consultations between Ministers in statutory instruments. Where one Minister is required to consult with another Minister by virtue of the subject matter under consideration, OLD assume that this will occur as a matter of course and it is not necessary to spell it out in regulations.

(3) Under the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, it is the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to determine whether a forest is degraded. However, in accordance with our joint media statement and the regular consultation that normally occurs on such matters, my colleague, the Hon John Anderson MP, will consult me in reaching his decision.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with myself, will consider whether forests on private land are of high conservation value based on:

PARA.TAB: whether the forests are required for the comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) national forest reserve system;
the report of an independent assessor on the general state of the forest; and
any other relevant matter.

ANSWER.PARA: (4) Under the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations, it is the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to determine whether a forest is degraded and for considering a degraded forest licence application. Decisions in relation to issuing degraded forest licences will be made in consultation with myself, and based on the following information:
Under the regulations, the Minister must consider:

PARA.TAB: the general state of the forest, and, in particular, whether the floristic composition of the forest has been altered significantly by reason of disease, weed infestation, harvesting and other human activities, or other causes; and
any other relevant matter.

ANSWER.PARA: (b), (c) and (d)

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy may not grant an export licence if the forest has conservation, heritage or other values which are required for the CAR reserve system. These values will be examined during the comprehensive regional assessments conducted as part of the Regional Forest Agreement process. They are currently protected under Deferred Forest Agreements between the Commonwealth and relevant States.
State laws applying to the protection and management of these values also apply to any forest operations.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is also bound by his obligations under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 when he considers woodchip export licence applications.

(5) The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is solely responsible for considering a degraded forest licence application. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is bound by the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has agreed to consult me when making decisions about whether a forest is degraded. These decisions are legitimate decisions for Government Ministers to make. A person aggrieved by the Minister's decision may apply for a review of that decision under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 28 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to advice given by former Senator Button to Senate Estimates Committee A on 31 March 1987 as to the average weight of 1 000 cigarettes: what has been the average weight of 1 000 cigarettes for each year since Senator Button provided his answer.
(2) Is the average weight of 1 000 cigarettes important for reasons of federal excise and estimating the carcinogenic potential of the tobacco being consumed in Australia.

(3) With reference to the fact that the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee used to publish tables of `estimated total consumption of tobacco products by type' for various years since 1965: (a) can the most up‐to‐date table of this data be provided; (b) is the consumption of each type of tobacco continuing to fall; and (c) if the data recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics or the Australian Customs Service is registering an increase, how can this be reconciled with statements by tobacco companies in their annual reports that consumption is falling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Customs Service does not maintain statistics on average weights of cigarettes. As Senator Button explained in his response to the question in 1987, excise is levied on weight and due to the variation in weights across all brands the exercise of calculating the average weight of 1 000 cigarettes would be too difficult and too costly.
(2) The average weight of 1 000 cigarettes is not directly relevant to the collection of federal excise as the excise is calculated on the actual weight of every tobacco product.

With regard to the importance of the tobacco weight for estimating the carcinogenic potential of the tobacco being consumed in Australia, the Department of Health and Family Services has advised that the chief cancer‐causing constituent of tobacco is tar and the tar content of a given sample of tobacco is not directly related to the weight of that tobacco. The Department advises that there are significant variations in tar content and weight between cigarette brands, rendering the average weight of cigarettes of little value in determining the cancer‐causing effects of tobacco.
(3) (a) No. This information is not collected by the Australian Customs Service.
(b) Tobacco consumption statistics are not collected by the Australian Customs Service.
(c) See (b) above. The Australian Bureau of Statistics have advised that they do not keep statistics on tobacco consumption.
